description:
Ottavio Antonio Bayardi


Prodromo delle antichita d'Ercolano. Naples: Regale stamperia Palatina 1752


5 volumes 4to (227 x 158mm.) half-titles title to vol.1 printed in red and black with engraved illustration woodcut headpieces and initials engraved illustrations vol.1: 6 engraved plates (4 folding) vol.2: 1 folding plate vol.3: 2 folding plates vol.4: engraved plate vol.5: 1 folding engraved plate contemporary Neapolitan calf gilt with the arms of the dedicatee Charles king of the Two Sicilies spines gilt in compartments red speckled edges bookplate removed from vol.1 occasional light foxing or browning 15M1 with tear at foot touching text bindings somewhat rubbed some damage and repairs to ends of spines


This is the first production from the Royal Press in Naples which was established to disseminate the discoveries made at Herculaneum excavated from 1738 on the orders of the King of the Two Sicilies. Many copies of this work were bound in this style; see British Library c.67.h.11 for another example. 


PROVENANCE

parts 1 & 2: Edmund Burke with his Beaconsfield stamp at head of title-pages (he purchased Beaconsfield in 1768) sale Evans 7 November 1833 lot 130 4s to Daniells; parts 2 & 4: Juan Pedro Aladro y Kastriota (1845-1914 pretender to the throne of Albania) armorial bookplates

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: H. Beck von Leopoldsdorf Document signed with signed autograph additions 1577-1582
description:
Hieronymus Beck von Leopoldsdorf


Document signed with signed autograph additions ("Hieronymus Beck von Leopoldstorff"; "H: Beck v. L.") 


3 pages 4to (315 x 215cm.) papered seal Ebreichsdorf (?) 5 January 1577-6 January 1582; together with: an autograph letter signed by Hannibal Beck von Leopoldsdorf (1556-1608 son of Hieronymus Beck) 1 page Vienna 12 December 1603; and an Italian translation of a decree by Louis XIV papered sealNice 9 December 1707


The Austrian Hieronymus Beck von Leopoldsdorf (1525-1596) was a notable Renaissance scholar the owner of a famous humanist library which included the so-called Becksche Portratbuch a 320-page codex with copies of 235 portraits.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Bernard de Paris Vocabolario italiano-turchesco Rome 1665 3 volumes modern half leather
description:
Bernard de Paris


Vocabolario italiano-turchesco... per l'utilita non solamente di quelli che bramaranno d'imparar la lingua Turchesca... [translated from the French by Pietro d'Abbavilla]. Rome: tipografia della Congregazione di Propaganda Fide 1665


3 volumes 4to (223 x 160mm.) half-title woodcut device on verso of title-page modern half brown leather occasional light browning


Bernard de Paris a Capuchin friar was a missionary in Turkey and the Near East and his French-Turkish dictionary was translated into Italian at the behest of the Congregatio de Propaganda Fide. It contains around 25000 entries and includes Turkish Arabic and Persian equivalents.


PROVENANCE

Duque de Hyjar (Hijar) armorial bookplate pasted to half-title

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Bible Greek Venice Aldus 1518 contemporary Venetian alla greca binding
description:
Bible. Greek


Panta ta kat'exokhen kaloumena Biblia theias delade graphes palaias te kai neas. Sacrae Scripturae veteris novaeque omnia. (Venice): Aldus (in the house of Aldus and Andrea Torresano February 1518)


Super-Chancery folio (332 x 210mm.) title-page and headings printed in red 3-line initial spaces with printed guides woodcut Aldine device on title-page (in red) and final verso (otherwise blank) woodcut initials and headpieces nearly all printed in red (except for the Epistles) with blank leaves aaaa4 dddd10 and hhhththth9 CONTEMPORARY VENETIAN ALLA GRECA BINDING blind-tooled morocco with arabesque decoration over wooden boards with later metal bosses some staining and worming throughout (mostly in the gutter) title-page torn and somewhat stained cg1 cg8 and Po1 detached tttt4 frayed candle wax drops (and stains) in the Gospels burn hole in zzpsps8 with loss of a few words binding somewhat worn and slightly defective lacking all four clasps


A TALL AND UNSOPHISTICATED COPY OF THE FIRST GREEK BIBLE IN A CONTEMPORARY ALLA GRECA BINDING.


The binding tools are found on other strictly contemporary Venetian bindings; one arabesque tool also appears on Davis Gift 271 (Venice c. 1521) the outer border tool on Davis Gift 272 (a dogale dated c. 1521 connected with the Mendoza Binder) and De Marinis 1616 (dogale dated 1489) the inner corner stamps on Davis Gift 276 (Venice c. 1525) and another small arabesquse stamp on De Marinis 1631 and 1644. 


This copy shows use in a Greek Orthodox liturgical context with candle wax stains in the Gospels but not elsewhere.


LITERATURE

Darlow & Moule 4594; Edit16 61055; Renouard 1518/8; Texas 156; UCLA 142


PROVENANCE

Giovanni Antonio Palavicino of Milan inscription on inside lower cover; inscription in Greek on inside lower cover dated 1714

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: [Bible] Epistolae Divi Pauli Apostoli Venice da Sabbio 1533 contemporary Venetian morocco with initials DLF
description:
Bible. New Testament. Epistles


Epistolae divi Pauli Apostoli cum triplici editione ad veritatem Graecam. (Venice: Giovanni Antonio Nicolini da Sabbio and brothers for Giovanni Antonio Garuffa January 1533)


8vo (144 x 100mm.) small woodcut of St Paul on title-page parallel text in Greek and Latin with final blank leaf contemporary Venetian blind-tooled morocco with gilt armorial with initials D.F.L. blue edges stubs from two pairs of ties extremities very slightly rubbed ends of spine repaired


The text of the Epistles is provided in Greek the Vulgate and the Latin versions of Erasmus and Jacques Lefevre d'Etaples. The editor Damiano Loro prior at the Dominican monastery of SS Giovanni e Paolo in Venice was considered a preacher of heretical ideas. 


A shield of a similar design was used by the Fugger Binder who was active in Venice at this time. De Marinis 2044 2299 and 2300 (all Venetian bindings) show the same armorial stamp.


LITERATURE

Edit16 6003

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: [Bible] New Testament in Greek Venice Nicolini da Sabbio 1539 modern leather
description:
Bible. New Testament. Greek


[Ieron Evangelion]. (Venice: Stefano Nicolini da Sabbio for Girolamo Giraldi and Damiano Santa Maria 1539)


folio (315 x 195mm.) a-b10 g-u8 ph6 text in Greek printed in red and black throughout with woodcut headpieces woodcut device below colophon modern tan leather with stepped cross tooled on upper cover old flyleaves with watermark of the Three Kings (probably German eighteenth century) lacking title-page and ph1_6 (the latter blank) stained with some fraying at edges repaired wormholes in lower margin


RARE. The Nicolini da Sabbio brothers printed numerous works aimed at members of the Greek Orthodox Church instigated by Andrea Cunadis a merchant of Patras resident in Venice. He died in 1522 and his work was continued by his son-in-law Damiano Santa Maria who is mentioned in the colophon here.


LITERATURE

Edit16 66362 no copies recorded; Legrand I:99 mentioning a copy in the Bavarian State Library Munich

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: [Bible] Novum testamentum [Greek] Paris 1546 contemporary morocco with gilt interlaced panel stamp
description:
Bible. New Testament. Greek


Tes kaines diathekes apanta. Novum testamentum. Paris: Robert Estienne 1546


2 parts in one volume 16mo (128 x 82mm.) woodcut device on title-pages different Estienne device on final verso woodcut initials and headpieces text in Greek ruled in red contemporary Parisian brown morocco with gilt interlaced design gilt edges small repairs to title-page second title-page loose binding slightly rubbed small label on upper cover


A charming copy of the small-format Estienne Greek New Testament the first Estienne edition of the Greek text in a fine contemporary interlaced binding.


LITERATURE

Darlow & Moule 4616; Mortimer Harvard French 74; USTC 149681


PROVENANCE

Presentation bookplate of Barthelemy Halle priest of Rouen and archdeacon of Ango sieur de Pittres et Berselou; Leopold Double sale 1863 lot 358; Thomas Brooke (1830-1908) of Armitage Bridge armorial bookplate (not found in the sale catalogue of Sir John Arthur Brooke Sotheby Wilkinson & Hodge 25 May 1921)

description:

Tes kaines diathekes apanta... Novum Iesu Christi D.N. Testamentum. Paris: Robert Estienne 1550


folio (329 x 220mm.) woodcut printer's device on title-page canon tables within woodcut frames woodcut initials and headpieces ruled in red near-contemporary limp vellum gilt edges last two leaves damaged and repaired with slight loss; otherwise a good copy


The Editio regia with critical apparatus in the margins indicating variant readings taken from manuscripts (including the Codex Bezae) and the Complutensian Polyglot.

description:

Quatuor evangelia graece [edited by Andreas Birch]. Copenhagen: J.F. Schutz 1788


folio (378 x 240mm.) LARGE PAPER COPY 3 plates of facsimiles vellum gilt by Charles Lewis gilt edges binding lightly soiled


A critical edition of the text of the Gospels based on first-hand examination of early manuscripts across European libraries by Andreas Birch (1758-1829) from the library of the celebrated bibliophile Frances Mary Richardson Currer.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Bilberg De refractio solis Stockholm 1695 contemporary half vellum
description:
Johan Bilberg


Refractio solis inoccidui in septemtrionalibus oris... circa Solstitium aestivum MDCXCV... Midnats solens ratta och synlige rum uti norrlanden effter... hallne wid sommar solstandet ar 1695. Stockholm: N. Wankijf 1695


4to (182mm.) parallel text in Latin and Swedish woodcut vignette on recto of first title-page woodcut initials and headpieces 5 double-sided woodcut plates contemporary vellum-backed boards a few manuscript annotations binding slightly soiled


FIRST EDITION. Bilberg (1646-1717) was professor of mathematics at Uppsala university and later bishop of Strangnas and was a proponent of Copernicanism and Cartesianism in Sweden.


An English translation was published in 1698 with the title A voyage of the late King of Sweden and another of mathematicians sent by him: in which are discover'd the refraction of the Sun which sets not in the northern parts at the time of the Summer Solstice.


LITERATURE

BL STC Scandinavian B586


PROVENANCE

Joh. Hernodius; And. Larson; Claes [--] signatures on first recto

Johannes Hernodius was an astronomer; his dissertation on the lunar cycle was printed in Uppsala in 1711.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Boileau-Despreaux | Oeuvres poetiques Parma Bodoni 1814 2 volumes extra illustrated
description:
Nicolas Boileau-Despreaux


Oeuvres poetiques. Parma: de l'imprimerie de la Veuve Bodoni 1814


2 volumes folio (445 x 315mm.) EXTRA ILLUSTRATED WITH NUMEROUS ENGRAVED PLATES from other editions works by the author together with ornamental prints by Stefano Della Bella and Quellinus late nineteenth-century blue half morocco gilt some spotting small inventory label stuck to binding; sold as a collection of plates not subject to return


The additional plates include various portraits of Boileau (around 20 at the start of volume 1 and around 16 in volume 2) two facsimiles of letters at the start of volume 2 over 80 plates for "Le Lutrin" (some in two states or proof states) cuttings from a seventeenth-century edition of his works inserted at relevant points in the volumes a series of engraved friezes from Cahier d'arabesques composes par C. L. Desrais en 1789 and Stefano della Bella Ornament[i] di fregi et fogliami (Paris: N. Langlois) at the end of volume 1 and 26 plates from Quellinus Aerdighe Festonnen at the end of volume 2.


LITERATURE

Brooks 1150

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Bolzanio Grammaticae institutiones Basel 1524 limp vellum
description:
Urbano Bolzanio


Grammaticae institutiones tam tanta adhuc iterum cura excussae ut maiora vix potuerint. Basel: (Valentin Curio) 1524


4to (214 x 135mm.) title within woodcut border woodcut initials and headpieces Qq3-4 transposed woodcut printer's device on final verso later limp vellum a few manuscript annotations occasional light staining small repairs to title-page


Bolzanio studied under Constantine Lascaris before moving to Florence and teaching an impressive array of students from Giovanni de' Medici to Scipione Forteguerri. His Greek grammar the first to be composed in Latin was first printed by Aldus in 1497.


LITERATURE

2 volumes Chancery folio (283 x 196mm.) part I: 380 leaves [*8] 2-46 a b8 c-f6.8 g h6 i-y8.6 z8 A-M6.8 N-Q6 R-Y8.6 Z8 AA6 BB8 CC DD6 EE8; part II: 370 leaves 2A8 B C6 aa bb8 cc-qq6.8 rr-tt6 vv-zz8.62AA-QQ8.6 RR SS6 TT-YY8.6 ZZ8 Aaa-Eee6 double column 52 lines plus headline and foliations "I-CCCLV" (I fos a1-EE7) and "I-CCCXLIX" (II fos 2A1-EEE6) gothic type initial spaces 4 woodcut illustrations a few contemporary marginal notes cancellation of lines of text and nota signs (including maniculae) in brown ink throughout contemporary blind-stamped Italian sheep over wooden boards paper labels on spines two clasps bindings worn and repaired lacking all straps

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: [Book of hours] Heures nostre dame a l'usage de Rouen Rouen [1593] vellum gilt binding
description:
Property from the Loverdos Collection


Book of hours. Use of Rouen


Three devotional works printed in Rouen in a contemporary gilt vellum binding comprising:


Heures nostre dame a l'usage de Rouen. Rouen: Henri le Mareschal (George Loyselet) [almanach 1593-1613] printed in red and black woodcut illustrations (some signed NV)


Francois le Picart. Les grans suffrages et oraisons. Rouen: Henri le Mareschal [no date] woodcut illustrations woodcut device at end with final blank leaf


La vie mort passion et resurrection de nostre Sauveur & Redempteur iesus christ. Rouen: Henri le Mareschal [no date] woodcut on title-page woodcut initials


3 works in one volume 8vo (170 x 107mm.) contemporary painted vellum gilt with panel stamp of the Crucifixion and arabesque corner pieces first title repaired in gutter first A8 becoming loose final quires of second work becoming loose final work with some tears and small holes textblock split at start of third part (becoming loose) binding somewhat rubbed spine creased with slight loss


A RARE ROUEN BOOK OF HOURS. Henri le Mareschal was active as a bookseller in Rouen from 1574 to 1622.


LITERATURE

1. Bohatta 1366 [but with imprint of Nicolas Vautier]; USTC 7403 (recording just one fragmentary copy in Nantes)

2. USTC 7418 (recording one copy only in Nantes)

3. not found in any of the standard bibliographies

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Breviarium romanum Antwerp Plantin 1733 4 volumes contemporary calf gilt with pull-off cases
description:
Breviarium romanum


A three-volume set of the Roman Breviary together with a Carthusian breviary eighteenth century comprising:


Breviarium romanum ex decreto Sacrosancti Concilii Trident. restitutum... Pars hiemalis (Pars verna; pars autumnalis). Antwerp: Ex Architypographia Plantiniana 1733 (1723) 3 volumes (of 4) printed in red and black engraved vignettes on title-pages full-page engraved illustration at start of Psalter uniform contemporary Spanish calf gilt edges gilt and gauffered without summer sectionsome light browning


[Breviarium sacri Ordinis Cartusiensis (Supplementum Breviarii Cartusiani). "Correriae" [i.e. Curriere (near Grenoble): Imprimerie de la Grande-Chartreuse] 1717] contemporary blind-tooled calf over wooden boards printed and manuscript corrections to the calendar annotations lacking title-page some paper repairs and light staining


together 4 volumes 4to (231 x 170mm.) housed in four uniform Spanish pull-off cases with gilt numbering 1-4 some boxes somewhat worn; sold as a set not subject to return


The Roman Breviary volumes also include the relevant section of the Proprium sanctorum Hispanorum (Antwerp 1723) bound at the end along with a few other short liturgies for particular feasts.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Bude Commentarii linguae Graecae Paris 1529 later half calf
description:
Property from the Spyros Loverdos collection


Guillaume Bude


Commentarii linguae graecae. Paris: Jodocus Badius Ascensius September 1529


folio (328 x 218mm.) title printed in red and black within woodcut border and with Ascensius's printer's device of a print shop woodcut crible initials without final blank leaf early nineteenth-century calf-backed boards spine gilt in compartments with red morocco lettering-piece occasional light staining at foredge lower joint cracked


FIRST EDITION and a large crisp copy of Bude's magisterial work on Greek prose with a few neat early annotations. Bude arranged his entries thematically rather than alphabetically.


LITERATURE

PMM 60; Renouard Ascensius II 239; USTC 146015


PROVENANCE

Mequignon junior Paris bookseller's label

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Caesar Comentarios Alcala de Henares Miguel de Eguia 1529 modern calf
description:
Gaius Julius Caesar


Commentarios... nuevamente impressos y corregidos. (Alcala de Henares: Miguel de Eguia) 1529


small folio (265 x 185mm.) title within historiated woodcut border verso of title-page within woodcut border woodcut initials modern leather lacking A1 containing portrait only small area of damage and repair to title affecting a small area of the border and a few words on the verso cut close at head (a couple of headlines shaved) occasional foxing or staining extremities slightly rubbed


The translation by Diego Lopez de Toledo was first printed in Toledo in 1498.


Eguia was the son-in-law and successor of Guillen de Brocar. The text on the verso of the title-page Eguia's dedication is in italic type which was first used in Spain the previous year by Cromberger of Seville.


LITERATURE

IB 2360; Palau 54138; USTC 335637

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Caesar Quae extant London Tonson 1712 contemporary diced russia gilt
description:
Gaius Julius Caesar


Quae extant. Accuratissime cum libris editis & MSS optimis collata recognita & correcta. Accesserunt annotationes Samuelis Clarke. London: James Tonson 1712


folio (453 x 280mm.) double-page engraved additional title-page engraved frontispiece portrait of the Duke of Marlborough engraved head- and tailpieces and initials 61 double-page engraved plates and maps 23 single engraved plates contemporary diced russia gilt spine gilt in compartments incorporating small bird dolphin and crown and sceptre tools marbled edges corners bumped and repaired joints cracked


Tonson's magnificent edition of Caesar's works richly illustrated with maps camp layouts depictions of native peoples and their customs and a set of engravings of Mantegna's Triumph of the Caesars (now at Hampton Court). According to ESTC this is one of the ordinary paper copies (there were also large paper copies around 5cm taller).


LITERATURE

ESTC T136730


PROVENANCE

old shelfmark "Est. F. Plut. 1N.17" on inside front cover (seemingly from the Biblioteca real Madrid); old shelfmark "C.21.c.1" on flyleaf

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Bassus Geoponika; De re rustica Basel 1539 later tan morocco gilt Syston Park copy
description:
Cassianus Bassus


A volume from the Syston Park library comprising:


Geoponika. De re rustica selectorum libri XX [edited by Simon Grynaeus]. Basel: (Robert Winter 1539) text in Greek woodcut initials woodcut printer's device on final verso foot of title-page repaired lacking preface (a2-8 supplied in neat contemporary manuscript)De agricultura libri viginta. Basel: Froben 1540 woodcut printer's device on title-page and final verso woodcut initials 


2 works in one volume 8vo (150 x 95mm.) nineteenth-century tan morocco gilt by S. Ridge of Grantham with his ticket spine gilt in compartments gilt edges joints rubbed


FIRST EDITION of the Greek text of Geoponika bound with a Latin translation by Janus Cornarius. It was a compilation made for the Emperor Constantine VII Porphyrogenitus as one of a series of handbooks of classical learning on various subjects. The text was based on the sixth-century Eclogae of Cassianus Bassus who is thought to have lived in Antiochia (northern Syria).


LITERATURE

VD16 C 1413 & C 1415


PROVENANCE

Sir John Hayford Thorold Syston Park Library sale Sotheby Wilkinson & Hodge 12 December 1884 lot 826 10s.; Harvard College Library booklabels and presentation stamp dated 1908

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Cebes Tabula [Florence: Lorenzo de Alopa c. 1496] crushed tan morocco by Chambolle-Duru
description:
Property from the Loverdos collection


Cebes


Tabula. Basilius Magnus: De legendis antiquorum libris sive De liberalibus studiis. Plutarchus: De liberis educandis. Xenophon: Hiero de tyrannide [all in Greek]. [Florence: Lorenzo de Alopa c. 1496]


8vo (172 x 110mm.) 74 leaves a-i8 k2 quire e misbound between k1-2 Greek text crushed tan morocco by Chambolle-Duru gilt edges washed


EDITIONES PRINCIPES. The philosophical tract called Pinax (painting or tablet) an allegorical description of the human life and condition with its attendant virtues and temptations is attributed here to the Cebes of Thebes mentioned by Plato; it is now considered a Hellenistic work from the second century. It was widely known and translated in the early modern world (influencing writers such as Milton and Quevedo) and here appears with three other educational tracts indicating that it was designed as an aid to the study of Greek.


LITERATURE

ISTC ic00356000

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Geoffrey Chaucer The workes London 1561 contemporary calf
description:
Geoffrey Chaucer


The workes... newlie printed with divers addicions whiche were never in print before. [London: John Kingston for John Wright] 1561


Folio (312 x 210mm.) Black Letter letterpress title within woodcut architectural border section titles for The Canterbury Tales and The Romaunt of the Rose within wide woodcut borders woodcut initials and illustrations title with contemporary and slightly later manuscript inscriptions and quotations contemporary ruled calf title repaired and laid down some other repairs with minor loss lacking the last leaf supplied in ?seventeenth-century ink binding somewhat worn rebacked and repaired


[with loosely inserted:] Chidiock Tichborne scribal manuscript copy of part of 'Tichborne's Lament' seven lines in an Elizabethan secretary hand with contemporary corrections to two lines in a darker ink with significant variants from the established text on a paper fragment (45 x 125mm) some staining and fraying with remains of red wax seals



The woodcuts are based on those used by Caxton for his famous edition of 1483; some of the blocks here were used by Richard Pynson. Caxton's editions had the woodcut for each character in both the prologue and start of each tale but this was reduced in subsequent editions to the prologues only with the exception of the first tale in the book the Knight's Tale. Kingston also issued this work without any woodcuts in the prologue possibly because he only obtained the blocks part way through printing (see D.R. Carlson "Woodcut illustrations of the Canterbury Tales 1483-1602" The Library 19 (1997) 25-67 p.50)


This book also contains a loose fragment of 'Tichborne's Lament' or Elegy which was written shortly before the author's execution for his involvement in the Babington Plot. The poem was widely circulated in manuscript form with numerous textual variants. 50 manuscript copies are recorded in CELM.


LITERATURE

STC 5076


PROVENANCE

Rob: Smithe contemporary ownership inscription on title

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Chevalier Alphabetum hebraicum & graecum Geneva 1566 & 1600 modern leather
description:
Property from the Loverdos Collection


Antoine-Rodolphe Chevalier and Theodore de Beze


Two grammatical works on Greek and Hebrew in one volume comprising:


CHEVALIER. Alphabetum hebraicum in quo literae hebraicae describuntur. Geneva: Henri Estienne 1566 woodcut device on title-page


DE BEZE. Alphabetum graecum & hebraicum [edited by Chevalier]. Geneva: Paul Estienne 1600 woodcut device on title-page upper margin cut close


2 works in one volume 8vo (160 x 95mm.) modern speckled calf


Rodolphe Chevalier was a Huguenot exile in England who returned to the Continent on the accession of Mary; he taught Hebrew at Cambridge Geneva and Strassburg. This is the first edition of his short work on the Hebrew alphabet which includes the Ten Commandments with an interlinear Latin translation and it is the first publication by Henri Estienne using Hebrew type.


In this copy the imprint GENEVAE has been hand-stamped onto the correct place on the title-pages.


LITERATURE

1st work: GLN-2304; Schreiber Estienne 158; 2nd work: 3 entries in USTC 6703453 & 199288 & 6703482


PROVENANCE

Carolus Dumans old signature on flyleaf

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Chrysoloras Erotemata Guarini Reggio Emilia 1501 later red morocco gilt Dampier-Chatsworth copy
description:
Property from the Loverdos Collection


Manuel Chrysoloras


Erotemata Guarini. Reggio Emilia: Benedetto Manzi for Simone Bombace Pontico Virunio and Dionigi Bertocchi 10 July 1501


8vo (143 x 87mm.) ruled in red eighteenth-century red morocco gilt in the style of Roger Payne gilt edges washed and browned resulting in friable paper damaged at end with loss of text; sold not subject to return


This edition was prepared by the scholar Pontico Virunio who began teaching Greek in Reggio Emilia in December 1500. The printing partnership with Bombace and Bertocchi using Manzi's press had been established in late 1499 but did not last long.


LITERATURE

Edit16 14533; Botley Learning Greek in Western Europe 1396-1529 Appendix 1:23


PROVENANCE

Thomas Dampier (1748-1812) bishop of Ely inscription on flyleaf; Chatsworth bookplate (listed in volume II p.217 of the 1879 Chatsworth library catalogue under Guarini) but not found in the sales from Chatsworth in the early 1980s

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Chrysoloras Grammatica Paris 1507 later calf
description:
Manuel Chrysoloras


Erotemata... Grammatica [edited by Francois Tissard]. (Paris: Gilles de Gourmont 1 December 1507)


4to (210 x 140mm.) woodcut printer's device on title-page first initial in blue on a gold ground with strawberry decoration red and blue paraphs ruled in red early manuscript interlinear Latin translation in first few leaves eighteenth-century mottled calf gilt flat spine gilt binding slightly rubbed


THE FIRST GREEK GRAMMAR PRINTED IN FRANCE. The editor Tissard states that he studied Greek with Battista Guarino in Ferrara (as did Aldus Manutius and many other notable scholars both Italian and foreign). This edition contains the full text of the Erotemata rather than the abridged version by Guarino. The typeface used by Gourmont has the accents on separate sorts.


For the 1501 Reggio edition of this grammar see lot 48 and for the 1512 Alcala edition see lot 50.


LITERATURE

BP16 100880; USTC 180245; Botley Learning Greek in Western Europe 1396-1529 Appendix 1: 30


PROVENANCE

early armorial of a tree with a name in a banner at foot of preface; Vincenzo ink stamp on flyleaf

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Chrysoloras Erotemata; Musaeus Opusculum de Erone et Leandro Alcala de Henares 1514 vellum
description:
Manuel Chrysoloras and Musaeus


Two works in Greek printed in Alcala by Arnao Guillen de Brocar in one volume comprising:


MANUEL CHRYSOLORAS. Erotemata. Erotemata. De formatione temporum ex libro chalcondylae. Quartus gazae de constructione. De anomalis verbis. De encliticis. Sententiae monostichi ex variis poetis. (Alcala de Henares: Arnao Guillen de Brocar 10 April 1514) large woodcut armorial of Cardinal Jimenes on title-page parallel text in Greek and Latin woodcut printer's device at end


MUSAEUS. Poiemation ta kat'ero kai leandron. Opusculum de erone et leandro [edited by Demetrios Doukas]. (Alcala de Henares): [Arnao Guillen de Brocar c. 1514] 8 leaves text in Greek large woodcut armorial of Cardinal Jimenes on title-page


2 works in one volume 4to (206 x 142mm.) modern vellum numerous early annotations in different hands (some in red ink) title-pages and a few other leaves with paper repairs some marginal annotations in corrosive ink causing slight damage in quire T


THE FIRST GREEK GRAMMAR PRINTED IN SPAIN. A RARE VOLUME OF GREEK WORKS PRINTED IN ALCALA in the font designed for the Complutensian Polyglot Bible. They were both produced (and perhaps financed) by the Cretan scholar Demetrios Doukas.


The colophon for the Musaeus states the involvement of Cardinal Francisco Jimenes and the skill of Demetrios Doukas "the Cretan"; Doukas had been brought to Alcala by the Cardinal to work on his Complutensian Polyglot printed in 1514-1522.


Chrysoloras's grammar in question and answer format was the most widely-used grammar of the fifteenth century partly due to the epitomised version produced by Guarino Veronese. This is a reprint of the 1512 Aldine edition of the full text which Doukas had also worked on. See lots 48-49 for other editions.


We have not been able to find any sale records for these works.


LITERATURE

IB 3243 & 4879 (listing 18 and 7 copies respectively); Martin Abad 407 & 1090; Palau 67956 & 186423; Chrysoloras: Botley Learning Greek in Western Europe 1396-1529 Appendix I:55

description:
Johannes Crastonus


Lexicon Graeco-latinum [with other grammatical tracts]. Venice: Aldus Manutius December 1497


Super-Chancery folio (305 x 203mm.) 243 leaves (of 244 without final blank) a-i k8 l10 A-K8 L10 M8 N10 O p-r8 s6 t8 42 lines text in Latin and Greek one woodcut initial on O1 initial spaces with printed guides early annotations in Greek and Latin in several hands mostly comprising additional dictionary entries modern green morocco gilt spine gilt in compartments doublures of red morocco gilt tooled in the manner of a sixteenth-century Spanish binding with the royal arms of Spain first quire washed and pressed with some marginal paper repairs occasional light staining last leaf repaired at head with loss of a few letters


This Greek-Latin lexicon was first printed in 1476 and was based by Crastone on earlier work by Lascaris and other Greek scholars; this is the third edition to which additional grammatical tracts and other supplementary material have been added including Crastone's Latin-Greek dictionary which previously appeared as a separate publication. The index of Latin terms was provided by Aldus who in his preface ad lectorem (O4v) explains how to use the dictionary and its index starting with the advice that readers should first number the leaves as the index provides leaf and line numbers for each entry.


LITERATURE

description:
Dionysius Periegetes


Tes oikoumenes periegesis upomnematisthesia. De situ orbis libellus [commentary by Eustathius Thessalonicensis]. Paris: Robert Estienne 1547


4to (251 x 166mm.) text in Greek woodcut Estienne device on title-page numerous early annotations in a neat humanist hand in both Latin and Greek dated 12 March 1572 later straight-grained green calf gilt spine gilt in compartments with the lettering "C. NOTIS MSS. CURTERII" gilt edges small adhesive label to upper cover


A FINE COPY WITH ANNOTATIONS BY THE SIXTEENTH-CENTURY GREEK SCHOLAR JOANNES CURTERIUS. Not much is known of Joannes Curterius (c. 1540?-after 1583 Jean Courtier?) who edited and translated Greek texts; he has been described as both French and English living in Paris. He was the tutor of members of the La Rochefoucauld family with whom he was in Bologna in 1579 according to one of his prefaces (see Anna Cataldi Palau Greek Manuscripts from the Meerman Collection pp.25-26).


The marginal annotations in this volume are delineated by a fold along the outer margin of each leaf and mostly refer to the place names mentioned in the text but with a few other notes of interest; in the section about the Nile (p.40) Curterius has written out the number of each letter (according to the Greek system of numerals) to find that the letters Neilos add up to 365. He also provides the date that he completed his reading 12 March 1572 below the end of the text.


LITERATURE

Renouard Estienne p.70; USTC 149783


PROVENANCE

"Joannis Curterii 1559" paper label pasted to inside front cover; Joh. item_title: Etymologicum magnum graecum Venice 1499 later calf gilt Bute-Broxbourne copy
description:
Etymologicum magnum graecum


[edited by Marcus Musurus]. Venice: Zacharias Callierges for Nicolaus Blastos and Anna Notaras 8 July 1499


Super-Royal folio (404 x 261mm.) 224 leaves A10 B-O AA-GG8 DD6 50 lines double column Greek type printed in red and black Byzantine-style 5- and 10-line woodcut initials and headpieces printed in red woodcut printers' device at end printed in red eighteenth-century English diced calf gilt red silk endleaves gilt edges rebacked to style extremities rubbed small adhesive label to spine


THE BUTE-BROXBOURNE COPY of this twelfth-century Byzantine compilation a crisp copy of the first printed Greek dictionary and the first book from the exclusively Greek press of Zacharias Callierges. He had the financial backing of Blastos a fellow Cretan and a stationer and Anna Notaras the daughter of a Byzantine nobleman who had settled in Venice.


LITERATURE

ISTC ie00112000; Legrand I 23; Sander 7110 Botley Learning Greek in Western Europe 1396-1529 Appendix 2:7


PROVENANCE

[Earl of Bute Luton Hoo library]; "Luton" written in blue pencil on flyleaf and "Bute copy" note on flyleaf by; Alfred Ehrman bookplate sale of the Broxbourne Library Sotheby's 9 May 1978 lot 655 PS2800 to N. Israel

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Euclid Elementa geometriae Vicenza 1491 later vellum
description:
Euclid


Elementa geometriae [translated by Adelardus Bathoniensis edited by Johannes Campanus]. Vicenza: Leonardus Achates de Basilea and Guilielmus de Papia [13 May or 20 June] 1491


Chancery folio (290 x 200mm.) 136 leaves (of 138 without initial and final blanks) a10 b-r8 49 lines plus headline roman type first heading printed in red 4- to 8-line woodcut initials a2 within woodcut border marginal woodcut diagrams later Italian vellum spine lettered in gilt woodcut border shaved r2 repaired in gutter last leaf torn and repaired (without loss of text) binding slightly defective at foredges


SECOND EDITION a close reprint of the 1482 Ratdolt first edition (and somewhat rarer) though in roman type rather than gothic and retaining the innovative layout of marginal explanatory diagrams. "The six-hundred-odd diagrams which were ingeniously designed for the editio princeps illustrated Euclidean proofs somewhat less 'dimly' than had been done in many hand-copied books. Printed diagrams endowed the Elements with a clarity and uniformity that they had not possessed before. Is it too fanciful to suggest that Euclid was associated thereafter less with Latin verbiage and more with triangles circles and squares?" (E. Eisenstein The Printing Press as an Agent of Change Cambridge 1979 p. 588).

Ratdolt's version of Euclid was the medieval version of Campanus of Novara based on the Latin translation of Adelard of Bath. The earliest surviving manuscript of this version dates to 1259; "the additiones Campanus made to his basic Euclidean text are particularly notable. With an eye to making the Elements as self-contained as possible he devoted considerable care to the elucidation and discussion of what he felt to be obscure and debatable points. He also attempted to work Euclid more into the current of thirteenth-century mathematics by relating the Elements to and even supplementing it with material drawn from the Arithmetica of Jordanus de Nemore" (DSB IV p.446).


Leonardus Achates from Basel was the first printer in Vicenza where he began work in 1474 after printing in nearby Sant'Orso and Padua. It is one of two books he is known to have printed in association with Guilielmus de Papia.


LITERATURE

ISTC ie00114000; Steck II.5; Thomas-Stanford 2

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern

This is the first parallel Greek-Latin text edition of Euclid which was reprinted at least ten times during the sixteenth century. It was edited by Stephanus Gracilis.

8vo (179 x 122mm.) parallel text in Greek and Latin woodcut printer's device on title-page and final verso woodcut initials near-contemporary blind-stamped pigskin with a roll-tooled border with medallion portraits of Caesar Cicero Vergil and Ovid interspersed with German princely armorials (plausibly by the Kasseler Hofbuchbinder EBDB w00041) line numbers added in red crayon for Iphigenia in Aulis manuscript annotations in a German hand (plausibly made by the eighteenth-century owner)


Erasmus's dedications are to William Warham Archbishop of Canterbury his patron and friend whom he first met in London in 1505. His translations of these two plays made while he was in Louvain in 1502-1504 were first printed in 1506 and regularly reprinted throughout the sixteenth century.

description:

Historia ecclesiastica [translated by Rufinus Aquileiensis].


Mantua: Johannes Schallus [not before 15] July 1479

Chancery folio (293 x 195mm.) 171 leaves (of 172 without final blank) [a-s8 t-y6.8] roman type 34 lines 4- to 6-line initial spaces with printed guides later cat's paw calf gilt with the arms of Pius VI spine gilt in compartments blue edges first quire slightly wormed with a few paper repairs small wormhole at end with slight loss of text slightly stained at end binding rubbed with a few small defects and repairs


Fourth edition dedicated by Schallus to Federigo Gonzaga duke of Mantua. The History of the Church written by Eusebius is one of the most important sources for the history of Christianity. The work which in its last recension in the author's lifetime was extended to ten books was translated into Latin in the fourth century by Rufinus of Aquileia a friend of St Jerome and a considerable translator from the Greek.

The entry for 1509 (folio 172 verso) describes the arrival in France of seven indigenous men from Newfoundland brought by Thomas Aubert of the Jean Angot. Euaggelikes progaraskeues bib. pentakaideka. Evangelicae praeparationis lib. XV. Paris: Robert Estienne 1544

Euaggelikes apodeixeos biblia deka. Evangelicae demonstrationis lib. X. Paris: Robert Estienne 1545 (1546)


2 works in one volume folio (323 x 200mm.) woodcut printer's device on title-pages different woodcut device on final verso of second work text in Greek woodcut initials and headpieces eighteenth-century calf gilt with later greek key border occasional light foxing a few small tears and small areas of damp-staining binding slightly rubbed rebacked


First edition of the Greek text of two works by Eusebius written to justify Christian rejection of Greek religion and philosophy in favour of that of the Hebrews.


LITERATURE

USTC 149170 & 160189; Schreiber Estienne 77


PROVENANCE

Victor Brodean early presentation inscription (slightly trimmed) at head of title-page (there was a sixteenth-century poet with this name); Ex Bibliothecae F. Oberthur (Franz Oberthur 1745-1831 the theologian?) inscription on inside front cover

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Eustathius Parekbolai eis ten Omerou Iliada kai Odusseia Basel 1560 3 volumes old calf gilt
description:
Eustathius


Parekbolai eis ten Omerou Iliada kai Odusseian... Eustathii archiepiscopi Thessalonicae in Homeri Iliadis et Odysseae libros parekbolai. Basel: (Hieronymus Froben and Nikolaus Episcopius) 1560 (1559)


2 volumes bound in 3 folio (317 x 210mm.) woodcut device on title-page and at the end of the Iliad woodcut initials and headpieces manuscript motto "permitte Divis caetera" at end of each volume with the initials BC old smooth calf with later gilt wreath centrepiece in period style spine gilt in compartments old inscriptions on title-pages crossed through final leaf of Odyssey torn and repaired bindings rubbed and stained with some repairs to spine ends and edges rebacked with period gilt tooling and new endpapers small adhesive labels to spines


The extensive commentary of Eustathius accompanied by the text of Homer was first printed by Antonio Blado in Rome in 1542-1550. It was compiled in the twelfth century from earlier commentators and demonstrates Eustathius's wide reading; many of the works he quotes from and some variant readings would be otherwise unknown.


LITERATURE

VD16 H 4595

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Ficinus De triplici vita Basel 1498 half calf over wooden boards
description:
Marsilius Ficinus


De vita libri tres (De triplici vita). [Basel: Johann Amerbach not after 1498]


4to (203 x 150mm.) 100 leaves a-l8 m-n6 35 lines plus headline roman type 3- to 6-line initial spaces numerous early annotations (some in red ink in an attractive hand) old half calf over wooden boards in imitation of a contemporary binding uncut quire a misbound some wormholes in text and binding calf rubbed


This is one of several fifteenth-century editions following the first of 1489. Ficino's spiritual work comprises three sections on healthy living on long life and on obtaining a life in accord with the heavens the last of which drew negative attention from the Church authorities for containing heretical themes.


LITERATURE

ISTC if00160000

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Galenus [Opera] Venice Aldus 1525 5 volumes old vellum
description:
Property from the Loverdos Collectoin


Claudius Galenus


[Opera omnia] Galenou A' (-E'). Venice: Aldus (in the house of Aldus and Andrea Torresano April) 1525


5 volumes folio (328 x 227mm.) woodcut Aldine device on title-pages and at end of each volume text in Greek with blank leaves f4 and &6 in vol.1 *3 in vol.2 *3 in vol.3 PPp8 in vol.4 and Yy10 in vol.5 annotations in various hands old vellum blue edges a few deckle edges occasional staining worming in gutter of vols 2-3 (sometimes affecting text) vol.4 with damage to lower corner of first few quires and with hole in the text of the last few quires a few small holes in text of vol.5 bindings refurbished with new endpapers


EDITIO PRINCEPS of the surviving works of Galen (129-c. 200) one of the most significant medical writers of antiquity. Despite its faults this is still a relatively tall and crisp copy showing extensive use by numerous readers.


This copy contains some pressed flowers and plants mostly in volume 5; some of them are accompanied by a manuscript label stating the species and the date such as Lagoecia cuminoides (wild cumin) picked in Athens in May 1839. Most of these date from 1838 and 1839.


LITERATURE

Cataldi Palau 95; PMM 33; UCLA 231-233 235-236

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Theodorus Gaza Grammatica introductiva Venice Aldus 1495 contemporary tooled morocco
description:
Property from the Loverdos collection


Theodorus Gaza


Grammatica introductiva [Greek]; De mensibus. Apollonius Dyscolus: De constructione [Greek]. Herodianus: De numeris [Greek]. Venice: Aldus Manutius 25 December 1495

Super-Chancery folio (302 x 201mm.) 198 leaves a8 bb-ll82a8 b10 AA-LL8 MM4 woodcut headpieces and initials Greek text contemporary Venetian blind-tooled morocco stubs from two pairs of ties slight worming throughout (more at beginning and end) first few leaves slightly stained lower corners of [2]a4-5 torn upper joint cracked foot of spine torn


FIRST EDITION of Gaza's influential Greek grammar and one of the first products of Aldus Manutius's newly established press in Venice. 


Plausibly composed while Gaza was teaching Greek in Ferrara in the 1440s or possibly later while he was in Rome it was certainly available by 1462 and circulated widely across Europe in the later fifteenth century in manuscript form with several manuscripts being written England before the publication of the text by Aldus. Aldus added the grammatical tracts by Apollonius Dyscolus and Herodian but kept all the text in Greek unlike his edition of Lascaris's grammar (printed earlier in 1495) which provided the text in both Greek and Latin to facilitate learning and was cheaper to buy.


Aldus printed several editions of Lascaris's grammar (see lot 112) but this was his only edition of Gaza's grammar plausibly because he still had copies available for sale even in 1513 (see Botley p.20). The fine contemporary binding on this copy shows that it was prized by its first owner.


LITERATURE

ISTC ig00110000; Aldo Manuzio tipografo 5; Renouard 4/2; UCLA 5; Botley Learning Greek in Western Europe 1396-1529 Appendix 1:16

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern

Carmina. (Venice: the Academy of Aldus June 1504)


4to (189 x 140mm.) parallel (interleaved) text in Greek and Latin woodcut Aldine device on verso of colophon modern leather lacking two errata leaves


This work forms the third volume of Aldus's Poetae Christiani veteres issued between January 1501 and June 1504.

description:
Gregorius I


A volume of 5 tracts mostly printed by Michael Furter in Basel comprising:


Homiliae super Ezechielem. [Basel: Michael Furter] 1496 102 leaves A-Q8.4 R6 double column 47 lines plus headline gothic type 4- to 9-line initial spaces [ISTC ig00425000]


Dialogorum libri quattuor. Basel: Michael Furter 1496 58 leaves a8 b-g8.4 h8 i6 double column 47 lines plus headline gothic type 3- to 6-line initial spaces [ISTC ig00407000]


Pastorale sive Regula pastoralis. Basel: [Michael Furter] 15 February 1496 42 leaves A-F8.4 G6 double column 47 lines plus headline gothic type 3- to 7-line initial spaces [ISTC ig00441000]


Commentum super Cantica canticorum. Basel: [Michael Furter] 13 March 1496 22 leaves a8 b-c4 d6 double column 47 lines plus headline gothic type 3- to 7-line initial spaces [ISTC ig00395000]


Homiliae super Evangeliis. Venice: Peregrinus de Pasqualibus Bononiensis 14 March 1493 110 leaves [2] aa-nn8 oo4 [ISTC ig00421000]


5 works in one volume 4to (217 x 155mm.) contemporary German blind-stamped pigskin over wooden boards by Johannes Rucker (Kyriss 62; active in southern Germany c. 1477-1513) 2 clasps paper lettering-piece on spine modern folding box some worming throughout (affecting text at end) lacking both catches binding slightly wormed and rubbed


The four tracts printed by Furter are often found bound together and were presumably offered for sale originally as a group as well as separately.


PROVENANCE

Tachov (western Bohemia) convent of Reformed Franciscans of Mary Magdalene and Elizabeth inscriptions on first title-page and A2

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Heliodorus Historiae aethiopicae libri decem Basel 1534 contemporary vellum
description:
Property from the Loverdos Collection


Heliodorus


Aithiopikes istorias biblia deka. Historiae aethiopicae libri decem nunquam antea in lucem editi. Basel: Johannes Hervagius February 1534


4to (204 x 149mm.) text in Greek woodcut device on title-page and final verso (otherwise blank) woodcut initials near-contemporary limp vellum stubs of two pairs of ties marginal losses to title-page and to fourth leaf of first few quires (indicating damage before the sheets were bound) occasional light staining cover becoming loose


EDITIO PRINCEPS of this fourth-century Greek novel Ethiopian Adventures of Charicleia and Theagenes. The editor Vincent Obsopeus states in the preface that the manuscript was saved from the destruction of the library of Matthias Corvinus by a soldier in the army of Casimir of Brandenburg. The popularity of the tale resulted in almost a hundred editions in various languages appearing over the next hundred years; see lot 83 for a Spanish translation.


LITERATURE

VD16 H 1673


PROVENANCE

Bibliotheque de M. Delasize bookplate sale Rouen 1846

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Heliodorus Historia de los dos leales amantes Barcelona 1614 red morocco for Don Pedro of Aragon
description:
Heliodorus


Historia de los dos leales amantes Theagenes y Chariclea [translated by Fernando de Mena]. Barcelona: Jeronimo Margarit 1614 (1615)


8vo (139 x 95mm.) woodcut initials and tailpieces woodcut printer's device on K2 and final verso mid seventeenth-century Italian red morocco gilt with the arms and name of Don Pedro de Aragon later gilt edges D6 torn at foot of gutter with slight loss small tear at foot of K2 and O3 occasional light foxing obscured inscriptions on title-page and at end binding refurbished with new endpapers and new gilt edges repairs to ends of spine


RARE. Second edition of the translation of Fernando de Mena following the 1587 Alcala printing. Also known as the Aethiopica from its setting this novel was written in the fourth century and translated into numerous languages in the sixteenth century proving to be greatly influential on contemporary writers and shaping the development of the novel.


Don Pedro de Aragon (1611-1690) was the owner of a substantial library much of which was obtained during his years in Italy (1662-1672) and it was bequeathed to the monastery of Poblet (though confiscated from there in the 1820s and taken to Tarragona). The binding was plausibly made in Rome or Naples while he was viceroy.


LITERATURE

IB 45132; cf. Palau 112868 (1587 edition mentioning this edition)


PROVENANCE

Don Pedro de Aragon arms on binding; Tarragona faded monastic library stamp on title-page

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Henry VIII | Document signed granting lands to Humfrey Tyrell 15 May 1541
description:
King Henry VIII


Document signed ("Henry R") at the head


indenture in English between the King (''the same most Crysten prynce or naturall lyege lorde'') and Humphrey Torrell granting the latter lands inherited from his father Henry Torrell with the stipulation that all the property be fully inspected and assessed by the King's valuers one vellum membrane (340 x 485mm.) scalloped upper margin lacking seal 15 May 1541 framed and glazed (frame sixe 545 x 645mm.) patches of soiling and staining two small holes with loss of a few letters


The lands of Humphrey Torrell were chiefly in Essex. The family home was Torrell's Hall in Willingale Doe. Humphrey Torrell died in 1544 leaving an infant daughter Anne who went on to marry Henry son of Sir Thomas Joscelyn.


PROVENANCE

Sotheby's London 24 February 2000 lot 271

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Herodianus Historia de imperio post Marcum Bologna 1493 later limp vellum
description:
Herodianus


Historia de imperio post Marcum [translated by Angelus Politianus]. Bologna: Franciscus (Plato) de Benedictis 31 August 1493


Chancery folio (288 x 199mm.) 68 leaves aa-hh8 ii4 34-36 lines roman type 3- to 6-line initial spaces heading on aa3 printed in red printed marginalia woodcut printer's device beneath colophon modern limp vellum reusing a leaf from a liturgical manuscript two ties


Herodian's history of the Roman Empire after Marcus Aurelius (from 180 to 238AD) was written shortly after the events it describes; Herodian probably died in around 240. The first edition printed in Rome in 1493 was not approved of by Poliziano in particular because of the long list of errata at the end and the omission of the printed marginalia. This edition includes a prefatory letter from Poliziano to the Bolognese Andrea Magnanimo indicating that Alessandro Sarti should help with the correction of the text which is not present in the Rome edition.


LITERATURE

ISTC ih00086000


PROVENANCE

Hesiod


Erga kai emerai. Theogonia. Aspis Erakleous... Opera et dies; Theogonia. Scutum Herculis. (Venice: Giovanni Francesco Trincavalli for Bartolomeo Zanetti June 1537)


4to (208 x 153mm.) woodcut printer's device on title-page an additional leaf containing an early Greek manuscript poem bound after title-page woodcut initials and headpieces (some printed in red) woodcut illustrations on x8v 5 leaves of early manuscript in Greek bound at end later calf gilt and gauffered edges from previous binding small area of damage to head of title-page (affecting first word of title) and first few leaves light staining towards end

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Hesychius Dictionarium Venice Aldus 1514 modern leather Egnazio-San Giorgio Maggiore copy
description:
Hesychius


Lexikon. Dictionarium. (Venice: in the house of Aldus and Andrea Torresano August 1514)


folio (298 x 200mm.) text in Greek woodcut Aldine device on title-page and final verso (otherwise blank) modern tan leather by A. & A. Ganiarne of Athens old inventory number 129 on front flyleaf (retained from earlier binding) paper repairs to title-page a few leaves browned occasional light foxing a few wormholes small adhesive label to spine


EDITIO PRINCEPS edited by Marcus Musurus from an early fifteenth-century manuscript owned by the Mantuan mathematician Gian Giacomo Bardellone the dedicatee of this edition. The lexicon of Hesychius is considered of particular importance; like many other lexicographers he records passages from numerous works which are now lost and he based his work on earlier dictionaries which have also not survived. In particular he recorded unusual vocabulary and dialects which are not known from any other source.


BEQUEATHED TO SAN GIORGIO MAGGIORE IN VENICE BY GIOVANNI BATTISTA EGNAZIO (1478-1553) a pupil of Marcus Musurus who had worked for Aldus as an editor and was part of the Aldine Academy. He taught Aldus's sons and continued his work for the press long after Aldus's death in 1515. His will specified that his Greek and Latin Aldine printings should go to the library of San Giorgio Maggiore though much of his library was sold and came into the possession of Ulrich Fugger. 


LITERATURE

Aldo Manuzio tipografo 124; Edit16 23059; Renouard 1514/3; UCLA 122; Botley Learning Greek in Western Europe 1396-1529 Appendix 2:15


PROVENANCE

"Iste liber legatus est bibliothecae monrii Sti Giorgii maioris Venetiarum a can[onic]o Jo. Baptista Egnatio. 1553" i.e. Giovanni Battista Egnazio bequeathed to; Benedictine monastery of San Giorgio Maggiore Venice; note in English on flyleaf about this copy dated 3.13.6

A compilation of 135 biographies of Christian writers concluding with Jerome himself thereby providing us with biographical information about him and his writings.


This was the first of a group of similar tracts issued by Zainer at around this time for which he also issued a printed list of contents.

Homer


A set of Homer in Greek printed in Strassburg in 1534 in uniform eighteenth-century French green morocco bindings comprising:


Ilias [edited by Volfius Cephalaeus]. (Strassburg: Wolfgang Kopfel and Peter Braubach) 1534 title within woodcut border woodcut device on final verso quire N with some washed annotations (with slight staining)

together 2 volumes 8vo (159 x 96mm.) eighteenth-century green morocco gilt (almost certainly by Derome) flat spines gilt gilt edges

The tools on the binding match those used by Nicolas-Denis Derome le jeune; a copy of this edition in green morocco by Derome was in an Evans sale 12 May 1835 lot 447 sold for PS1-9s to J. Bohn.

item_title: Homer Opera Basel 1551 contemporary German calf
description:
Homer


Omnia quae quidem extant opera graece adiecta versione Latina ad verbum (Odyssea). Basel: Nikolaus Brylinger and Bartholomaeus Stahelin 1551


2 parts in one volume folio (317 x 205mm.) woodcut printer's device on title-pages parallel text in Latin and Greek verse woodcut initials a few manuscript annotations (including manicules) with final blank leaf contemporary blind-tooled calf over wooden boards (one border attributed by EBDB to the binder A.T. of Frankfurt an der Oder w002200 active 1561-1566 and the other border dated 1548/9 and assigned to workshop w007312 unlocalised) two clasps metal corner edges occasional light staining a few small wormholes binding rebacked with new endpapers lacking both straps one metal corner defective


This bilingual edition of Homer was the work of Heinrich Pantaleon (1522-1595) scholar translator and librarian whose name appears in the subsequent 1553 Brylinger edition. As well as the epics of Homer the volume contains Plutarch's life of Homer also in parallel Latin and Greek.

THE FIRST COMPLETE SPANISH TRANSLATION OF THE ODYSSEY composed by Gonzalo Perez Secretary in the service of Charles V and Philip II. The first thirteen books were printed in 1550 in Salamanca and this is the first edition of his completed text. This respected translation was the prime vehicle for knowledge of Homer during Spain's Golden Age.

Dealy flat spine gilt with red morocco lettering-pieces brown morocco gilt doublures plain edges matching slipcase marginal paper repairs to first few leaves repaired wormholes in upper margin towards end of volume


A fine specimen of Greek printing; the font was designed by Alexander Wilson and the text was corrected by James Moor professor of Greek at Glasgow. The Foulis press had previously issued the Iliad in 1756.

item_title: Homerici centones... Virgiliani centones [Geneva] Henri Estienne 1578 contemporary French olive morocco gilt
description:
Property from the Loverdos Collection


Homerici centones


Homerici centones a veteribus vocati Omerokentra... Virgiliani centones... Nonni paraphrasis Evangelii Ioannis Graece & Latine. [Geneva]: Henri Estienne 1578


12mo (120 x 76mm.) woodcut Estienne device on title-page contemporary French olive morocco covers gilt to a fanfare pattern with small flower tools flat spine similarly gilt gilt edges stubs from two pairs of ties


A Byzantine compilation of Greek religious poetry written in Homeric meter attributed to Empress Eudoxia or Patricius Pelagius with the fourth-century Latin verses of Falconia Proba retelling parts of the Bible. The final 80-page section (not in the collation provided by GLN) contains "Homerici versus proverbiales". These texts previously appeared together in a volume printed by Aldus Manutius in 1501-1502 as part of his series of Christian poets.

Horae. Greek


Horae in laudem beatissimae Virginis Mariae. Antwerp: Marten de Keyser (November) 1528


16mo (95 x 56mm.) text in Greek printed in red and black woodcut printer's device on final verso without final blank early annotations at beginning and end late eighteenth-century half calf flat spine gilt a few small marginal tears occasional light staining small adhesive label to upper cover


A charming and rare miniature Greek book of hours which is also recorded with the imprint of Johann Setzer in Hagenau and of Gilles Gourmont in Paris. It is a close copy of the miniature format Horae printed by Aldus in 1497 and again in 1505 retaining Aldus's original preface in which he recommended the use of this devotional text to aid the learning of Greek.

description:
Horapollo


Ierogluphika... De sacris notis & sculpturis libri duo [edited and translated by Jean Mercier]. Paris: (Guillaume Morel for) Jacques Kerver 1551


8vo (161 x 98mm.) woodcut initials and illustrations (that on F8r printed upside down that on G7v with a replacement pasted in) woodcut printer's device on final verso (otherwise blank) crushed burgundy morocco by Antolin Palomino Olalla (made in 1982) brown morocco doublures with gilt-tooled coloured morocco onlays marbled edges slipcase


A fine copy of this emblem book first printed by Aldus in 1505. The unknown author claimed to be able to decipher hieroglyphics and the second part of the work interprets the symbolism of various animals depicted in the series of fine woodcuts which previously appeared in Kerver's 1543 edition.

First printed by Aldus Manutius in 1505 this edition of Horapollo's hieroglyphics was produced by Juan Lorenzo Palmireno humanist scholar and professor of Greek in Valencia. Sanahuja was active as a bookseller from 1544 onwards and also printed books for a short period between 1554-1556. His printer's device was based on Durer's rhinoceros.

Chancery folio (285 x 196mm.) 96 leaves [a-h10 i-k8] double column 36 lines gothic type 3- and 4-line initials in red first 6-line initial in blue with red penwork decoration red initial strokes a line of text added in manuscript to foot of [b]2 nineteenth-century half vellum nineteenth-century English manuscript note about the book on flyleaf slight water-damage to head with some leaves in quire e repaired at head last 10 leaves slightly damaged and repaired at edges last leaf laid down


Jacobus de Theramo's Consolation of sinners was a popular text appearing in many editions in different languages (some illustrated) from its first printing in German in 1464; the Latin text was first printed in Augsburg in 1472. It comprises a law suit between the Devil and Jesus about the redemption of Man in which Jesus wins but the Devil is allowed to take the damned at the Last Judgement.

description:
Property from the Loverdos Collection


Joannes Chrysostomus and Xenophon


A volume of Greek works printed in Louvain in 1529 comprising:


JOANNES CHRYSOSTOMUS. Dialogi sex. (Louvain: Rutger Rescius and Johann Sturmius 1529) with final blank


JOANNES CHRYSOSTOMUS. Peri proseukhes logoi b. Louvain: Rutger Rescius and Johann Sturmius November 1529


XENOPHON. Apomnemoneumaton biblia tessara... Commentariorum libri quatuor. (Louvain: Rutger Rescius and Johann Sturmius September 1529) with final blank leaf slight worming


3 works in one volume 4to (209 x 152mm.) text in Greek start of volume ruled in red heavily annotated by a contemporary hand contemporary calf tooled in gilt and blind two pairs of (later) leather ties occasional light staining rebacked retaining most of original spine


Rutger Rescius (c. 1497-1545) was a professor of Greek at the Collegium Trilingue in Louvain as well as a printer and Johann Sturm (1507-1589) was also a teacher; they took over the press of Thierry Martens (see lot 145). The Xenophon was the first book to be printed by them and is dedicated to Gilles Busleiden. These texts were printed for the use of their students which is evidenced by the annotations in this copy.


LITERATURE

USTC 443925 (listing one copy in The Hague) & 437428 & 403403


PROVENANCE

Monastery of St Adrianus inscription on title-page

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Don Juan of Austria signed decree Santa Fe de Mondujar 23 April 157[0]
description:
Don Juan of Austria


Signed decree ("Don Ju[an]") written by his secretary Juan de Soto and countersigned by Soto


written during the rebellion of the Alpujarras (the Morisco Revolt) in Granada (1568-1571) ordering his troops not to take as slaves any of the new Christians of this kingdom ("Christianos nuevos que en este Reyno se an revelado") on pain of death nor to mistreat them but to gather them with mercy


"no haciendoles ninguna molestia ni maltratamiento antes recogiendolos con toda piedad benignidad y blandura"

folio (316 x 215mm.) 1 page papered seal no watermark Santa Fe de Mondujar 23 April 157[0] in a modern buckram folder shaved at right hand side of leaf with loss of final digit of the date


Following the Spanish conquest of Granada from the Moors in the late fifteenth century official policy was to Christianise the remaining local Muslim population though Charles V had suspended this practice on receipt of a substantial payment from the Moors. In 1567 a council in Madrid prohibited Moorish customs and language in order to facilitate the Christianisation of the Moriscos. These repressive measures were met with resistance and an armed uprising in 1568.


During the brutal military campaign there were (unsurprisingly) incidents of looting and enslavement by the Spanish soldiers which hampered the success of the operation. The Moorish troops supported by Algeria targeted churches and Old Christians and also sold Christian captives into slavery.


Don Juan de Austria half-brother to Philip II was appointed to the command of the Spanish troops in early 1570 and this decree attempted to regulate the behaviour of his troops by broadcasting the punishments for disobedience. He managed to suppress the rebellion by the end of that year following which many of the Moors were deported to other regions of Spain. The campaign also provided literary inspiration for Cervantes who shortly afterwards served under Don Juan at the Battle of Lepanto.

A fine copy of Pollux's second-century lexicographical work organised by topic rather than alphabetically. It was based on the Aldine edition of 1502 by Antonio Francino who dedicated it to Thomas Linacre. This is the only text by Pollux to survive.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Lascaris De octo partibus orationis Venice Aldus 1512 later vellum
description:
Constantinus Lascaris


De octo partibus orationis [and other works]. (Venice: Aldus October 1512)


4to (214 x 149mm.) parallel text in Greek and Latin last section with Hebrew type woodcut Aldine device on title-page and &4v with blank leaf f10 and without blank r4 modern vellum with two straps and toggles first few leaves slightly staineda few leaves in quire zp with marginal paper repairs occasional light staining


Lascaris's grammar first circulated in manuscript and was first printed in Milan in 1476; its significance to the spread of Greek learning in Italy was cemented by Aldus's printing of it in 1495 as the first book to issue from his press. Aldus added a Latin translation based on the one by Johannes Crastonus. For his later editions Aldus appended other similar grammatical works as well as his own short introduction to Hebrew grammar; this is the third Aldine edition following that of [1502-3].


For a later edition see lot 113.


LITERATURE

Aldo Manuzio tipografo 107; Edit16 36173; Renouard 58/1; UCLA 105; Botley Learning Greek in Western Europe 1396-1529 Appendix I:46

A crisp copy with good margins and some deckle edges. This is a reprint of the Aldine editions of [c. 1503] and 1512 (see lot 112 for the latter).


The final section containing the introduction to Hebrew is a letter by letter reprint of the 1512 Aldine text and was printed separately from the rest of the volume as can be seen by the different typeface and paper stock. It does not appear in all copies and is not included in the register.

item_title: [Liturgy] Neon anthologion Rome 1598 tan morocco gilt with the arms of Marescot
description:
Liturgy. Greek rite. Anthologion


Neon anthologion plerestaton te kai akribestaton (Litera... Clementis... VIII super indulto ut clerici vel monachi Graeci... hoc Breviario uti possint). Rome: Stamperia Apostolica Vaticana 1598


2 parts in one volume 8vo (170 x 110mm.) ruled in red printed in red and black woodcut papal arms on title-page woodcut initials head- and tailpieces text in Greek (except for Latin dedication to Clement VIII by Antonio Arcudi) with blank leaf Aa8 seventeenth-century tan morocco gilt with arms of Marescot [Olivier 620] gilt edges upper joint cracked hinges strengthened ends of spine slightly chipped


RARE. A Greek breviary produced by Antonio Arcudi archpriest from Soleto in Puglia for the use of Greeks in Italy observing the Byzantine rite. It was composed in the manner of the Latin breviary together with the Psalter and Hours. The printing was supervised by Aldo Manuzio the younger though he died in 1597 before it was completed.


Bound at the end is the papal bull issued by Clement VIII on the use of this liturgy by the Greek clergy and monks granting a privilege restricting its printing for 10 years. The six-page letter is signed by M. Vestrius Barbianus and dated Ferrara 30 July 1598. We have not been able to find a copy of this printed letter recorded elsewhere.


LITERATURE

Edit16 12020; Legrand II.225


PROVENANCE

Guillaume Marescot (1567-1643 privy counsellor and owner of a substantial library of 6000 volumes); Bernard Quaritch Catalogue: Examples of the Art of Book-Binding and volumes bearing distinguished marks of ownership 1897 no.516 priced PS8-8s

Sabellico (1436-1506) was a devotee of Livy; he composed his own Ab urbe condita on the history of Venice and composed a speech in praise of Livy. His commentary on Livy was first printed in 1491.

Lucianus Samosatensis


Luciani opera. Icones Philostrati. Eiusdem Heroica. Eiusdem vitae Sophistarum. Icones Iunioris Philostrati. Descriptiones Callistrati. (Venice): Aldus (in the house of Aldus and Andrea Torresano October 1522) (colophon on ee2: Venice: Aldus February 1503)


folio (306 x 202mm.) woodcut Aldine device on title-page and final verso dd4-5 supplied from another copy (see footnote) and slightly shorter a few early annotations in Greek modern leather with gilt Aldine device on covers with the remains of an old spine retained lacking aa3-6


A mixed edition of the Aldine Lucian; the text was reissued in 1522 with a preface by Giovanni Francesco Torresano which is not here present (the 1503 edition has no preface) and a new colophon on the final leaf. The printed pagination is unusually located at the centre of the upper margin rather than at the outer corner.


The missing leaves contained "De morte Peregrini" which was on the Index of Prohibited Books (see UCLA 213) and removed by an early reader; the same was the case for the "Philopatria" on dd4-5 though these two leaves were subsequently supplied from another copy.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Manuscript Recipe Book belonging to Jane Harrison 18th century
description:
Recipe Book


Manuscript collection of culinary recipes


including sauces and condiments ("Wallnut Ketchup") desserts ("Lemon pudding") drinks ("Cowslip wine") and a few household and medicinal receipts ("Blacking for shoes" "Cough or Consumption") with an index in several hands with written from the reverse two pages of school notes on mathematics c.71 pages 8vo (205 x 165mm) marbled boards ink ownership inscriptions on endleaves ("Jane Harrison | Whitburn | Febry. 17th 1771") and on upper cover ("Miss Jane Harrison" "Mrs Wardell" "Mrs Platt") and to covers heavily worn staining and wear to outer leaves


[with loosely inserted:] 28 leaves of additional contemporaneous recipes in a number of different hands many signed ("Lemon Cheese Cakes [...] M Robinson's best love") many sent to Miss Wardell of Whitburn


"To Make Cowslip Wine


To 20 Quarts of Water put in 14 pounds of Sugar a few whites of Eggs to Clear it let it Boil half an houe skiming [sic] it well and when Cold put in 4 pounds of Cowslips with a gill of zest & as much hop as you Can hold in your hand lett it Stand 3 Days stirring it and Squeezing the cowslips several times a Day with your hand put into your Cask a pint of Brandy then Taw [i.e. beat] it all; together with the Juice of 6 Lemons and 3 rinds Close it tight & Lett it Stand 2 months then Bottle it putting in each Bottle a bit of Shugar."


A FINE COLLECTION OF SOPHISTICATED 18TH-CENTURY RECIPES. Like many such manuscripts this collection was collaborative and contains contributions from a number of sources including numerous loose notes provided by friends and neighbours. It was compiled over many years and may well have been passed down the family from mother to daughter. 


PROVENANCE

This recipe book belonged to a gentry family in 18th century County Durham. Jane Harrison was the daughter of Christopher Harrison of Whitburn West-House between the villages of Whitburn and Cleadon. In 1768 she married John Wardell and the couple inherited Whitburn West-House.

One of numerous sixteenth-century editions of Aldus's Latin grammar (first printed in 1493 by Andrea Torresano) followed by his Greek grammar and with his short introduction to Hebrew at the end. The section on the eight parts of speech purporting to be by Erasmus (with his name crossed through in this copy) is actually his revision of a work by William Lily.

item_title: Montfaucon L'antiquite expliquee Paris 1722 (1724) 15 volumes contemporary calf
description:
Bernard de Montfaucon


L'antiquite expliquee et representee en figures... Seconde edition revue et corrigee (Supplement). Paris: Delaune Nyon Foucault Ganeau Closier & Giffart 1722 (1724)


10 volumes bound in 15 (comprising 5 volumes of the main work each bound in two volumes plus 5 voumes of supplement) folio (406 x 265mm.) engraved frontispiece in volume 1 titles printed in red and black with engraved vignettes engraved portrait at start of volume 1 engraved and woodcut headpieces and initials 973 (of 974) engraved plates; supplement: 417 engraved plates (some double-page or folding) nineteenth-century calf spines gilt-tooled in period style morocco lettering-pieces (some missing) lacking plate 144 from volume 4 part 2 upper cover of volume 1 detached bindings somewhat rubbed and scraped joints weak (some cracked) one spine torn at foot


An encyclopaedic survey of the monuments and remains of the ancient world from Britain to Egypt displaying statuary temples reliefs medallions altars tombstones everyday objects such as keys and shoes as well as scenes of hunting and dancing and military and naval subjects. The first edition of 1719 proved to be a seminal work of antiquarianism though Montfaucon issued this second revised edition almost immediately which was itself followed by a supplement in 1724. Following an English translation published in 1721-1722 the work proved to be hugely influential on English antiquarians and architects such as Robert Adam.


LITERATURE

cf. BAL RIBA 2178 (English edition)


PROVENANCE

Countess of Craven from the Coombe Abbey library (according to a pencil note on the flyleaf)

Musaei opusculum de Herone & Leandro. Orphei Argonautica. Eiusdem hymni. Orpheus de lapidibus. (Venice): Aldus (in the house of Aldus and Andrea Torresano November 1517)

THE BUNAU-SAXONY COPY.

description:

Poiemation ta kath'Ero kai Leandron... Opusculum de Herone et Leandro [and other works]. (Florence: heirs of Filippo Giunta 1519)


8vo (159 x 90mm.) text in Greek (Hero and Leander in parallel Greek and Latin) woodcut illustrations woodcut printer's device on final verso later calf lacking lower cover


There is a manuscript note on the title-page about the editions of this work but only mentioning the 1517 Aldine and the present edition (both of which were owned by Mitford; see provenance). The text first appeared in Florence from the press of Lorenzo de Alopa in around 1494 was one of the first books printed by Aldus (1495 & 1497 the Greek and Latin parts printed separately) then reprinted by his successors in 1517 this time including the texts of Orpheus (Argonautica Hymni De lapidibus) and Homer (Batrachomyomachia). This Giunta edition prepared by Antonio Francini from the 1517 Aldine also contains these additional texts.


For the 1514 Alcala edition of Musaeus see lot 50.

This is the only book with the imprint of Giovanni Agostino Burgo (or Juan Agustin del Burgo); he mostly worked as a book dealer on behalf of the Giunta and sourced numerous texts in Greek for Nunez de Guzman.

These two didactic poems on fishing and hunting are attributed to different Oppians. The Greek text was first printed by the Giunta in 1515 (this is the first Aldine edition) and the verse translation of the poem on fishes by Lippi first appeared in 1478 in Lippi's home town of Colle Val d'Elsa. It is the first Greek text to be printed by Gian Francesco Torresano (Cataldi Palau p.210).

Chancery folio (308 x 210mm.) 121 leaves (of 133) [*6+1 a-m10 n6] 6-line initial in blue with red penwork decoration 2- to 6-line initial spaces a few leaves rubricated 9 leaves of contemporary manuscript at start containing the register (by a south German or Austrian scribe) early annotations throughout a leaf of manuscript notes on final blank contemporary Austrian(?) pigskin over wooden boards (a remboitage?) decorated to a leafy pattern with a kopfstempel (plausibly Kyriss 154 active 1473-1497) 2 later clasps in period style lacking first quire (supplied in contemporary manuscript) and c4-6 (supplied in old photocopy) and n5-6 (blanks) rebacked reusing an old vellum spine covering later board liners lacking original catchplates


FIRST EDITION of Orosius's history of the world to the year 417 AD based on Justin Eusebius and Jerome. Orosius a Christian apologist and student of St Augustine sought to demonstrate that the troubles of his time were not caused by the advent of Christianity. The influence of the Historiae can be seen in the fact that Dante cited Orosius as one of four classical prose authors the others being Livy Pliny and Frontinus whose style should be imitated by the aspiring poet.

Academiae Oxoniensis pietas. Erga serenissimum et potentissimum Iacobum Angliae Scotiae Franciae & Hiberniae regem fidei defensorem beatissimae Elizabethae nuper reginae legitimae & auspicatissime succedentem. Oxoniae: excudebat Iosephus Barnesius almae academiae topographus 1603

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Pausanias. Venice. Aldus 1516 contemporary calf
description:
Property from the Loverdos collection


Pausanias


[Periegesis]. (Venice: in the house of Aldus and Andrea Torresano July 1516)


Super-Chancery folio (309 x 207mm.) text in Greek woodcut Aldine device on title-page and final verso annotations in Greek throughout contemporary (probably Parisian) calf with small gilt arabesque centrepiece title-page stained and almost detached stain at lower corner of first ten leaves slight staining towards end binding rather rubbed rebacked and recornered in old calf small label on upper cover; otherwise a tall crisp and unwashed copy


EDITIO PRINCEPS edited by Marcus Musurus. Pausanias wrote his narrative based on his travels around mainland Greece during the reign of Marcus Aurelius though the first mention of his work by another author is in the sixth century when Stephanus Byzantinus (who also provided the author's name and the standard title Description of Greece) mentions it in his quest for the names of Greek cities.


An almost identical outline arabesque binding tool was used by Claude de Picques (Book Bindings from the Library of Jean Grolier plate D tool 24) and the Cupid's Bow Binder (plate G tool 8).
