Olumpia. Puthia. Nemea. Isthmia. Rome: Zacharias Kallierges [for Cornelio Benigno] (13 August 1515)


4to (225 x 160mm.) text in Greek woodcut devices on title-page and on final verso some printing in red 2-line initials supplied in manuscript with both blank leaves quire A misprinted eighteenth-century Italian speckled calf spine gilt in compartments occasional light foxing


THE FIRST GREEK BOOK TO BE PRINTED IN ROME. The editio princeps of Pindar's victory odes had appeared two years earlier in Venice printed by Aldus Manutius though without the scholia included here. Aldus and Kallierges were both renowned for the elegance of their Greek typefaces.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Pinder | Speculum passionis Nuremberg 1507 contemporary pigskin
description:
Ulrich Pinder


Speculum passionis domini nostri Ihesu Christi. (Nuremberg: [printer for the Sodalitas Celtica ?Friedrich Peypus] 20 August 1507)


FIRST EDITION folio (310 x 215mm.) 39 full-page woodcuts (including 5 repeats) of which 36 are by Hans Schaufelein (those at M2v and N2v signed with his monogram and crossed-shovel device) and 3 by Hans Baldung Grien or Wolf Traut numerous smaller woodcuts some within ornamental two-part borders a few initials supplied in red a few early manuscript annotations contemporary pigskin over wooden boards tooled in blind metal clasps and catches marginal dampstaining at heard some wear to binding


First edition of the first book to contain woodcuts signed by Schaufelein considered one of the most beautiful works of the German renaissance. With the exception of the three woodcuts attributed to Wolf Traut and Hans Baldung Grien the illustrations were the work of Hans Schaufelein a native of Nuremberg and student and journeyman of Albrech Durer. The full-page woodcuts were engraved specially for this book and owe much to Durer's influence. The small woodcuts come from Pinder's Garten des Rozenkranzes Mariae published in Nuremberg in 1505. This edition was probably printed by Friedrich Peypus who printed the second edition in 1519 for Georg Glockendon. Peypus published other books including the work of the Benedictine canoness Hrosvita of Gandersheim for the Sodalitas Celtica a group of friends formed around the celebrated humanist Conrad Celtes.


LITERATURE

Fairfax Murray Early German Books 333; Holstein II 128; VD16 P2807

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: William Pitt the Younger | Series of 12 autograph letters signed to William Eden on international affairs 1786-90s
description:
William Pitt the Younger


Series of 12 autograph letters signed as Prime Minister to William Eden Lord Auckland


offering him the ambassadorship to Paris discussing a commercial treaty with France ("...I believe it will appear [...] 1st that the Balance of Trade is likely to be ultimately very much in our Favor and 2ndly that the encreased Revenue which We shall draw from the Encreased Importations will bear a much larger Proportion to the Value of the Articles than the Encrease of their Revenues will to the Value of our encreased Exports..." 21 April 1786) and with later letters giving news of war in Europe ("...I grieve at the Accounts from Naples (even allowing for French Exaggeration) and cannot think of Austria with Patience...") c.33 pages 4to and 8vo 1786-90s damp damage


[with:] typed transcriptions of all letters


William Eden (1745-1814) was a diplomat who served as Ambassador to France from 1785-87 amongst other postings. He was elevated to the peerage in 1789 and retired in 1793 to his country seat at Beckenham. This was close to Pitt's home at Holwood and the two men were close friends. There were even rumours of an engagement between Pitt and Eden's eldest daughter Eleanor but in 1797 the Prime Minister made clear that he had no intention of making a proposal. She went on to marry the Earl of Buckinghamshire (for letters to Eleanor from her younger sister Emily see lot 187).

Plato


Apanta ta tou Platonos... Omnia Platonis opera. Venice: (in the house of Aldus and Andrea Torresano September 1513)


bound in two volumes folio (307 x 192mm.) woodcut Aldine device on title-page and final verso text in Greek with blank leaves 2/4 and ii4 bound in crushed tan morocco gilt with inset coloured portraits of Aldus and Marcus Musurus gilt morocco doublures with blue morocco panel tooled to the design of a sixteenth-century arabesque binding with central stamp of a seated poet being crowned with a laurel wreath lettered "Jos. Lassi et amicorum" on inside lower covers spines gilt in compartments with red morocco lettering-pieces in a single slipcase with brown morocco gilt sides with Aldine device stamped in gilt


EDITIO PRINCEPS OF THE TEXT OF PLATO A TALL CRISP COPY. The text was prepared by Aldus and Marcus Musurus; the first addressed his preface to the new pope Leo X making a "supplicatio" for a new Christian Republic and for literature and the latter composed a verse Hymn to Plato (in Greek). Between the two prefaces is a list in Latin of the treatises include in this volume.


The book retains some endleaves from a previous binding with watermarks of an armorial inhabited by a snake similar to Heawood 688 and 690 both of which are dated to Paris in the 1680s.

Porphuriou eisagoge. Aristotelous kategorion biblion en... Porphyrii institutio. Aristotelis Praedicamentorum liber unus [and other works]. Louvain: Thierry Martens December 1523


4to (218 x 155mm.) text in Greek woodcut initials and diagram nineteenth-century marbled boards extensively annotated in Greek UNCUT preliminaries damaged at head with some loss of text quires g and nn misbound some staining and browning throughout


AN UNCUT COPY WITH EXTENSIVE ANNOTATIONS IN GREEK BY BRACCIO RICASOLI. A sixteenth-century manuscript copy of Catullus in the Biblioteca Medicea Laurenziana in Florence also contains annotations by Braccio as does a copy of Polybius in Greek from the Heber library (lot 5846).


Thierry Martens was the first printer of books in Greek in the Low Countries; his edition of the Nicomachean Ethics appeared in 1513. He was linked with the Collegium Trilingue of Louvain and was the main printer working with Erasmus.

Historiarum... libri VIII. Nunc primum Graece editi. Accessit liber de aedificiis Justiniani... opera Davidis Hoeschelii. Augsburg: David Franck 1607


folio (297 x 193mm.) engraved title-page depicting Justinian Narses and Bellisarius contemporary vellum with remains of green silk ties


A good copy of the editio princeps of Procopius's History of theWars and Buildings though without his better known Secret History which had not yet been discovered. Procopius is the main and sometimes only source for this period; the Buildings (dated to c. 560 AD) describes Justinian's rebuilding of towns and frontiers and the History of the Wars recounts the campaigns of Justin and Justinian up to c. 553/4.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Psalterium Venice Aldus [not after 1498] modern crushed tan morocco
description:
Psalterium graecum


Psalterion [edited by Justinus Decadyus]. Venice: Aldus [not after 1 October 1498]


Super-Chancery 4to (210 x 142mm.) 150 leaves a-th8 i6; k-n o-u8 the first line of text at the head of i1r supplied in early manuscript (see footnote) 20 lines Greek type printed in red and black throughout woodcut initials and borders (a3 and k1 with full borders) ruled in black modern tan leather lettered on upper cover red edges first two leaves inlaid with small repairs


A good copy of the Aldine Greek Psalter the third to be printed after the 1481 Milan and 1486 Venice editions WITH THE LINE OF MANUSCRIPT TEXT IN ALDUS'S OWN HAND on i1r. There was a mistake during the typesetting of this work which resulted in the omission of a line of text on i1r; once the mistake was noticed the type was reset to include the text but in the copies already printed the missing text was supplied by hand.


The text was edited by Justinus Decadyus of Corfu and was adressed by him to native speakers "to the Greeks of Greece" (unlike the Greek book of hours which as a Catholic liturgical text was only of use as an educational text for Catholics). The dating is provided by the inclusion of this edition in Aldus's list of books for sale of 1 October 1498 priced at 4 marcelli.


LITERATURE

Aldo Manuzio tipografo 29; ISTC ip01033000; Renouard 260/8; Sander 5944; UCLA 29; Geri della Rocca de Candal "Lost in transition: a significant correction in Aldus Manutius's Psalterion (1496/98)" The Library 7th series 23 (2022) 155-179 appendix copy no. 30

EDITIO PRINCEPS. Quintus of Smyrna's mythological epic usually referred to as the Posthomerica fills in the narrative from the end of the Iliad to the Odyssey and was probably composed in the third or fourth century AD. This volume additionally contains Tryphiodorus De Troiae excidio and Coluthus De raptu Helenae shorter poems also relating to the Trojan expedition.


The text was used by teachers of Greek in Italy after the discovery of a manuscript in Otranto by Cardinal Bessarion.

description:

Rithaymer studied Greek in Vienna with Jacobus Ceporinus and in 1529 became the first professor of Greek at the University of Vienna. The previous Greek scholar in Vienna Conrad Celtis had Greek texts ordered from Aldus in Venice as Viennese printers did not have access to Greek type until later. Rithaymer also produced an edition of Guarino's epitome of Chrysoloras in 1523.


This copy contains extensive manuscript notes showing that it was studied closely.

The translation of the Catiline Conspiracy and the Jugurthine War is attributed to Infante Don Gabriel though it is more likely to be by Perez Bayer. The extensive notes also include engraved plates showing specimens of Phoenician Hebrew and Maltese-Greek alphabets and of coins and weapons.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Jacopo Sannazaro Contemporary manuscript copy of an important letter about "De partu Virginis" 1521
description:
Sannazaro Jacopo


Fine sixteenth-century Italian manuscript of an important letter about Latin poetry to Antonio Seripando the author signing himself as "Syncerus tuus" [c. 1521]


comprising a lengthy discussion analysis and defence of Sannazaro's still unpublished Latin poem De partu Virginis closely written in a humanistic Renaissance hand up to forty lines per page with a few additions inserted between the lines deletions and corrections in which he expresses pleasure at the retirement and departure of Pietro Bembo ("...Chel s[ign]or [messer] Pietro Bembo sia partito et habbia havuto il Cambio sto allegro...") and responds to critiques of his poem by Antonio Tebaldeo and others the drafts of which he has sent out to friends for their opinion adducing over sixty short quotations in Latin from the poem in question matched with a similar number from Virgil Ovid and others in his defence together with a few in Greek concluding with a complaint that his health is affected by the weather and reporting that this has limited his studies of Judaea and Syria


"...Ringratio infinite volte [messer] Anto Thebaldo de le fraterne et amorevoli admonitioni et le excuse come son soverchie che come V.S. sa pero mandai queste mie ineptie in Roma per intender il parere deli amici et de tali amici mi son piaciute due cose l'una che vedo che va per la via che vo io benche piu cautamte et con piu felice corso. L'altra che non solo riprende ma pensa ali remedii che anchora non so ha fatto alcuno..."


6 pages folio (c.285 x 215mm.) closely written possibly a retained copy made directly from the autograph later pencil pagination remains of stitching [probably Naples c.1521] a few tiny perforations from oxidation of the ink staining to margins


RARE: this is the most important manuscript of Jacopo Sannazaro (1458-1530) to appear at auction for many years; he was one of the luminaries of the Italian Renaissance and the father of Arcadian poetry (see lot 200). This letter originally dating from around 15-20 April 1521 is by far his longest known; it is arguably one of the most informative documents on the writing of Latin poems in the early modern age. Sannazaro here agonizes over the final redaction of his poem De partu Virginis after sending drafts to Antonio Tebaldeo Jacopo Sadoleto Giles of Viterbo and Seripando himself. 


This copy could possibly have been made at the time and directly from the original so that Sannazaro had a record of his lengthy literary arguments; these cover seven pages in the autograph manuscript (now British Library Add Ms 12058 ff.1-4) and twice that in modern printed editions. Certain small additions which in the autograph are inserted between the lines are in this manuscript mostly integrated into the continuous text; however not all: one is omitted and there are two passages one nineteen words long that are also additions here. Possibly Sannazaro only added them to his autograph after this manuscript had already been copied from it. The humanistic hand is quite similar to Sannazaro's own and might well be that of a pupil or relative.


De partu Virginis is a Latin poem in hexameters overtly inspired by Virgil fusing classical epic poetry with a biblical episode in this case the birth of Christ. The poem was published in 1526 and again by Aldus in 1528 but as the author points out it circulated in manuscript well before that. Sannazaro states in this letter that the poem was the result of more than thirty-eight years of study and it is characteristic of the self-conscious intellectualism of his milieu that he feels compelled to explain and justify his art. Sannazaro's comment on Bembo's recent retirement dates the letter to 1521 and is the last and longest of his letters to Antonio Seripando (1476-1531) secretary to Cardinal Luigi d'Aragona. Sannazaro's academic name was "Actius Syncerus" and he frequently signs himself "Syncerus tuus" as here: see also the letters sold at Sotheby's on 25 June 1968 (Phillipps Collection) lot 884 now at the Morgan Library and Museum.


Sotheby's is happy to acknowledge the advice of Carlo Caruso and Brian Richardson in preparing this description.


LITERATURE

J. Sannazaro Opere volgari ed. by A. Mauro (Bari: Laterza 1961) letter LIII pp. 375-88 (dated 15 April 1521); also in De partu Virginis edited by C. Fantazzi and A. Perosa (Florence: Olschki 1988) Appendix IV pp. 95-108. Fantazzi 'Poetry and religion in Sannazaro's De partu Virginis' in Ut Granum Sinopsis. Essays in Honour of Jozef IJsewijn (1997) p.236.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Saverien Histoires des philosophes modernes Paris 1760-1766 5 volumes armorial red morocco
description:
Alexandre Saverien and Jean-Charles Francois


Histoire des philosophes modernes avec leur portrait grave dans le gout du crayon d'apres les desseins des plus grands peintres. Paris: Francois 1760-1766


5 volumes 4to (288 x 214mm.) engraved title-pages (some with printed labels pasted on to amend the section title) engraved frontispieces half-titles in volumes 1 3 and 5 engraved headpieces 42 engraved portraits (or allegories of portraits) and 15 engravings of cherubs pasted into volumes 3-5 at end of sections of text all printed in sanguine contemporary red morocco gilt with the arms of Charles Emmanuel III of Savoy with the name Caissottis stamped in gilt above spines gilt in compartments (armorials and spine decoration on volumes 4-5 slightly different) gilt edges a few plates shaved extremities very slightly rubbed


A fine set of the second edition of this collection of crayon portraits by the engraver Jean-Charles Francois (1717-1769) in a technique created by him to provide the grainy appearance of crayon drawings. The categories included are philosophers scientists and political theorists and among the characters represented are Newton Tycho Brahe and Kepler; Hobbes Locke and Bayle; Bacon Gassendi and Descartes; Montaigne Grotius and Pufendorf.


LITERATURE

Cohen-De Ricci 942


PROVENANCE

Charles Emanuel III of Savoy (1701-1773) arms on binding; Caissottis name stamped on binding presumably Conte Carlo Francesco Giacinto Caissotti di Chiusano (1754-1831) the renowned book collector; Bernard Quaritch pencil note of collation at end of volume 1 dated 1982

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Schedel Das Buch der Croniken Nuremberg 1493 contemporary Nuremberg binding with bosses and clasps
description:
Property from the Loverdos Collection


Hartmann Schedel


Liber chronicarum [German] Das Buch der Croniken und Geschichten [translated by Georg Alt]. Nuremberg: Anton Koberger for Sebald Schreyer and Sebastian Kammermeister 23 December 1493

Imperial folio (465 x 315mm.) 294 leaves (of 297) [*10 a6 b-d4 e-h6 i2 k4 l-n6 o2 p q6 r-y4 z6 aa-cc6 dd2 ee6 ff4 gg-ii6 kk2 ll4 mm-zz A-C6 D E4 F-H6 I6+1] partly double column gothic letter xylographic title-page 2-line woodcut initials numerous woodcut illustrations throughout (some full-page or double-page) by Wolgemuth and Pleydenwurff including portraits and town views double-page map of the world on [b]2v-3r double-page woodcut map of Europe at end initial on fol.1 in blue on a gold ground within a red and green frame and leafy marginal extensions (slightly rubbed) CONTEMPORARY NUREMBERG BINDING of blind-stamped calf over wooden boards (Kyriss 112 Adler) title stamped at head of upper cover metal cornerpieces and centrepiece on lower cover two clasps with catchplates lettered MARIA lacking text leaves CCXLVIII (containing small woodcut portraits) CCLXXI-CCLXXII (containing woodcuts of Wallachia Thrace and "von dem Turcken") occasional staining or marginal tearing throughout title-page slightly stained and repaired wormholes in first and last few leaves (including the map of Europe) fol.IX torn and repaired with thread slight loss of text on fos CLIX-CLX fol. CCXLII torn and repaired with slight loss rebacked with blind tooling in period style binding wormed and rubbed lacking three cornerpieces


A TALL AND UNSOPHISTICATED COPY IN A CONTEMPORARY NUREMBERG BINDING. The binding workshop (Kyriss 112 Adler) was active in Nuremberg from around 1477 to 1514 and bound other copies of the Nuremberg Chronicle. This German version of the text is less common than the original Latin which was printed slightly earlier in July 1493.


LITERATURE

ISTC is00309000


PROVENANCE

Presentation inscription from Hans von Elmsb[--] to Jakob Hannibal graf von Hohenems dated 6 February 1574 on verso of title-page; "Bibl. Embs" i.e. Bibliotheca Emsiana (in Hohenems Austria) inscription on title-page

description:
Lucius Annaeus Seneca


Opera philosophica. Epistolae [edited by Blasius Romerus]. Treviso: Bernardus de Colonia 1478


Median folio (325 x 221mm.) 213 leaves (of 214 without final blank) a10 b-h8 i10 k-l8 m10 n-z8 [et]8 aa-bb8 53 lines gothic type start of text with 10-line illuminated initial with leafy marginal extensions (southern German) 3- to 11-line initials in red initial blank leaf with a page of manuscript from Quintilian on Seneca early annotations in different hands (some in red ink) contemporary stamped south German calf over wooden boards (plausibly an Augsburg binding) two clasps a leaf from Epistolae et Evangelia (Plenarium) [German] (Augsburg: Johann Bamler 20 September 1474) used as front boardliner (though without printed foliation) modern folding box occasional light staining rebacked binding rubbed lacking both straps


Second edition of the philosophical works of Seneca based on the 1475 Naples printing by Moravus. This is one of only two books with the name of Bernardus de Colonia who may have worked previously for Matthias Moravus in Naples (Bernardus died in September 1478 and in his will he mentions his business connections with the Venetian printers Johannes de Colonia and Johannes Manthen). The editor Blasius Romerus was a Cistercian monk from Poblet (Catalonia) who also wrote on music theory and was closely associated with Moravus.


LITERATURE

inscription on flyleaf dated 1492 (?) description:
Juan Gines de Sepulveda


Opera cum edita tam inedita. Madrid: Typographia regia de la Gazeta 1780


4 volumes 4to (257 x 188mm.) half-titles woodcut armorial on title-pages vol.1: 1 engraved plate engraved portrait of Charles V with F4 blank; vol.3: engraved diagram on p.183 with final blank leaf; contemporary red morocco (probably by Gabriel de Sancha) with greek key border spines gilt in compartments with black morocco lettering-pieces gilt edges some worming at head of last few quires of vol.2 volume 4 with slight damage to upper inner corner towards the end of the volume with slight loss of text bindings slightly rubbed


A respected edition of the works of Luis Gines de Sepulveda (?1490-1573) prepared by Francisco Cerda y Rico and according to Palau "edicion bien impresa y apreciada". Sepulveda was court historian and wrote accounts of the reigns of Charles V and Philip II as well as writing works against Bartolome de Las Casas's criticisms on the Spanish methods of rule in the Americas.


The binding is most likely to be by Gabriel de Sancha; for a named binding with similar neoclassical motifs see British Library G18295 a copy of the Ibarra Don Quixote from 1780.


LITERATURE

PROVENANCE

item_title: Simplicius Venice Callierges 1499 diced calf with arms of Michael Wodhull
description:
Simplicius


Hypomnemata in Aristotelis categorias [Greek]. Venice: Zacharias Kallierges for Nicolaus Blastos 26 October 1499


Median folio (337 x 230mm.) 168 leaves A10 B-U8 Ph6 37 lines Greek type first leaf printed in red with woodcut printer's device of Blastos second leaf with heading woodcut initial and woodcut headpiece printed in red other woodcut initials and headings in red woodcut diagrams woodcut printer's device of Kallierges at foot of register diced russia gilt (by Roger Payne according to Wodhull sale catalogue) with Wodhull arms gilt on binding spine gilt in compartments old manuscript title lettering along foot of textblock title-page foxed and with small tear at foredge annotations in outer margins washed resulting in friable paper with some tears and repairs (a few touching text) joints cracked extremities slightly rubbed small label to head of upper cover


A TALL COPY OF THE EDITIO PRINCEPS. Simplicius a Neoplatonist scholar of sixth-century Alexandria wrote several commentaries on Aristotle. This volume is printed in Kallierges' clear Greek type with the accent incorporated into the sort for each letter. This is one of four books printed by Kallierges for Nicolaus Blastos a fellow Cretan whose role in the collapse of the Lippomano Bank in 1499 marked the end of the press's output.


LITERATURE

ISTC is00535000; Sander 6998


PROVENANCE

Michael Wodhull notes on flyleaf bought from Payne 12 May 1797 PS4-4-6 plus PS1-1-2 for "binding & much mending" sale Sotheby Wilkinson & Hodge 11 January 1886 lot 2372 PS1-7s ("large copy MS. Notes... very scarce")

item_title: Sophocles Commentarii in septem tragedias Sophoclis Rome Ginnasio Mediceo 1518 later calf
description:
Sophocles


Commentarii in septem tragedias Sophoclis. Rome: Ginnasio Mediceo 1518


4to (204 x 128mm.) text in Greek without final blank leaf late eighteenth-century calf gilt gilt edges some annotations in Greek and Latin occasional light foxing small repair to final leaf joints and extremities rubbed upper joints cracked


This work was printed by the Greek College Press which had been founded in the house of the papal secretary Angelo Colocci on the Quirinal Hill issuing a handful of Greek books between 1517 and 1520. It has been argued that the printer of these works was Vittore Carmelio recorded in the Vatican Archives as "magister stampator Grechus" who may well have worked for Kallierges previously.


LITERATURE

Edit16 12875; S. Fogelmark "The anonymous Rome 1522 Chrysoloras: a newly discovered Greek press" PBSA 97 (2003) 5-42

This volume contains books 1 and 2 only; books 3 and 4 were considered a separate work and had appeared in 1536.

description:
Themistius


Logoi ITh... Orationes XIX [edited by Denis Petau]. Paris: Sebastien Cramoisy 1618

item_title: Theocritus Idyllia [and other works] Venice Aldus 1495/96 modern leather binding
description:

Theocritus


Eidullia; Theognis; Dionysius Cato: Disticha [translated into Greek by Maximus Planudes]; Sententiae Septem sapientium; De invidia; Hesiodus: Opera et dies Theogonia. Venice: Aldus Manutius February 1495/96


Super-Chancery folio (291 x 198mm.) 137 leaves (of 140) A.A-D.D8 E.E.-Th.G.6; AA.aa-DD.dd8 EE.ee6 ZZ.zz10; a.a-b.b8 g.c10; d.d-e.e8 quire ZZ.zz bound after quire Th.G. 30 lines Greek type woodcut initials and headpieces manuscript foliation in Greek numerals other old annotations in Greek modern leather lacking A.A8 and d.d2 and 7 substantial paper repairs throughout (though mostly marginal); sold not subject to return


Second edition of Theocritus accompanied by Hesiod's Works and days Shield of Hercules and Theogony together with the Distichs of Theognis and other smaller Greek works. Theocritus's Idylls had been previously issued in Milan in 1480 by Bonus Accursius but this volume contains the editio princeps of Hesiod's Theogonia. Aldus dedicates his edition to his former teacher Battista Guarino who had requested him to produce an edition of Theogonia.


This is the first issue with Th.G.6v blank and the incorrect text on Z.F5 (see BMC).


LITERATURE

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Nikephoros Theotokis Stoicheon mathematikon Moscow 1798-99 3 volumes blue paper Russian tree calf
description:
Property from the Loverdos Collection


Nikephoros Theotokis


Stoikheion mathematikon ek palaion kai neoteron suneranithenton... tomos protos (-tritos). Moscow: Rudiger and Claudius 1798-1799


3 volumes 8vo (203 x 120mm.) printed on blue paper woodcut initials head- and tailpieces engraving at head of preface 25+31+39+22 folding plates (engraved and letterpress two sets of plates in vol.3) without final blanks at end of vols 1-2 contemporary Russian tree calf flat spines gilt red edges occasional worming (affecting some plates) occasional light staining possibly lacking plate 16 in vol.1 quire N in vol.3 misbound (before and after plates in centre of vol.3) bindings slightly rubbed with a few small wormholes some chipping of spine ends


FIRST EDITION. Nikephoros Theotokis (1731-1800) a native of Corfu was appointed archbishop of Cherson after his countryman Boulgaris (see lot 180). This school textbook the Elements of Mathematics compiled from ancients and contemporaries stretching from Euclid to Newton was in circulation in manuscript from the 1760s and first published in this edition of 1798; it introduced differential and integral calculus to a Greek audience. Theotokis was also the author of a similar textbook of physics printed in Leipzig in 1766.


Like Boulgaris Theotokis saw the Russian state as a potential saviour of the Greek nation from the Ottomans. His book was funded by the Zosimas brothers a Greek family of merchants and benefactors in Russia who also supported Greek independence.


LITERATURE

Christine Phili "A Corfiot Scientist in the Russian Empire: the case of Nikephoros Theotokis (1731-1800)" in In Foreign Lands: the migration of scientists for political or economic reasons (Cham: Springer 2022)

folio (273 x 190mm.) title within woodcut border woodcut illustration on O2 modern vellum lower corner of Cc1 repaired occasional staining or browning


FIRST SPANISH TRANSLATION OF THUCYDIDES. Diego Gracian translated several Greek works into Spanish including Xenophon and Plutarch as well as Latin texts. He was a member of a dynasty of translators who held several posts at the royal court from the time of Charles V into the seventeenth century. The book was dedicated by Gracian to Charles V even though he had died by the time of publication and Gracian included a petition within the dedication for his son to inherit his official position.

Property from the Loverdos Collection


Georgius Trapezuntius


Rhetorica. Venice: Vindelinus de Spira [not before 1472]


Chancery folio (314 x 217mm.) 154 leaves (of 156 without initial and final blanks) [a10 b-d8 e6 f-h8 i10 k-m8 n10 o-t8] Latin text with Greek quotations roman type modern half blue morocco numerous early annotations first leaf slightly soiled with small tear at head of gutter some wormholes towards end occasional light staining


A TALL COPY OF THE FIRST EDITION RARE. Georgius Trapezuntius (1396-1474) settled in Italy in 1416 studying Latin with Guarino of Verona and he translated numerous Greek texts as well as teaching Greek across Italy. This work of his is considered to be the first humanist handbook of rhetoric and this copy shows careful study by an early reader.

Vargas a fourteenth-century Augustinian monk studied Peter Lombard's Sententiae in Paris in the 1340s; this is the first edition of his commentary on the first book and is considered to be indicative of Augustine's reception in the later Middle Ages.

The numerous woodcuts were originally used for the Gruninger Strassburg edition of 1502 edited by Sebastian Brant whose verse address to the reader appears here on the verso of the title-page. The text was prepared by Jodocus Badius Ascensius and was first published in this form in Paris 1500-1501.

3 volumes folio (417 x 280mm.) half-titles titles printed in red and black engraved dedications (to Charles Emanuel of Savoy by Marco Carloni to Victor Amedeus of Savoy by Barbazza after Charles Vanloo and to Benedetto Maria Maurizio of Savoy by Ignazio Benedetti) engraved map of the Mediterranean at start of the Aeneid numerous engraved illustrations within the text contemporary Roman speckled calf gilt spines gilt in compartments red edges bindings slightly rubbed

Publius Vergilius Maro


A set of his works translated into Greek verse by Eugenios Boulgaris and printed in St Petersburg comprising:


Ton Georgikon... ta D biblia... Georgicorum libri IV [translated by Eugenios Boulgaris]. St Petersburg: Academy of Sciences 1786 parallel text in Latin and Greek engraved and woodcut head- and tailpieces

together 2 volumes folio (384 x 235mm.; 398 x 242mm.) contemporary calf red edges bindings rebacked and repaired


A translation of Vergil's works into Greek verse by Eugenios Boulgaris (1716-1806) a native of Corfu who spent time in Leipzig and Gottingen before being invited to St Petersburg by Catherine the Great the dedicatee of this work who appointed him as archbishop of Cherson in 1775. This is one of several translations into modern Greek made by Boulgaris.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Voltaire Candide [Paris] 1759 later calf with an autograph letter by Voltaire dated 1756
description:
[Francois Marie Arouet de Voltaire]


Candide ou l'optimisme. Traduit de l'allemand de Mr. le docteur Ralph. [Paris: Lambert] 1759


12mo (178 x 106mm.) 237 [3]pp. A-K12 paper watermarked with a bunch of grapes lettered "D[heart]Tamizier" [similar to Heawood 2388 etc] later smooth tan calf gilt fillet borders spine gilt in compartments top edge gilt others UNCUT AUTOGRAPH LETTER SIGNED ("Voltaire") tipped in at front of volume [watermark HR] 3pp. dated Les Delices de Geneve 27 March 1756 extracts from old sale catalogues pasted to front and rear flyleaves small engraved portrait of Voltaire pasted to front flyleaf light damp-staining in gutter of last few leaves autograph letter with a few small tears along creases and a repair on verso


Voltaire's Candide was first printed in Geneva by Cramer on 15 January 1759 on which day 1000 copies were sent to Paris and it was quickly reprinted elsewhere; at least 17 editions have been listed with this date of publication. The reprints with 237 numbered pages are usually associated with a Parisian printing which is borne out here by a paper stock often found in Parisian imprints.


The letter by Voltaire is addressed to Madame [Marie Sophie de La Tour d'Auvergne princesse de Beauvau-Craon 1729-1763] mentioning the death of one of her friends which kept Voltaire from her court and talking of one of his works [Poeme sur la religion naturelle] which is not yet ready to see the light of day though the Margravine of Bayreuth sent him a copy which had been printed "d'une maniere tres fautive".

The letter was sold in the 1920s with an English biography of Voltaire and has been subsequently inserted into this copy of Candide.


LITERATURE

Bengesco 1437; Electronic Enlightenment database letter D6805 (location unrecorded but giving provenance as A. Brun and baron de T.); Giles Barber "Modele genevoise mode europeene: le cas de Candide et de ses contrefacons" Studies in the history of printing 9 (1994) 56-74


PROVENANCE

Letter: [A. Brun sale Lyon 24 April 1884 no.738; baron de T. sale Paris 23 May 1885 no.191]; sale Hodgson's 10 May 1922 lot 473; Tregaskis catalogue 934 (1927) no.526 (extract pasted to inside front cover)

Book: Einar Christiansen EC bookplate

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Izaak Walton | The Compleat Angler 1653 first edition nineteenth-century morocco gilt the Rimington-Wilson copy
description:
Izaak Walton


The Compleat Angler or the Contemplative man's Recreation. Being a Discourse of Fish and Fishing Not unworthy the perusal of most Anglers. London: T. Maxey for Richard Marriot 1653


FIRST EDITION small 8vo (138 x 84mm.) engraved title within piscatorial cartouche ten engraved vignettes of fish in text two engraved pages of music by Henry Lawes with R3r in first state (with the misreading of "contention" for "contentment" corrected in a contemporary hand) nineteenth-century dark green morocco gilt by F. Bedford spine with raised bands in six compartments citron morocco labels in second and third compartments gilt edges marbled endpapers housed within a modern green half morocco collector's box a few leaves very slightly shaved at marginsfinal three leaves neatly extended at outer margins with a few letters in skillful facsimile extremities very slightly rubbed


A CHOICE COPY OF THE RARE FIRST EDITION OF THE MOST FAMOUS WORK IN ANGLING LITERATURE WITH A DISTINGUISHED NINETEENTH CENTURY PROVENANCE. This much-loved work is a fishing manual literary classic and a celebration of contemplation and the traditional natural order written in quiet opposition to Cromwell's regime. "...Sir There are many men that are by others taken to be serious grave men which we contemn and pitie; men of sowre complexiouns; mony-getting-men that spend all their time first in getting and next in anxious care to keep it: men that are condemn'd to be rich and alwayes discontented or busie. For these poor-rich-men wee Anglers pitie them ... For (trust me Sir) we enjoy a contentednesse above the reach of such dispositions...".


Walton's work contains "The Angler's Song" by the leading mid-seventeenth-century English songwriter Henry Lawes (1596-1662) with the second page printed upside down to enable two singers to sing facing each other. The charming engravings of fish have been variously attributed to Lombart Faithorn or Vaughan.


LITERATURE

Coigney 1; ESTC R202374; Horne 1; Oliver 1; Pforzheimer 1048; Westwood & Satchell p. 217 ("Copies rarely reach the auction room"); Wing W661


PROVENANCE

James Rimington-Wilson (1822-1877) of Broomhead Hall Yorkshire strong amateur chess player and noted collector of books on chess and other sports: ownership inscription to verso of front free endpaper; George Armin Goyder (1908-1997) businessman author Anglican layman bibliophile (with particular expertise on literature of the English Reformation) and president of the William Blake Society: armorial bookplate

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: John Wesley-Methodism | book of fair copies of 52 letters mostly unpublished mostly autograph 1742-1747
description:
John Wesley-Methodism


Book of fair copies of 52 letters mostly unpublished many in Wesley's hand 1742-1747


52 fair copies of letters by John Wesley addressed to various recipients from Newcastle dated February 23 1742 - March 13 1747 mostly autograph letters signed others plausibly in Charles Wesley's hand plus 8 pages of related material circa 100 pages in all 4to contemporary vellum light spotting and browning at extremities some early gatherings becoming loose binding slightly soiled


THE MOST SUBSTANTIAL COLLECTION OF (MOSTLY) UNPUBLISHED LETTERS BY JOHN WESLEY TO BE OFFERED AT AUCTION 49 (of 52) unrecorded by the Wesley Works Editorial Project which lists just 63 extant letters composed between February 1742 and 1747.


Three hands are present. The majority of the correspondence is in the hand of John Wesley himself (letters 1-45 48 49 50 52 plus 1p 'Proposals for printing by subscription these volumes of Moral and Sacred Poems: Collected from Various Authors'). Other letters (47 51) are plausibly in Charles Wesley's autograph and a 6pp draft of a sermon appears to be written in Charles's hand with corrections by John. A single letter (46) is written in a third hand perhaps that of an amanuensis. 


Whilst Wesley was a prolific letter writer 'much of his correspondence was private' and 'only a small percentage of Wesley's letters have been preserved' (Campbell). This correspondence documents Wesley's early attempts to establish his base in the North East revealing the dynamic between Wesley and his contemporaries including George Whitfield women in his ministry emerging Methodist networks and family members. Addressees include Wesley's traveling companion and secretary John Meriton (letter 4) Sarah Perrin (letter 40) William Horner (letter 5) Revd. John Hutchings (letter 19) Thomas Glascott (letter 27) Thomas Butts (letter 30) and John Stephenson (letter 38). 


Wesley tussled with George Whitfield over issues of Calvinist predestination in c.1740 but a letter of December 9 1742 addressed 'To The Revd. Mr. Whitef.' extends an olive branch of 'peace between me and Thee and between my people and thy People' expressing 'no inclination to controversy of any kind' and acknowledging that 'Many Calvinists are in our Society here' (letter 17). A later letter (addressee unknown) of February 1743 declares that 'there is no one Point where I differ from the Moravian Breth[re]n wherein Mr. Whitfield does not differ from them too' (letter 29).


Other letters convey excitement about the burgeoning Methodist movement whilst revealing the logistical challenges of establishing regional bases. On November 30 1742 Wesley declares that 'Our Society here consists now of seven hundred and ten persons & more are pressing in every Day. the Word of the Lord runs & is glorified greatly' although the same letter bemoans the 'wretched Management' of West Country ministers (letter 11) and another composed on the same day frets about 'Schism' amongst his brethren. In one of two letters addressed to the Mayor of Newcastle dated July 12 1743 he is forced to absolve his followers from blame for causing a 'tumult' whilst preaching on the Sand-hill in Newcastle (letter 44).


Some of the most interesting letters reveal Wesley's attitudes towards women in his ministry. Writing to 'Mrs Rawlins Bristol' on 16 November 1742 he tenderly urges her to 'See that Molly Francis & you be as one soul. Take care of the little ones' (letter 1). He encourages an active role for pioneering female exhorter Sarah Perrin instructing her to visit the sick of Bristol alongside Sarah Colston (letter 40). (Sarah Perrin would later be proposed as a possible spouse for John's brother Charles).


Together this correspondence conveys the sense of a scrupulous rational thinker but also occasionally reveals a complex character who was willing to do whatever was needed to grow his ministry.


LITERATURE

Campbell 'John Wesley as diarist and correspondent' Cambridge Companion to John Wesley


PROVENANCE

Presented by John Wesley to Joseph Cownley (1723-1792) a talented Wesleyan Methodist preacher in regular correspondence with Wesley; presented by Cownley to Wesleyan preacher John Gaulter (1764-1839): manuscript note in Gaulter's hand to front pastedown detailing early provenance ('These letters were co[llected?] by the Revd Mr John Wesley and by him given to the Revd Mr Jos Cownley who presented them to me as a memorial of his love and friendship. NCastle July 15.1792. JGaulter'); Revd. Dr. Robert Alder (1796-1873) Methodist minister and (later) Anglican priest who 'watched vigorously over the growth of the Methodist organization in the Maritime provinces' (Dictionary of Canadian Biography); thence from Alder's widow to her granddaughter Miss Alton; presented by Alton to the Wesleyan minister and naturalist Reverend Hilderic Friend (1851-1940): manuscript note to front free endpaper ('This interesting property became the property of Rev. Dr. Alder whose widow presented it to her granddaughter Miss Alton daughter of the Rev. Mr. Alton Wesleyan Minister. In July 1891 Miss Alton sent the volume to the Rev. Hilderic Friend').

description:
Album


Autograph album of the Hamburg Philharmonic Society containing musical quotations inscriptions photographs and signatures


including by Stravinsky (autograph inscription: "Vielen herzlichen Dank Igor Stravinsky...Sept/58") Richard Strauss (signature) Sibelius Arrau Ansermet Bohm Backhaus Busch Boult Britten Beecham Brendel Barenboim Cortot Celibidache Curzons Dohnanyi Dorati Fischer Furtwangler Fournier Malcom Frager Gieseking Arthur Grumiaux Hindemith Heather Harper Krenek Walter Klien Kienzl Klemperer Leinsdorf Menuhin Messiaen Muti Martin Nielson Ormandy Orff Pfitzner Pollini Perlmann Leonard Rose Reznicek Rostropovich Sargent Solti Walter


over 90 leaves plus blanks 4to (c.22 x 16.5cm) Hamburg and elsewhere original leather binding by Georg Hulbe Hamburg/Berlin embossed lettering to upper cover ("Autographen-Register") c.1935-1974 split at upper hinge some loss of leather to spine

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Augsburg. Three manuscript liturgical volumes made by the Dominican sisters of St Catharine's Augsburg 1725-1749
description:
Augsburg


A group of three eighteenth-century manuscript liturgical volumes produced by the Dominican Sisters of St Catharine's Convent Augsburg comprising:


1. [A volume of antiphons] 229 [1 (blank)] ff. with hand-stamped foliation inscribed by Sor Maria Walburga on front flyleaf stamped "A" on upper cover


2. Processionale juxta ritum Sacri Praedicatorum Ordinis Augsburg 1727 [1 (title and contents)] 253 ff. with hand-stamped foliation stamped "C" on upper cover


3. Hymnus [Augsburg] 1745 (1749) 53 ff. manuscript foliation with a leaf of liturgical manuscript in the same hand loosely inserted


3 volumes 8vo (approx. 19 x 12cm) manuscripts on paper in red and black with musical notation all in contemporary blind-tooled pigskin over wooden boards two volumes with near-identical decoration and lettered A and C in gold on upper covers and with blue edges the third volume with red edges all with two pairs of clasps plausibly from the bindery of Johann Georg Mozart in Augsburg.


The third volume contains a manuscript title mentioning Mother Maria Dominica Erhardt (1694-1756) who wrote a chronicle of the convent in 1752.


Johann Georg Mozart (1679-1736) the grandfather of Wolfgang Amadeus was a bookbinder in Augsburg; his shop was on Frauentorstrasse 30 before moving in 1722 to Jesuitengasse. The family business was continued by Joseph Ignaz (1725-1796) and Franz Aloys (1727-1791) brothers of Leopold Mozart.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: [B. Bartok] Two music albums belonging to Stefi Geyer and Rosmarin Jaggi 1901-1965
description:
[Bela Bartok] Stefi Geyer and Rosmarin Jaggi


Two music albums belonging to Bartok's muse Stefi Geyer and her daughter Rosmarin Jaggi containing musical quotations drawings inscriptions letters photographs and signatures over 125 entries in all 1901-1965 


including by Bartok (signed menu card) Stravinsky (photographic portrait inscribed and signed ("Fur Fraulein R. Schulthess ein Andenken von I Stravinsky 8 Nov 1936") Ravel (signature dated 5 February 1932) Rachmaninoff (signature 1938) Massenet (2 one a 2-bar autograph musical quotation signed from Manon) Wilhelm Kienzl (postcard photographic portrait signed) Honegger (musical quotation signed from Nicolas de Flue) Dohnanyi Pfitzner Reger Siegmund von Hausegger Richter Ferdinand Lowe Siegfried Wagner John Philip Sousa Kubelik Huberman Kreisler Leschetizky Wilhelmj (3) Nellie Melba Cortot Horowitz Rubinstein Schnabel Solomon Bruno Walter Adolf Busch Casals Gieseking Milstein Serkin Toscanini Edwin Fischer Furtwangler Backhaus Willy Burkhard Carl Flesch Pierre Fournier Menuhin Paul Sacher Hindemith Peter Pears Britten (3-bar autograph musical quotation from the Serenade for tenor horn and strings 1948) Kodaly Elisabeth Schwarzkopf and Ormandy with four drawings and watercolours including by Hans Erni


2 volumes c.46 and 90 pages plus blanks c.21 x 14.3 and 17.5 x 13cm ownership inscription to front free endpaper of one volume ("Geyer Stefi / Budapest...") the Massenet items laid down or mounted in Geyer's album gilt edges leather book jacket by Maison Casset of Lyon to Stefi Geyer's album with small silver monogram ("SG") to upper cover leather binding to Rosmarin Jaggi's album London Budapest Zurich and elsewhere 1901-1965 where indicated one gathering detached in Geyer's volume Jaggi's album split at upper hinge


The original owner of the older of the two albums with entries from 1901-1908 was the distinguished Hungarian violinist Stefi Geyer (1888-1956) Bartok's early muse and the inspiration for his first violin concerto (1907-1908). Some highly revealing letters by Bartok to Geyer are now preserved in the Paul Sacher Stiftung Basel. The other album with entries from 1925-1965 was that of Stefi Geyer's daughter Rosmarin Jaggi.


PROVENANCE

By descent to the present owner

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: L. v. Beethoven. Receipt signed and sealed by Beethoven for his allowance from Prince Kinsky 25 February 1827
description:
Ludwig van Beethoven


Receipt signed in Roman script and sealed by Beethoven ("Ludwig van Beethoven")


acknowledging receipt of two hundred and forty gulden being his six-monthly living allowance for the period 1 September 1826 to 1 March 1827 paid from Prince Rudolf Kinsky's treasury in Prague in accordance with the assent granted on 18 January 1815


...Uiber Zweyhundert Vierzig Gulden Conv. Munze vom 1. September [1]826 bis 1. Marz 1827 halbjahrig vertagten Unterhaltungs-Beytrag welchen ich...aus der Rudolph furstlich Kinskyschen Prager ['pupillar': deleted] Hauptkasse heute baar und richtig empfangen zu haben anmit quittire...


1 page folio (c.35 x 20.7cm) integral blank numbered "82" in manuscript with Beethoven's red seal (lettered "LVB") with a second scribal signature countersigned by the priest C. Santner confirming his residence in Vienna papered seal Vienna 25 February 1827


Signed by Beethoven a month before his death.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: A. Bruckner. Autograph sketches for the second movement (Scherzo) of the unfinished 9th Symphony 1889
description:
Anton Bruckner


Autograph sketches for the Scherzo movement of the unfinished Symphony no.9 in D minor NOT RECORDED OR PUBLISHED IN SAMTLICHE WERKE


written in pencil in Bruckner's shaky but indomitable hand on up to 6 three-stave systems per page with autograph heading and date (" IX te ! Scherzo 4. 1. 89.") some bar sequences numbered by the composer ("1...2...3...4...5...6...7...8...") the pitches changed or confirmed by the composer in many places with letter-names and annotated by him in the margins containing extensive autograph cancellations revisions and corrections


4 pages oblong 4to (c.27 x 32.5cm) 20-stave paper ("B & H. Nr. 16.A.") watermarked "BREITKOPF & HAERTEL LEIPZIG" inscription by Ferdinand Lowe ("Lowe IX te !") to upper inside corner of the first page no place [Vienna] 4 January 1889 splitting along hinge browning central vertical crease a few tiny marks and stains


THE MOST SIGNIFICANT BRUCKNER MANUSCRIPT TO BE OFFERED AT AUCTION IN RECENT YEARS.


BRUCKNER'S NINTH SYMPHONY RANKS ALONGSIDE SCHUBERT'S EIGHTH AND MAHLER'S TENTH AS ONE OF THE GREATEST UNFINISHED CREATIONS IN ALL MUSIC.


THIS 4-PAGE SKETCH EVIDENTLY THE FIRST SURVIVING DRAFT FOR THE ICONIC SCHERZO WAS UNKNOWN TO THE EDITORS OF BRUCKNER'S COLLECTED WORKS. 


The writing of his ninth symphony one of the mightiest creations in the entire symphonic repertory occupied the last nine years of Bruckner's life. Dedicated to 'dem lieben Gott' and with a famously unfinished finale it represents the composer's musical testament a truly sublime score into which Bruckner poured his unshakeable belief as well as his tortured doubts.

The present manuscript unknown to the editors of Bruckner's works in the collected edition is a continuity sketch for the first eighty-eight bars of the Scherzo (with its celebrated hammered drumbeat theme) and evidently represents Bruckner's first attempts to write the movement; a somewhat neater and more extended sketch for the movement written on the same day (4 January 1889) is preserved in the Austrian National Library (Mus. Hs. 3196). These are the only two known sketches for the movement. The autograph score of the first three movements as well as the bulk of autograph material relating to the finale is also located in the Austrian National Library.


The first performance of the symphony in a revised version was given by Bruckner pupil Ferdinand Lowe (1865-1925) with the Wiener Konzertvereinsorchester on 11 February 1903. The first performance of the work in its original form took place as late as 1932 in Munich under the baton of Siegmund von Hausegger.


LITERATURE

Anton Bruckner. Samtliche Werke: ix ('Studienpartitur 2. revidierte Ausgabe') ed. Leopold Nowak (1951); ix ('2. Satz...Scherzo und Trio: Entwurfe') ed. Benjamin Gunnar Cohrs (1998); ix ('Finale') ed. John A. Phillips (1996); ix ('1. Satz - Scherzo & Trio - Adagio') ed. Benjamin Gunnar Cohrs (2001)


PROVENANCE

J.A. Stargardt Berlin Catalogue 700 (2014) lot 665

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: E. Caruso. Signed photograph and an art deco compact showing a caricature of Caruso early C20th
description:
Enrico Caruso


Photographic portrait inscribed and signed to Sybil Seligman with a silver and enamelled art deco compact showing a caricature of Caruso


Photographic portrait signed and inscribed on the image to Sybil Seligman ("Alla cara e amabile amica Sybil Sinceramente Enrico Caruso Londra 1913") 22.5 x 16.5 by H. Mishkin of New York 1913 a few marks and tiny stains


Silver and enamelled art deco compact showing a caricature of Caruso c.6.8 x 5.4 x 2cm by Lacloche Freres original case Paris and London early twentieth century minute crack to enamel at lower left-hand corner of compact lid


Although chiefly remembered as an important friend of Puccini Sybil Seligman nee Beddington (1868-1936) from whom the photograph and compact ultimately derive was also a close friend of Caruso.


PROVENANCE

By descent to the present owners.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: E. Caruso. Fine large autograph caricature of the composer Leoncavallo signed and inscribed ("Enrico Caruso 1907")
description:
Enrico Caruso


Fine large autograph caricature of Ruggero Leoncavallo signed and inscribed ("Enrico Caruso 1907")


in black crayon on paper 1 page folio (c.35.6 x 21.5cm) 1907 staining at edges from remains of former mounting with adhesive tape editorial stamp to verso


Roles in the operas of Leoncavallo were central to Caruso's repertory particularly Canio in Pagliacci. In 1907 alone he performed the role in Baltimore Chicago Milwaukee London and Hamburg.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Composer and musicians. Collection of letters signed with an autograph musical quotation by R. Strauss 1876-1963
description:
Composers and musicians


Collection of mostly autograph and typed letters signed and a 2-bar autograph musical quotation signed by Richard Strauss from Till Eulenspiegel


including by Grieg (a thank-you letter 1 page) Humperdinck (to E.W. Fritzsch in Leipzig requesting he be sent in future only one copy of the Musikalisches Wochenblatt 1 page on a postcard) Delibes (discussing a matter of copyright 4 pages) Jenny Lind (1 autograph note to Clara Schumann signed "J.L-G" 8 March 1882 on a postcard; 1 clipped signature and a photographic portrait) Joseph Joachim (in English describing a photograph of himself: "...a poor beaten Cambridge man who hopes for better times next year") Clara Schumann (in English commenting on a visit to London: "It seems to me like a dream..." 2 pages on a correspondence card) Saint-Saens Adelina Patti (describing a successful season on the Riviera singing in La Traviata Lucia di Lammermoor Don Giovanni etc. 7 March 1896 3 pages; with a visiting-card-style photographic portrait) Sir Henry Wood Eduard Strauss (presenting his correspondent with a volume of memoirs 2 pages) Vaughan Williams (remembering a beautiful day 1 page) Walton (to Basil Ashmore returning a typescript [not enclosed] Adrian Boult Malcolm Sargent (2) Basil Cameron Owen Brannigan Barbirolli 1 page 27 August 1953)


c.28 pages in all various sizes the autograph musical quotation by Strauss framed and glazed (overall size 33.5 x 34cm) the other items Vienna London Dorking and elsewhere 1876-1963 where indicated creasing to the Vaughan Williams letter

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Composers and musicians. Collection of autograph letters signed C19th and C20th
description:
Composers and musicians


Collection of autograph letters signed including by


Hummel (to Leo 1 page 2 May 1825) Cornelius (about Berlioz 3 pages 16 February 1855) Gade (2 to Joachim and Reinecke) Cesar Franck Bruch (to Prof. Schaffer 1 page on a postcard 31 December 1892) Alma Mahler (to Kallir mentioning Berg and Mahler 2 pages 25 February 1948) Robert Franz (to a professor 2 pages 30 December 1886) Paderewski Toch (autograph musical quotation from the Symphony no.1 op.72) Moriz Rosenthal Heinrich de Ahna Bischoff (2 to Edward Speyer) Karl Klindworth Pfitzner Pauer Bulow Moszkowski Volkmann Vaughan Williams (2 to Marion Scott) Hans Joachim Moser (2) Radecke Norma Gadsden (signed postcard photograph); together with a number of letters and other items by miscellaneous politicians poets writers artists etc. including by Gladstone Franz Werfel Daudet (2) Lin Yutang Philipp Scheidemann Christopher Fry Charles I of Austria and Renee Sintenis


over 200 items in all various sizes Paris Weimar Berlin Copenhagen and elsewhere C19th and C20th


Sold as a collection not subject to return.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Dance. Eighteenth-century French manuscript volume of 478 dance and song tunes c.1780s
description:
Dance


Eighteenth-century French manuscript volume of 478 dance and song tunes


notated in dark brown ink on up to six single-stave systems per page by apparently three different unidentified hands the dances comprising contredanses minuets marches allemandes gavottes bourrees cotillions ariettes etc. and INCLUDING A VERSION OF "LISON DORMAIT" (on p.64) a melody on which Mozart based his piano variations K.264 (315d) a number of melodies with detailed instructions for dancing the melodies occasionally continued in to the margins on hand-drawn staves


[224] pages oblong 8vo (12.6 x 20cm) 6-stave paper pastedowns and endpapers with indexes and other contemporary annotations ("...Pour moi le 10 juin 1785...1786 le 4 fevrier...Recette...1788: 9 fevrier") contemporary vellum alum-tawed ties [?Paris 1780s] one tie defective staining to covers


A fascinating eighteenth-century source of named dance and song tunes.


This volume rich in research potential apparently originated in Paris in the 1780s (up to the beginning of the Revolution) and may well have been the handbook of a maitresse de danse who was perhaps a violin teacher as well. The evidence for a female owner is perhaps suggested by some of the recipes (one for make-up remover) and other (copious) annotations which cover the pastedowns and endpapers of the volume: particularly suggestive are the addresses of two doctors Jean-Baptiste-Claude Jeannet des Longrois and Joseph Raulin known to have specialised in female medicine. Such a person may have managed a dance hall which often doubled as a gambling den and in some instances a kind of brothel (according to the memoirs of Retif de la Bretonne).

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: A. Dvorak. Cabinet photograph signed in pencil 1884
description:
Antonin Dvorak


Cabinet-style photograph signed on the image and mount ("Antonin Dvorak") in pencil


by Negretti & Lambra of London 16.8 x 11.8cm dated on verso by the recipient "Worcester 1884" photographer's elaborate imprint on verso ("Negretti & Lambra Crystal Palace") [Worcester November 1884] loss of small piece of inside lower corner of mount 


Dvorak's first visit to England was in March 1884 when he conducted his Stabat Mater op.58 in the Albert Hall. The great success of that performance lead to a second visit in November 1884 when he travelled on to Worcester again conducting the Stabat Mater. The following year saw the premiere of the Seventh Symphony in London.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: E. Elgar. Violin Concerto op.61 score signed and inscribed by Elgar 1916
description:
Edward Elgar


Violin Concerto in B minor op.61 score signed and inscribed by Elgar ("Edward Elgar March 1916") in blue-black ink on the dedication page and also by Albert Sammons and Yehudi Menuhin 


the 8vo edition of the full score the printed dedication also annotated by the composer "[Aqui esta encerrada el alma de] A.N." with Sammons's inscription below Elgar's ("AlbertSammons 1916") and Menuhin's over the title in blue ink ("Yehudi Menuhin April 26 1981")


8vo Novello printed wrappers the spine and hinges reinforced with translucent adhesive tape staining affecting the printed text on the final page (but not the inscriptions); together with two newspaper cuttings concerning Sammons's performances of the concerto under Henry Wood at the Queen's Hall London all contained in an envelope addressed to the former owner postmarked in 1916 red seal bearing Elgar's initials ("EE")


Albert Sammons and Yehudi Menuhin were two celebrated interpreters of Elgar's Violin Concerto performing it under the composer's baton several times. Sammons recorded the work in 1929 with Henry Wood and Menuhin made a famous recording with the composer in 1932 when only 16 years of age.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Gershwin's "Strike up the Band" and Stravinsky's "Scenes de ballet" both scores inscribed by their composers 1930-1944
description:
George Gershwin and Igor Stravinsky


Two inscribed scores: "Strike up the Band" by Gershwin and "Scenes de ballet" by Stravinsky 1930 & 1944


GERSHWIN. Strike up the Band [vocal score] New York: New World Music Corporation 1930 signed and inscribed by Gershwin to the composer Maurice Yvain FIRST COMPLETE EDITION inscribed in black ink on the title ("To Maurice Yvain with cordial greetings on his first trip to America With Admiration George Gershwin Apr.29 1930") 167 pages 4to lyrics by Ira Gershwin book by Morrie Ryskind publisher's wrappers printed in red and blue red cloth spine modern red folding cloth box front wrapper restored


STRAVINSKY. Printed reproduction score of "Scenes de ballet" signed twice ("Igor Stravinsky 1944") and inscribed by him with a warm dedication to his choreographer Anton Dolin ("Pour vous mon cher Antony Dolin avec mes pensees admiratives et avec toute mon impatience de voir realise cette musique avec votre brillant couleurs/ Votre Stravinsky/ Hollywood Sept 16 1944") a photographic reproduction of a manuscript piano score 25 leaves 4to 12-stave paper printed on one side only fixed together with adhesive tape contemporary dark blue cloth blue-gilt labels staining from the adhesive tape


Gershwin originally staged Strike up the Band in 1927 but only separate numbers were published. This wholesale revision with half of the score rewritten was premiered on 14 January 1930 and only then published in full. The plot satirizes America's enthusiasm for trade wars declaring war on Switzerland over the tariff on Swiss chocolate. Stravinsky's score was probably used at the rehearsals of Scenes de ballet in Philadelphia in 1944. Anton Dolin (1904-1983) provided the choreography for the production alluded to in the composer's dedication which opened on 24 November 1944.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: C. Gounod. Autograph musical quotation from the love duet in Act 3 of "Faust" signed and inscribed to Adelina Patti
description:
Charles Gounod


Autograph musical quotation from the love duet in Act 3 of Faust in Italian signed and inscribed to Adelina [Patti] ("All' Adelina Mirabile uno fra tanti!...Ch. Gounod")


four bars for Doctor Faust (tenor) from the introduction to the duet with Marguerite with the words "Dammi ancor dammi ancor contemplar il tuo viso!" notated on a hand-drawn stave titled "Faust"


1 page on an album-leaf c.15 x 25cm [possibly London 1871-1874] with part of an autograph note signed by Giovanni Bottesini on verso from the Hotel Privitali [London] some browning the verso defective from former mount tiny hole not affecting text   


Faust (1859) is Gounod's most famous work. This quotation is from the Italian version of the introduction to the Act 3 duet for Faust and Marguerite "O Nuit d'amour". The original French words for this passage are "Laisse-moi laisse-moi contempler ton visage". Outside France Faust was often sung in Italian especially at Covent Garden where Adelina Patti (1843-1919) reigned supreme from 1861 to 1885. It is highly likely that Gounod heard "the wonderful Adelina" in Faust during his exile in London from 1870 to 1874 and that this album-leaf constitutes his musical request to meet her. Gounod echoes Dante (with regard to Beatrice) in dubbing Patti "mirabile".

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: G.F. Handel. First edition of "Radamisto" together with the "Arie aggiunte" 1720-1721
description:
George Frideric Handel


Two first editions


Il Radamisto Opera rapresentata nel Regio Teatro D'Hay Market [score] London: author (Meares and Smith) [1720]; with Arie aggiunte di Radamisto [score] London: author (Meares and Smith) [1721]


2 volumes in one 121 and 38 pages folio (c.35.5 x 22.5) engraved titles and music privilege ownership inscriptions to front free endpaper contemporary panelled calf gilt lettering to upper cover creasing to endpapers light browning to title light wear to covers splitting to joints 


RARE.


Copies of Radamisto one of Handel's most important early operas with the 'Arie aggiunte' are highly prized. Among the ownership inscriptions to the volume is one by Mary Jackson the widow of the organist and composer William Jackson (1815-1866) the so-called "Jackson of Masham".


LITERATURE

Smith nos.1 and 2; RISM H 258 and H 261; BUC p.429

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: G.F. Handel. First edition of the oratorio "Judas Maccabaeus" (Smith no.2) 1747
description:
George Frideric Handel


Judas Macchabaeus an Oratorio set to Musick by Mr Handel London: J. Walsh [1747]


FIRST EDITION 3 leaves 72 [1] pages folio (c.33 x 24cm) unpaginated 'Marche' after p.72 engraved title Table of the Songs and music second state of the printed privilege (31 October 1739) single pagination throughout marbled boards black morocco label gilt to upper cover the 'Marche' cut out and laid down rebacked and restored new flyleaves


Smith no.2; not in Hoboken; RISM H 636; Hirsch iv 772


LITERATURE

Smith notes that the issue with the first state of the privilege was advertised in the London Evening-Post on 28-30 April 1747 and speculates that the present issue was probably that advertised in the General Advertiser on 2 March 1748.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: J. Haydn. Dr. Haydn's VI Original Canzonettas first edition signed by Haydn 1794
description:
Joseph Haydn


Dr. Haydn's VI Original Canzonettas for the Voice with an Accompaniment for the Piano-Forte [Hob XXVIa:25] London: "for the Author & Sold by him at No.1 Bury Street S.t James's..." [1794] SIGNED BY THE COMPOSER ON THE TITLE ("Haydn[paraph]")


FIRST EDITION 4to (c.35.5 x 25.5cm) 31 pages engraved throughout bound together with other works including by Harrington Abington Kent Harrison Hook Stephen Storace and Paisiello ownership inscriptions to front pastedown and elsewhere ("E Wood"; "Eliz.th Wood") contemporary half calf binding worn


This celebrated collection of Haydn's English songs was issued by the composer himself from his lodgings in London during his last visit to England in 1794.


LITERATURE

RISM H 2656; Hoboken ix (1991) 1525; Hirsch iii 799

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: E. Humperdinck. Autograph manuscript of the revised ending of "Hansel and Gretel" composed for Dessau [c.1894]
description:
Engelbert Humperdinck


Autograph manuscript of part of "Hansel und Gretel" being the revised ending composed for Dessau in 1894


with the title "Hansel und Gretel / Dessauer Schluss" the short score unsigned notated in black ink on six two-stave systems containing the final chorus "Wenn die Not aufs hochste steigt" slightly simplified and without the solo singers followed by a completely different continuation for orchestra from that found in the original version incorporating an old march-tune ('Der alte Dessauer-Marsch') with copious stage directions written above the music explaining that the gingerbread house collapses ("Das Knusperhauschen sturzt ein") and a trunk with gold and jewellery appears from which the children take various instruments (trumpets drums rattles etc.) and join the march until the curtain falls the manuscript comprising 57 bars in all with some deletions and alterations and a few instrumental markings ("Fag" "Horn" "Trompeten" "Hr.")


1 page folio (c.35.5 x 25.7cm) 16-stave paper no place or date [c.1894] some splitting at folds and marginal tears trace of mount on verso


RARE: Hansel und Gretel is Humperdinck's masterpiece and autograph manuscripts from it are seldom offered for sale. His fairy-tale opera is one of the most enduring works of post-Wagnerian German opera. Richard Strauss who conducted the premiere in Weimar in 1893 declared it a masterpiece and it has never fallen out of the repertory. 


Humperdinck composed this revised ending for a production in Dessau in 1894 staged by Cosima Wagner in which he incorporated 'Der alte Dessauer-Marsch' an infantry march dating from c.1705. The march dominates the music from the third system until the end creating a much more extended instrumental ending than the original Weimar version which is only eleven bars long. The march is here notated in double the time values found in contemporary printed sources for the tune such as Emil Pauer's Sammlung der beruhmtesten Deutschen Franzosischen und Italienischen Marsche (1875) no.36 (p.69).

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: J. Joachim. Portrait of the twelve-year-old violinist by Suzette Hauptmann 1843
description:
Music


Joseph Joachim


Fine portrait of the twelve-year-old violinist by Suzette Hauptmann


executed in pencil a half-length drawing showing the child prodigy with his violin and bow inscribed in the lower right-hand corner "Joseph Joachim / 1843" 


14.2 x 10cm on paper laid down on card glazed (overall size 17.8 x 11.2cm) with a manuscript inscription quoting the first verse of a poem by Herman Grimm (1899) in an unidentified hand on a strip of paper now loose below the image [Leipzig] 1843 some discolouration some fraying of the paper border


THE ICONIC PORTRAIT OF THE YOUNG VIOLIN PRODIGY.


This famous drawing dates from 1843 the year Joachim commenced his studies with Mendelssohn in Leipzig. While there Joachim also received lessons in composition from the violinist and Thomaskantor Moritz Hauptmann; it was his wife Suzette (born 1811) daughter of the painter Marianne von Rohden (1785-1866) who executed the present portrait. A notable feature of the drawing with regard to Joachim's instrument is the absence of a chin rest which although invented by Spohr already around 1820 did not gain general popularity until many years later.


The later-added manuscript inscription below the drawing is a quotation of the first verse of a seven-verse poem by Herman Grimm ('Joseph Joachim. Zur Erinnerung an den 17. Marz 1839') dating from April 1899 celebrating the sixtieth anniversary of Joachim's public debut at the Adelskasino in Pest on 17 March 1839:


Vor sechzig Jahren als es Fruhling war

  Da stand ein Kind in lichtem Lockenhaar

  Vielhundert Augen sah es auf sich blicken

  Sie schienen Muth ihm freundlich zuzunicken:

  Die kleine Geige nahm es unter's Kinn

  Den Bogen setzt' es auf die Saiten hin:

  An diesem Abend klang zum erstenmal

  Dein Saitenspiel im weitgedrangten Saal... 


LITERATURE

A. Moser Joseph Joachim: ein Lebensbild (Berlin 1898) facing p.19.


PROVENANCE

Formerly in the collection of the Berlin pianist composer and conductor Ernst Rudorff (1840-1916)

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: J. Joachim. Collection of 5 autograph letters signed by Joachim Saint-Saens Bazzini and Casals 1858-1911
description:
Joseph Joachim


Five autograph letters signed by Joachim Saint-Saens Bazzini and Casals


JOSEPH JOACHIM. Good autograph letter about Brahms signed with initials to Ave Lallemant expressing his delight at finally seeing Brahms's first orchestral works in print (the Serenades and the First Piano Concerto) pointing out that insulting reviews of them in the journal Signale and elsewhere are only to be expected and discussing dates of his concerts with Clara Schumann mentioning Otten and Grimm ("...Ich habe mich sehr gefreut endlich Johannes Sachen fur Orchester gedruckt vor mir zu sehen. Nun konnen sie getrost von den 'Signale' und andern oberflachlichen Gesellen verschimpfirt werden...") 3 pages 8vo (22 x 14cm) integral autograph address-panel remains of seal postmarked (with an envelope for another letter) Hanover 2 January [1861]--CAMILLE SAINT SAENS. Two autograph letters one to the conductor Albert Carre about La Princesse jaune (1872) asking whether it is really still relevant discussing whether his early ballet Gavotte and the opera Phryne are worth a place in the repertory the other about an musical instrument and Aquilino Barba 4 pages 8vo & oblong 4to (c.17.5 x 22cm) embossed monogram date-stamp 21 October 1904 19 and 20 October [1904]--ANTONIO BAZZINI. Fine autograph letter in French to a journalist describing his career and his many concert-tours including playing with Liszt 4 pages 8vo (20.5 x 13cm) Paris 6 April 1858--PABLO CASALS. Autograph letter signed ("Pablo Casals") to the composer Emanuel Moor about playing his music 2 pages 4to (c.29 x 20.5cm) printed stationery of the Hotel Wiedenhof Elberfeld 21 October 1911

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: L. Lacoste. First edition of "Orion" 1728
description:
Louis Lacoste


Orion Tragedie en Musique [score] Paris: J.-B.-Christophe Ballard 1728


FIRST EDITION 4 leaves [lvi] and 331 [1] pages 1 leaf oblong 4to (18.9 x 24.5cm) type-set music advertisement tables and list of performers woodcut devices head- and tail-pieces ownership inscription to verso of front endpaper ("...Beroldingen") spine gilt in compartments red morocco label gilt to spine contemporary mottled calf modern folding box last two leaves supplied in photocopy splitting at joints lower outer corner of upper cover renewed some worming to lower cover


LITERATURE

RISM L 158; Hirsch ii 500

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: F. Liszt. Autograph letter signed 22 January 1867
description:
Franz Liszt


Good autograph letter signed in German with musical examples to Frau Hirschfeld


commenting on a sonata in B minor by her husband which he has often played with pleasure stating that he will offer some detailed comments to the author of the work in person also praising his Polonaise noting however that a rhythmical similarity to Chopin's A major Polonaise [op.40 no.1 the "Military"] disturbs him slightly offering some generous criticisms and suggesting a revision which he illustrates by means of 4 autograph musical examples


...Auch die Polonaise hat Feuer und Schwung - doch stort mich dabei ein Klein wenig die rhythmische Ahnlichkeit mit der A dur Polonaise von Chopin...


3 pages 8vo (c.21 x 13.5cm) modern pencil annotation to otherwise blank final page with a visiting card of the singer Luise Scharnack possibly inscribed by her (?) and a postcard photographic portrait of Liszt Rome 22 January 1867 splitting along folds a few old repairs slightly affecting the text in a few places


A good letter illustrating Liszt's typically generous musical spirit.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: J.-B. Lully. First edition of the full score of "Acis et Galatee" 1686
description:
Jean-Baptiste Lully


Acis et Galatee Pastorale Heroique [full score] Paris: C. Ballard 1686


FIRST EDITION 2 leaves li and 183 pages 2 leaves folio (37.3 x 25cm) dedication type-set music printer's woodcut device to title head- and tail-pieces a number of contemporary corrections some later pencil and ink annotations to front endpapers manuscript inscription to title ("campistron et lulli. 1686") spine gilt in compartments contemporary calf browning and some old repairs to a few leaves a few small tears splitting to joints covers scuffed and extremities worn


LITERATURE

RISM L 2932; Hirsch ii 525

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: F. Mendelssohn Bartholdy. Partly autograph manuscript of "Jagdlied" op.120 no.1 c.1837
description:
Felix Mendelssohn Bartholdy


Partly autograph manuscript of the choral tenor part of "Jagdlied" op.120 no.1 [MWV G 21] c.1837


the music notated by a scribal hand on eight single staves THE WORDS WRITTEN BY MENDELSSOHN THROUGHOUT in dark brown ink including the title "Jagdlied" tempo marking ("Presto") and text ("Auf ihr Herrn und Damen schon") the vocal designation ("Tenore 1") by the scribe with a few small corrections possibly made by the composer comprising forty-two bars of music in all


1 page folio (c.30 x 24cm) 16-stave paper no place or date [c.1837]


Mendelssohn composed this attractive part song for four solo voices and chorus in November 1837 to honour a bet made earlier that summer with the poet Franz Bernus who wrote the words. It was first published posthumously in 1873 as the first of the Vier Lieder op.120. 


LITERATURE

MWV pp.106 (source d) & 450 ('Sammelhandschriften' no.38 (source b))

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: G. Meyerbeer and M. Bruch. Collection of 6 autograph letters and two autograph musical manuscripts 1847-1918
description:
Giacomo Meyerbeer and Max Bruch


Collection of six autograph letters and two autograph musical manuscripts


Meyerbeer Giacomo. Fine autograph letter signed ("G. Meyerbeer") to Friedrich Roth enclosing a specimen of his musical hand (see following manuscript) 1 page 4to with an autograph envelope Berlin 3 May 1851[?]--Autograph album-leaf manuscript signed ("Giacomo Meyerbeer") comprising an 8-bar 'Andantino quasi Allegretto' in F for piano notated in brown ink on three two-stave systems 1 page cut down from a larger leaf (12.3 x 17cm) Vienna 17 March 1847 mounted on card small tear with paper loss to upper outer corner 


Bruch Max. Five autograph letters signed ("Max Bruch") to unnamed correspondents concerning performances of his music including his opera Odysseus and oratorio Gustav Adolf mentioning Simrock Joachim and his daughter Margarete and referring to English politics and other matters 25 pages various 8vo sizes Berlin and elsewhere 1874-1918 some paperclip stains--Autograph musical quotation signed ("Max Bruch") comprising 5 bars of the melody of "Ich wob dies Gewand mit Thranen am Tage" from the opera Odysseus notated in brown ink on a single hand-drawn stave 1 page 11.5 x 18cm Berlin-Friedenau 4 December 1894 central and horizontal folds

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: W.A. Mozart. Collection of early editions late C18th
description:
Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart


Collection of early editions


Die Zauberflote eine grosse Oper in zwey Aufzugen furs Clavier oder Pianoforte [vocal score] [RISM M 4792] Berlin and Amsterdam: J.J. Hummel [1792/1793] pages 1-8 41-64 plate number 842 lacking pages 9-40; bound together with 2 numbers ('Bey Mannern' and 'Alles fuhlt der Liebe Freuden') engraved by C.C. Menzel in Berlin


Suite d'Airs connus varies pour le Clavecin ou Piano-Forte...N.o 4 Unser dummer Poebel meynt [K.455] [RISM M 7060] Offenbach am Main: J. Andre [1793] 11 pages vignette title plate number 533


Suite d'Airs connus varies pour le Clavecin ou Piano-Forte...N.o 6 Salve tu Domine [K.398 (416e)] [RISM M 7046] Offenbach am Main: J. Andre [1792/1793] 7 pages vignette title plate number 535


bound together with: Kirmair Friedrich Joseph. [Six themes par Mozart...varies pour le fortepiano...II. partie [RISM K 672] Berlin: J.J. Hummel; Amsterdam: au grand magazin de musique 1795] 18 pages plate number 844 lacking title; Steibelt Daniel. Premier Pot-Pourri d'Airs connus Paris: Le Duc 13 pages plate number 456 [RISM S 5509]; and Weyse Christoph Ernst Friedrich. VI Allegri di bravura per il Piano-Forte...publicato dai maestri di Capella Schulz e Reichardt Berlin [1796] 29 pages plate number 9  


6 works in one volume folio (32.5 x 23.2cm) engraved music manuscript paper label to upper cover ("1 Aus der Zauberflote...4 VI Allegri di bravura del S.r Weisse") contemporary marbled boards some scuffing to covers staining to paper label; together with loose part of the 11th installment (pp.65-72) from the series Allerneueste Auswahl von Gesangen aus den vorzuglichsten Opern der deutschen Buhne published in Berlin by J.C.F. Rellstab (1792)


An attractive volume from the collection of the Berlin composer and teacher Ernst Rudorff (1840-1916) possibly deriving ultimately from the Nachlass of J.F. Reichardt a granddaughter of whom was Betty Pistor Rudorff's mother.


Sotheby's gratefully acknowledges the kind assistance of Dr. Rupert Ridgewell and Dr. Christopher J. Salmon with the identification of two editions in this lot.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
