auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: John Ruskin | Series of c.105 autograph letters signed to Henry Jowett
description:
John Ruskin


Series of c.100 autograph letters mostly signed with initials ("J.R." some signed in full some incomplete or with clipped signatures) to Henry Jowett


on printing and publishing sending manuscripts ("...I send you the end of Fors Clavigera! & very thankful to have been spared to end it in better hope than I began...") revised proofs corrections and with instructions over such issues as typography illustrations and cover design including frequent complaints ("...I am aghast at the time this chapter has been in your types...") relating to works including Fors Clavigera Praeterita ("...I mean to do Praeterita my own way...") Proserpina Deucalion lectures translations some later letters also acknowledging his declining health including c.3 letters written on his behalf by Joan Severn and four other letters various locations including Broadlands Brantwood Herne Hill Corpus Christi College Oxford c.137 pages chiefly 8vo 1876-88 in a green morocco gilt album stamped in gilt the majority of the letters mounted but c.35 letters loosely inserted spotting occasional staining some letters torn with loss or clipped upper hinge of album split


Henry Jowett was the manager of Messrs. Hazell Watson & Viney's printing works at Aylesbury. The company printed most of Ruskin's books during the period covered by these letters which show Ruskin's close attention to bibliographical details such as typeface and layout as well as to his own text. Although he could be critical of Jowett's work Ruskin's appreciation of the skill of a master printer is evident in these letters.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Ronald Searle | Illustration for Lemon Hart rum advertisement signed by the artist
description:
Ronald Searle 


Original illustration for Lemon Hart Rum advertisement


executed in gouache and pencil on artboard 497 x 376mm. adhesive strips at upper right-hand margin (where Lemon Hart Rum logo was previously affixed) adhesive residue at lower and upper margins (not affecting illustration)


Searle contributed to Lemon Hart Rum advertising campaigns for eleven years between 1955 and 1962.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: E.H. Shepard | Pencil drawing of Winnie-the-Pooh
description:
E.H. Shepard


Winnie-the-Pooh reaching his hand into a honey pot


A fine large oval pencil drawing of Winnie-the-Pooh Tigger and Piglet seated at the kitchen table 200 x 180mm. on paper watermarked 'Hylton Bank' previously mounted some creasing and browning a few very minor tissue repairs to verso


An enlarged and expanded version of the illustration "Tiggers don't like honey" which features in The House at Pooh Corner.


PROVENANCE


By descent from the family of E.V. Knox (1881-1971 editor of Punch) and Mary Shepard (1909-2000 daughter of E.H. Shepard and illustrator of P.L. Travers' Mary Poppins); sold Bonhams 4 November 2008 lot 316

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: A. Szyk--C. Roth | The Haggadah [1940] limited edition number 78 of 125 vellum copies signed by Szyk and Roth
description:
Arthur Szyk--Cecil Roth (editor)


The Haggadah Executed by Arthur Szyk Edited by Cecil Roth. London: Beaconsfield Press Limited [1940]


LIMITED EDITION NUMBER 78 OF 125 VELLUM COPIES SIGNED BY SZYK AND ROTH FOR SALE IN THE BRITISH EMPIRE folio (284 x 235 mm) printed on double-vellum sheets (two connected vellum leaves with the flesh sides facing inward) with Hebrew and English calligraphic text in variously coloured inks fourteen full-page and numerous smaller colour halftone reproductions of Szyk's original watercolour gouaches including embellished initials vignettes and border decorations original elaborately gilt blue crushed morocco by Sangorski and Sutcliffe covers tooled with image of a Hebrew prophet after Szyk spine gilt in seven compartments with crown motifs turn-ins gilt silk doublures printed with a monochromatic illustration of Moses supporting the Ten Commandments housed in original three-quarter morocco folding case some minor discoloration along edges of first and final folios (as usual)


This Haggadah represents the culmination of a thousand-year-old tradition of illuminated Hebrew manuscripts. Upon its publication The Szyk Haggadah was described by the Times Literary Supplement as a book worthy to be placed among the most beautiful of books that the hand of man has produced. Each individually illuminated text is an example of both extraordinary artistic accomplishment and of profound scholarship. There could be no more fitting subject than the Haggadah for this milestone collaboration between Arthur Szyk (1894-1951) the Polish refugee and internationally acclaimed illuminator and Cecil Roth (1899-1970) the preeminent British doyen of Jewish history who edited the text and appended a historical introduction.


Given the unfolding events in Nazi Europe the Haggadah became for Szyk a personal and political statement. Dedicating his Exodus narrative to King George VI (1895-1952) Szyk acknowledged the key role that England his temporary place of residence had to play in Jewish survival: "At the Feet of Your Most Gracious Majesty i [sic] humbly lay these works of my hands shewing forth the Afflictions of my People Israel. arthur szyk [sic] illuminator of Poland". Of his accomplishments Szyk wrote in French on the page opposite the title: "I am but a Jew praying in art and if I have worked if I have succeeded to some degree if I have been favourably accepted among the elite of society I owe it all to the teachings traditions and eternal virtues of my people".


PROVENANCE


Presented to Ralph C. Hazell by the Directors of Sun Engraving Ltd. March 22 1945: signed letter of presentation from Directors laid in; presented by Ralph C. Hazell to Sun Printers (formerly Sun Engraving Ltd.) 6 September 1950: explanatory letter in Hazell's hand also laid in

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Francis Thompson | A collection of autograph draft manuscripts of poems and translations
description:
Francis Thompson


A collection of autograph draft literaary manuscripts comprising:


i) Partial translation of Victor Hugo's Le Dernier Jour d'un condamne c.54 pages in two school exercise books (labelled "Dernier Jour" II and III) with a preface to the work (in French) and written from the reverse of the second notebook notes on Hugo's prose and earlier abandoned pencil drafts in prose and verse (chiefly overwritten with the Hugo translation) also with additional notes and passages relating to the translation on five additional leaves of paper altogether 82 pages plus blanks chiefly 4to


ii) Draft poems including an early draft of 'From the Night of Forebeing' here with the working title 'Song to Spring' (approx. 4 pages) and also part of 'Carmen Genesis' as well as unpublished poems and fragments in pencil 16 pages folio


edge mounted in a album in brown morocco backed marbled boards neat repairs at some edges and folds light staining


A HITHERTO UNKNOWN MANUSCRIPT BY FRANCIS THOMSON POET AND CATHOLIC MYSTIC. Thompson (1859-1907) was one of the most unusual and distinctive poetic talents of the late Victorian period. Described by G.K. Chesterton as "the greatest poetic energy since Browning" he remained outside the literary mainstream both because of his personal life - he struggled with opium addiction for many years and spent three years homeless on the streets of London - and the Catholic mysticism that was his chief subject. Thompson is best remembered for his much-anthologised poem "The Hound of Heaven" (1893) but he was the author of a considerable body of verse and prose. He was discovered by the publishers and editors Wilfrid and Alice Meynell in 1887 and the Meynells both nurtured his talent and provided personal support to Thompson for the rest of his life. Wilfrid Meynell published extensive further works posthumously but the extent to which he revised Thompson's work only became clear when the poems were freshly edited from the surviving manuscripts by B. Boardman for The Poems of Francis Thompson (2001). 

 

The draft manuscript poems found here date from the mid-1890s and were written when Thompson was living at the Franciscan friary at Pantasa Flintshire. They form part of a group of twelve mystical poems that were given the title 'Sight and Insight' when published in Thompson's New Poems (1897). The most important of these poems is the Paschal ode 'From the Night of Forebeing'. These are poems that draw on Thompson's deep study of ancient symbolism and mysticism that ranged far beyond the Roman Catholic mainstream as noted by Boardman in her entry on Thompson for the Oxford Dictionary of National Biography: "Most of the more notable poems are concerned with one or another aspect of the incarnation of supernatural life within the human and natural order. In 'From the Night of Forebeing' he reinterprets the Easter liturgy of the resurrection in terms of renewal in the natural world and within his own soul. 'Assumpta Maria' celebrates the bodily assumption of the Blessed Virgin into heaven as the ultimate effect of incarnation as he understands it. Furthermore he identifies the role of the Blessed Virgin as queen of heaven with the pagan goddesses who were her precursors."  

 

Also found here is a partial draft of a translation of Victor Hugo's haunting novella Le Dernier Jour d'un Condamne (1829). The story's depiction of mental anguish and a harsh uncaring society connect it closely to Thompson's concerns but his translation is believed to be unpublished.

 

Thompson owned nothing but his literary manuscripts at the time of his death in 1907 and these passed to Wilfrid Meynell (1852-1948. The bulk of Thompson's surviving papers are now preserved at Boston College. A smaller collection is at the Harris Library in Thompson's native Preston and some other papers are at Ushaw College Cambridge University Library and a few university libraries in the USA.


PROVENANCE


Francis Thompson; Wilfrid Meynell; given by the Meynell family to a scholar who was working on Francis Thompson in the years after World War II; thence by descent

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: J.R.R. Tolkien | The Lord of the Rings Trilogy London 1954-1955 3 volumes first edition rebound in calf
description:
J.R.R. Tolkien


The Lord of the Rings Trilogy. London: George Allen & Unwin Ltd 1954-1955 comprising: The Fellowship of the Ring. London: George Allen & Unwin Ltd. 1954; The Two Towers. London: George Allen & Unwin Ltd. 1954; The Return of the King. London: George Allen & Unwin Ltd. 1955


8vo FIRST EDITION FIRST IMPRESSION FIRST STATE 3 volumes half titles titles with list of titles in series on verso volume 3 page 49 with signature mark '4' and sagging text folding maps printed in black and red at end of each volume rebound in calf spines gilt with raised bands in 5 compartments red morocco labels small marginal tear to map in "The Return of the King" spine label slightly worn on volume 2


FIRST EDITIONS FIRST IMPRESSIONS of all three volumes of the greatest work of twentieth-century fantasy. While serving in the trenches in WWI Tolkien conceived of these tales set in a "secondary World" which developed over a period of forty years into an epic narrative based in Tolkien's constructed universe beginning with the publication of The Hobbit in 1937. In his essay "On Fairy-Stories" Tolkien elucidates his philosophy of writing fantasy arguing that fantasy worlds serve not only as "consolation" and "joy" for the reader but speak to a "reality or truth". Thus The Lord of the Rings has been read as an allegory for multiple good-versus-evil conflicts: post-World War I and the rise of Hitler; Christian myth; even the environment with the Dead Marshes reflecting Tolkien's despair over the desolation wreaked by military technology. The series has never been out of print.


PROVENANCE


Christopher Eaton Hart bookplates in each volume


LITERATURE


Hammond A5(a); West A20-22

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Leo Tolstoy Signed cabinet card photographic portrait Moscow c. 1886
description:
Lev Nikolaevich Tolstoy


Signed cabinet card photographic portrait ("Leo Tolstoy" in English) by Scherer Nabholz & Cie. [Moscow c. 1886]


a head and shoulders portrait of Tolstoy (142 x 100mm.) produced by Scherer Nabholz & Co mounted on a cabinet card with the date 1886 on verso (total size 165 x 109mm.)


A fine portrait of the writer in a traditional belted smock in unusually good condition.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Vollard | Sainte Monique Paris 1930 original drawings by Bonnard Paul Bonet binding
description:
Ambroise Vollard


Sainte Monique. Illustrations de Pierre Bonnard. Paris: Ambroise Vollard 1930


4to (318 x 240mm.) copy no. 9 from a total of 340 copies one of 25 copies on japon imperial half-title 29 lithographs 17 etched plates (14 unused 3 index guides) and 178 text illustrations by Pierre Bonnard


EDITION: one of 25 copies with an additional suite of the lithographs on velin d'arches initialled by the author and artist on limitation statement at the end an additional suite of the 14 unused etched plates and a further suite of 15 unused woodcut illustrations IN ADDITION THE FULL SUITE OF ORIGINAL DRAWINGS BY BONNARD FOR THE 29 LITHOGRAPHS


BINDING: FULL CRUSHED BURGUNDY MOROCCO BINDING SIGNED BY PAUL BONET covers with a Greek cross above angled concentric circles of white and burgundy morocco board liners of white crushed morocco with concentric burgundy and white morocco circles purple watered silk endleaves gilt edges in a suede-lined morocco-backed drop-back box WITH A SIGNED LETTER BY PAUL BONET about the commissioning of this binding dated 31 July 1931 stating that the work was done by the binder F. Giraldon and the gilder A. Jeanne mounted at the end of the volume original printed wrapper bound in small stains on third version of plates 13 (p.119) and 17 (p. 131) joints weak


AN EXCEPTIONAL COPY CONTAINING PIERRE BONNARD'S ORIGINAL DRAWINGS FOR THE 29 LITHOGRAPHS FROM THE GASTON LEVY COLLECTION IN A SOBER BONET BINDING.


Vollard's text had previously been published in 1927 and is considered to be a work of disguised autobiography rather than hagiography (it was banned by the Church on publication). Like St Augustine Vollard came from abroad to study in the metropolis (Paris rather than Milan) and also had a domineering female in his early life (though it is unclear if St Monica represents Vollard's own mother or his Aunt Noemie).


Bonnard and Vollard had collaborated on previous livres d'artiste the most famous (or notorious) of which was Verlaine's Paralellement (1900). Vollard paid Bonnard 46200 francs on 10 October 1930 for the drawings. On the verso of some of the Bonnard drawings are other sketches of his such as on plates 22 and 29. Plate 28 seems to have the incorrect drawing before the plates.


THE FINE BINDING BY PAUL BONET is a wonderfully restrained example of his designs. Bonet states in the accompanying letter "Le decor de cette relieure avait rester tres sobre tant comme motifi principal qui s'inspire la croix que comme couleurs". Francois Giraldon executed the binding and Andre Jeanne the gilding. Paul Bonet is today regarded as perhaps the most celebrated of hte French designer bookbinders. Originally a hat designer he took up binding professionally in 1924. His clean geometric and very modern designs display great artistic and technical skill.


PROVENANCE


Gaston Levy name stamped in gold on inside front cover; Francis Kettaneh (1897-1976) blue morocco gilt booklabel sale Paris 20 May 1980; armorial bookplate of three sickles surmounted by two swan's heads (of Van Syckle)


Gaston Levy (1893-1977) was a prominent art collector in Paris who had bought numerous works of Pierre Bonnard's from the dealer Ambroise Vollard.


LITERATURE


Bonet Carnet 170 ("bonne et sobre reliure")

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: F. Werfel Four autograph poems from 'Ein Totenpsalter' c. 1935 or later
description:
Werfel Franz


Autograph manuscript of four poems from the collection 'Ein Totenpsalter' DIVERGING IN PLACES FROM THE PUBLISHED TEXT


comprising the poems 'Mann und Selbstmorderin' 'Litanei von den Zimmern der Verstorbenen' 'Kleines verlassenes Kurtheater im Herbst' and 'Elegie an einen Jugendgenossen' a fair-copy manuscript written in black ink with autograph titles provided with pink-crayon borders WITH A FEW PROBABLY AUTOGRAPH CORRECTIONS AND ALTERATIONS IN INK PINK CRAYON AND PENCIL


...Ich offne ein altliches Buch

Da zerbrechen die Zeilen und knicken.

Rot funkelt des Zierglases Fluch

Und die Uhr hetzt mit stichelndem Ticken...


7 leaves 4to (28.3 x 22.5cm) written on rectos only gatherings strengthened on guards modern half vellum gilt lettering to upper cover ('Franz Werfel / Vier Gedichte') small tear to front free endpaper


Franz Werfel (1890-1845) was one of the founders of the expressionist movement in German literature. His eventful life included marriage to Gustav Mahler's widow Alma in 1929 and a dramatic escape from the Nazis to America in 1940. He is perhaps best known for his novel The Forty Days of Musa Dagh (1933) whose subject was the Armenian Genocide of 1915.


The four poems contained here come from the twenty-poem collection 'Ein Totenpsalter' published in the 1935 volume Schlafen und Erwachen. THE PRESENT AUTOGRAPH CONTAINS A NUMBER OF SIGNIFICANT TEXTUAL DIVERGENCES FROM THE PUBLISHED EDITION; one such divergence concerns for example the title of the last poem - 'Elegie an einen Jugendgefahrten' in the 1935 print.


A nearly complete manuscript of Schlafen und Erwachen from around the time of publication is held among the Mahler-Werfel Papers in the Kislak Center for Special Collections at the University of Pennsylvania. A typescript carbon of 'Ein Totenpsalter' is recorded among the collection of Werfel's papers in the Department of Special Collections UCLA Library.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Writers Collection of autograph letters signed C19th and C20th
description:
Writers


Collection of autograph letters signed including by


STEFAN ZWEIG (to Noel Charavay concerning La Fontaine 2 pages Salzburg December 1924) ROMAIN ROLLAND (2 one concerning a financial matter 4 pages Villeneuve and elsewhere 1914 and 1938 one line cut out) THOMAS MANN (about some lectures 1 page Los Angeles 29 September 1940) ISRAEL ZANGWILL (to the manager of the Pacific Review 2 pages London 19 July 1901): together with an autograph envelope by SIGMUND FREUD (addressed to Paul Federn postmarked 20 November 1932) and letters by Jacques Maritain (2) Edgar Quinet Rafael Schermann Hippolyte Taine and others


...Toutefois je sais que justement les fables de La Fontaine etaient l'objet favori d'un habile faussaire vers 1840-1850 et l'ecriture (que vous voyez bien dans le facsimile) me parait exacte mais un peu trop facile...

over 50 pages in all various sizes Salzburg Vienna Berlin Los Angeles and elsewhere nineteenth and twentieth centuries  


The prolific pre-war writer Stefan Zweig was one of the great twentieth-century collectors of literary and musical manuscripts: here he writes to the firm of Charavay the premiere address for autographs in Paris concerning an autograph by La Fontaine.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: W.B. Yeats | Celtic Twilight 1905 first Irish edition with letters by by Yeats inserted
provenance: Winifred M. Letts (1882-1972), poet, playwright, and novelist: ownership inscription
description:
W.B. Yeats


Two autograph letters signed to the poet playwright and novelist Winifred M. Letts


discussing her plays submitted to the Abbey Theatre giving extended thoughts on dramaturgy ("...A good play must have truth of atmosphere...") expressing his admiration of Balzac and also writing of "wonderfully beautiful" Lough Gill site of the Lake Isle of Innisfree ("...I once walked round Lough Gill & started as night fell trying to sleep in a wood & getting back to Sligo half dead for lack of sleep and fatigue at noon the next day. I remember the rabbits at sundown & a little after sunrise...") 7 pages 8vo 24 February and 25 March n.y. Nassau Hotel Dublin (one on Coole Park headed stationery) the final page of the second letter browned and with adhesive stain to margin[the letters laid in to]: Celtic Twilight. Dublin: Maunsel and Co. Ltd. 1905. First Irish edition 8vo author portrait frontispiece 235pp plus 4pp publisher's advertisements at end ephemera pasted in including postcard of Lough Gill Co. Sligo and newspaper clipping with photographic portrait of Lady Gregory publisher's green cloth spine lettered in gilt leaves uncut author portrait frontispiece detached upper hinge splitting extremities rubbed


"...take any life you know & express its reality as your own eyes have seen that reality..."


Winifred Letts (1882-1972) was a poet novelist and playwright who spent most of her adult life in Ireland. She wrote several one-act plays that were performed at the Abbey Theatre beginning with The Eyes of the Blind in 1907. In the first of these two letters Yeats explains why he had rejected a play she had submitted: "the dialogue is often very good but the plot is too far from life". In a long and encouraging postscript he gives her detailed advice on dramaturgy: "If you would found your work as much as possible on real life you would find it is at once easier to write and more powerful in structure". She should avoid the influence of "authors who keep on the surface"; "I am myself" Yeats continues "going to school to Balzac & have in the last few months read some thirty of his forty volumes" and has found much of relevance to Ireland in Balzac's "description of provincial life". 


Letts seems to have replied to Yeats with fresh ideas for plays and the second letter appears to be Yeats's response. He encourages her to continue to develop at least two ideas for plays repeats his injunction that a play must contain truth - "it is a good subject if you can keep it real" - and also encourages her towards nationalist themes: "The other subject that of the vicarage is good I think if you can make the struggle between father and daughter subject to obvious Irish conditions."

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Guillaume Apollinaire | Le Poete Assassine Paris 1916 first edition inscribed by the author
description:
Guillaume Apollinaire


Le Poete Assassine. Paris: Bibliotheque des Curieux 1916


FIRST EDITION INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR to Andre Tudesq 8vo portrait of Apollinaire by Andre Rouveyre later maroon half-morocco over marbled boards binding slightly rubbed


Apollinaire served as an infantry officer in the French Army during the war was wounded in the head in 1916 and died aged 38 of Spanish flu on 9 November 1918 two days before the Armistice. Although mostly prose the volume features a small number of poems concerning WW1.


This copy was inscribed to the writer Andre Tudesq who jointly founded the review Les soirees de Paris with Apollinaire.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Guillaume Apollinaire | Calligrammes Paris 1918 first edition inscribed by the author to Michel Georges-Michel
description:
Guillaume Apollinaire 


Calligrammes. Poemes de la paix et de la guerre (1913-1916). Paris: Mercure de France 1918


FIRST EDITION INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR TO MICHEL GEORGES-MICHEL 8vo wood-engraved frontispiece portrait by R. Jaudon after Picasso calligrammatic poem to Georges-Michel on pasted-in slip in prelims publisher's wrappers in collector's marbled slipcase browning at extremities


Inscribed by the author with a calligrammatic poem to his friend the painter novelist and literary journalist Michel Georges-Michel (1883-1985) on a pasted-in slip:


"A M. Michel Georges-Michel pour le remercier l'un echo aimable paru dans Paris-Midi. Calligramme en forme de morceau de sucre. 

Tel un contrefilet

Ton bel entrefilet 

Michel je l'apprecie

Et je te remercie.

Guillaume Apollinaire 28 Juin 1918"


Georges-Michel a prolific author and critic who organised the first exhibition of Picasso in Rome in 1917 had written about the book in the magazine 'Paris-Midi'. Apollinaire's manuscript inscription tells us that the poem to Georges-Michel has been composed in the visual form of a sugar cube hence continuing the radical experiments in typography found within the printed text.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Louis Aragon | Feu de Joie Paris 1920 first edition copy number 1 of 50 inscribed by the author to Marius Andre
description:
Louis Aragon


Feu de Joie. Paris: Au Sans Pareil 1920


FIRST EDITION COPY NUMBER 1 OF 50 (marked "000" for the press) 12mo original wrappers leaves toned


The Dadaist author's first book inscribed to the vocally anti-Dadaist poet and critic Marius Andre ("A Marius Andre | Louis Aragon"). Whether the inscription was intended to have been in homage or as a provocation is unclear but a few years later Andre described Dadaism as "une stupide mystification". Aragon served in the French army during the war and was then at the forefront of the Dadaist and Surrealist movements alongside Andre Breton and Philippe Soupault.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Laurence Binyon | The Winnowing Fan London 1914 first edition inscribed by the author
description:
Laurence Binyon


The Winnowing Fan: Poems on the Great War. London: Elkin Mathews 1914


FIRST EDITION INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo original wrappers collector's folding case residue from old label to half-title wrappers slightly discoloured


Inscribed by the author to a Mrs. Tate--the identity of whom remains obscure. Born in 1869 Binyon was considered too old for military service. This collection includes the first appearance of "For the Fallen" perhaps the most enduring poem to emerge from WW1: "They shall grow not old as we that are left grow old: | Age shall not weary them nor the years condemn. | At the going down of the sun and in the morning | We will remember them." A very good copy in wrappers.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Edmund Blunden | Poems Translated from the French... Sussex 1914 first edition inscribed by the author
description:
Edmund Blunden


Poems translated from the French. Horsham Sussex: privately printed for the author by Price & Company 1914


FIRST EDITION ONE OF 100 COPIES INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo original wrappers postcard from the author to dedicatee of inscription laid in staples rusting


Blunden's rare first book this copy inscribed 50 years after publication by the author: "This copy of a first attempt - and the last of its kind by me - rescued by Edward Finneron must have my thanks and blessings to him while we talk . . . once more Edward Blunden 8 July 1964." The identity of the recipient is unknown but a medic of that name served in the Black Watch during WW1. A friendly postcard from the author to Finneron is laid-in. There have been no inscribed copies at auction for over 30 years.


LITERATURE


Kirkpatrick A2

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Edmund Blunden (Robert Graves) | The Waggoner and Other Poems London 1920 first edition inscribed by the author
description:
Edmund Blunden (Robert Graves)


The Waggoner and Other Poems. London: Sidgwick & Jackson 1920


FIRST EDITION INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo half-title original blue cloth lacking dust-jacket together with two manuscript versions of the poem "On Turning a Stone" window-mounted on card all housed in dark blue buckram fitted case endleaves toned spine sunned


A fine copy inscribed by the author to his friend and fellow WW1 poet: "Alan Porter with the affectionate good wishes of his friend Edmund Blunden Nov 13 1920 'E wur only a labourin man the likes of me' Helpstone Methusaleh". (The recipient was the author of The Signature of Pain London 1930). Together with two manuscript versions of the poem "On Turning a Stone" which appears on page 18 of the book and which is dedicated in print to this book's recipient Alan Porter. These manuscript texts reveal the collaboration between Blunden and Graves that lies behind the poem. An earlier draft of the poem entitled "Turning the Stone" is in Blunden's hand in black ink and extensively revised in pencil by Robert Graves. The second version is in pencil entirely written and signed by Graves and entitled "On Turning the Stone". It is the latter version that is printed except for one word change which was suggested by Porter (as is noted by Graves on the verso of Blunden's draft). Blunden served as an officer during the war from 1915 to 1917 and was gassed but never wounded.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Vera Brittain | Testament of Youth London 1933 first edition inscribed by the author ephemera laid in
description:
Vera Brittain


Testament of Youth. London: Gollancz 1933


FIRST EDITION INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo original wrappers original dust-jacket and (very scarce) wraparound band related ephemera laid in


Inscribed by the author to Dr. Ernest S. du Bray and dated 13 February 1940. Laid-in are a 1933 review of the book a receipt for du Bray's original purchase of the book in 1934 from a London dealer (Frank Hollings) plus a newspaper clipping and a leaflet regarding Vera Brittain's visit to San Francisco in mid-February 1940 when du Bray presumably asked her to inscribe the book. Brittain served as a Voluntary Aid Detachment nurse; Du Bray served in Base Hospital 18. An excellent copy in near-fine dust-jacket with the original wraparound band and very scarce thus still more in an inscribed state (there have been no such copies at auction since at least 1974).

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Rupert Brooke | 1914 and Other Poems New York 1915 first American edition
description:
Rupert Brooke 


1914 and Other Poems. New York: Doubleday Page & Company 1915


FIRST AMERICAN EDITION one of 87 copies of unbound sheets printed by Doubleday to secure American copyright first and final gatherings in paper self-wrappers "1914-POEMS | STOCK" stamped in ink to upper wrapper housed in blue quarter-morocco collector's case slight creasing and browning case slightly rubbed at extremities


Doubleday printed these sheets for copyright purposes but were unable to secure publishing rights so their proposed edition failed to appear. The sequence of events is explained in John Schroder's catalogue of his Rupert Brooke collection which included papers from Brooke's English publisher Sidgwick & Jackson:


"This Copyright Edition was printed at the request of Sidgwick & Jackson who wrote to Doubleday Page & Company on 9th June 1915 instructing them to secure American copyright. This was done promptly and a copy received by the Library of Congress on 15th July 1915. [...] [Christopher] Morley [...] was working for Doubleday and had written to Mrs Brooke enquiring about American rights. Mrs Brooke passed the request to [Eddie] Marsh who forwarded it to Frank Sidgwick [...] Unfortunately Sidgwick & Jackson could not agree terms with Doubleday and eventually both Poems (1911) and 1914 and Other Poems were accepted by the John Lane Company in July 1915."

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Edward Carpenter | Autograph manuscript signed: "Ballad of the Bodkin & the Muskett" [n.d.] plus typescript and photograph
description:
Edward Carpenter--Henry Salt


Autograph manuscript signed typescript and photograph comprising:


i. "The Ballad of the Bodkin & the Muskett" autograph manuscript signed 4 pages 4to (227 x 175mm.) no place [Manchester] undated in black ink on heavy paper browning at extremities rust stain from old staple at upper margin

ii. Typescript of "Henry Salt on Edward Carpenter. Revelations in Personal Letters" essay for "The New Leader" magazine dated 1 July 1932 a few manuscript corrections to typos p.1 marked "E.C." in upper right-hand margin 4 pages 4to creased at margins previously folded

iii. Photograph of Edward Carpenter on card 191 x 128mm. facsimile signature to lower margin


Autograph manuscript copy of one of the "Three Ballads" which were privately printed for the author in Manchester in 1917 (see next lot). Written in black ink on heavy paper this poem is uncorrected and is presumably either a final draft or a fair copy. Carpenter wrote the poem as a response to E. D. Morel's arrest and imprisonment in August/September 1917 under the Defence of the Realm Act for sending two publications to the pacifist and Nobel Literature Prize laureate Romain Rolland. Carpenter sent a copy of the poem to Sassoon. No magazine (not even left-leaning ones) would publish the poem so Carpenter self-published it in Three Ballads. E.D. Morel was a politician a pacifist in WW1 and a colleague and supporter of Roger Casement in his campaign against slavery in The Congo Free State.


Also included is a photograph of Carpenter and the typescript of an affectionate essay penned by Henry Salt after Carpenter's death for the American political and cultural magazine "The New Leader". Salt read Carpenter's essays about Thoreau and the simplification of life when at Eton as is recalled in the essay and he later became friends with the reformer and social critic moving close to Carpenter's home at Millthorpe for seven years.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Edward Carpenter | Three Ballads Manchester 1917 first edition inscribed by the author
description:
Edward Carpenter


Three Ballads. Manchester: privately printed for the author 1917


FIRST EDITION INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR small 8vo original wrappers a fine copy


Inscribed by the author: "to A. T. Bartholomew Xmas 1917." Theo Bartholomew was the Cambridge University librarian who introduced Sassoon to his first lover Gabriel Aitken and was involved in the printing of Sassoon's post-war poetry collections Picture Show and Recreations. One of the ballads in this collection is "Lieutenant Tattoon MC" a parody of Sassoon's treatment at Craiglockhart Hospital. Edward Carpenter was the recipient of one of the carbon copies of "A Soldier's Declaration" that Sassoon sent to his commanding officer and which was subsequently read out in the House of Commons resulting in Sassoon's being sent to Craiglockhart. There appear to have been no other inscribed copies offered for sale for at least 15 years.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: G.K. Chesterton | The Ballad of St. Barbara London 1922 first edition inscribed by the author to his mother
description:
G.K. Chesterton


The Ballad of St. Barbara. London: Cecil Palmer 1922


FIRST EDITION INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR: "To my mother with love GKC Nov 18 1922" 8vo original wrappers in the scarce dust-jacket slight creasing and browning to front free endpaper minor tears at spine ends of dust-jacket


Chesterton's mother--nee Marie Louise Grosjean--although born in Kensington was of Swiss and Scottish descent in a family of Wesleyan Methodist persuasion. Saint Barbara is the patron saint of gunners and those in danger of sudden death. Weighing nearly 290lbs Chesterton was unfit for army service. (When once asked why he was not "out at the front" he replied: "Madam if you go round to the side you will see that I am.") Nonetheless he was an enthusiastic recruit to the War Propaganda Bureau.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Agatha Christie | The Road of Dreams London 1925 first edition
description:
Agatha Christie


The Road of Dreams. London: Geoffrey Bles 1925


First (sole) edition 8vo original boards dust-jacket prelims toned light spotting throughout dust-jacket slightly chipped at extremities


Published at the author's expense this collection includes two World War I poems (e.g. p.92: "that valiant passing Which some call Death others name Release").


Not in Catherine Reilly's bibliography of WW1 poetry although 14 copies are located on OCLC. A very good copy of a rare book in the dust-jacket.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Jean Cocteau | Poesies 1917-1920 Paris 1920 first edition inscribed by the author
description:
Jean Cocteau


Poesies 1917-1920. Paris: Editions de La Sirene 1920


FIRST EDITION ONE OF 32 NUMBERED COPIES ON HAND-MADE PAPER INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo original wrappers leaves uncut a very good copy


One of 32 copies on hand-made paper of a total edition of 1032. Inscribed by the author on half-title to Viscount Carlow with a drawing of a face. Cocteau served as a Red Cross ambulance driver during the war.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Arthur Conan Doyle | The Poems of Arthur Conan Doyle: Collected Edition London 1922 first edition signed
description:
Arthur Conan Doyle


The Poems of Arthur Conan Doyle: Collected Edition. London: John Murray 1922


FIRST EDITION SIGNED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo original cloth lacking dust-jacket endleaves toned


Signed by the author: "from Arthur Conan Doyle Xmas 1922". A "Mrs. English" has appended her name.


Doyle attempted to enlist in the army following the outbreak of war with Germany: "I am fifty-five but I am very strong and hardy and can make my voice audible at great distances which is useful at drill." His offer to serve was declined but his lobbying of the War Office was efficacious in the introduction of life-jackets for sailors and body-armour for soldiers.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Harry Crosby | Red Skeletons Paris 1927 first edition inscribed by the author
description:
Harry Crosby


Red Skeletons. Paris: Editions Narcisse 1927


FIRST EDITION number 333 of 345 copies on verge Hollande Van Gelder Zonen (of a total edition of 370) INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 4to 9 full-page colour lithographs by Alastair original wrappers wrappers slightly soiled


Inscribed by the author to John de Bosschere the Belgian novelist and illustrator of works by Wilde Baudelaire and others. Crosby later suppressed the book buying the unsold copies 84 in total and burning them (with the exception of four copies which he blasted to bits with a pistol). The author volunteered for the American Ambulance Service in 1917--aged 19--and was one of the youngest Americans to be awarded the Croix de Guerre.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: E.E. Cummings | The Enormous Room New York 1922 first edition first state inscribed by the author
description:
E.E. Cummings


The Enormous Room. New York: Boni and Liveright [1922]


FIRST EDITION FIRST ISSUE ("Shit!" present on final line of p. 219) INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo original boards dust-jacket dust-jacket split at folds and missing substantial chip on lower right corner of upper panel


Cummings's first book a novel based on his internment by the French during WW1. Inscribed by the author to Michael and Claire--unidentified recipients--and rare thus. Cummings' signature is in a different ink from the inscription but both are in his hand. Cummings volunteered for the Norton-Harjes Ambulance Corps and went to France in 1917. His letters home expressing anti-war sentiments were intercepted by censors and he was interned for suspected espionage being held (with many others) in "an enormous room".

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: E.E. Cummings | Tulips and Chimneys New York 1923 first edition first printing inscribed by the author
description:
E.E. Cummings


Tulips and Chimneys. New York: Thomas Seltzer 1923


FIRST EDITION FIRST PRINTING INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo original boards lacking dust-jacket extremities slightly bumped


First edition first printing of the author's first collection of poetry inscribed by him: "For [Edward] Titus with the compliments of Cummings". The recipient was the American proprietor of the Black Manikin Press in Paris (a press whose published authors included D.H. Lawrence and Hart Crane). Titus later became editor of This Quarter to which Cummings contributed. There have only been three inscribed copies at auction since 1985. A very good copy lacking the rare dust-jacket.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Nancy Cunard | Parallax London 1925 first edition inscribed by the author
description:
Nancy Cunard


Parallax. London: Hogarth Press 1925


FIRST EDITION INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo original boards light browning to edges of boards extremities slightly rubbed else an excellent copy


One of about 420 copies printed (Woolmer). Inscribed by the author: "for Timmy from Nancy Cunard 1931". The recipient--Dorothy "Timothy" Hanley--was the wife of James Hanley himself the author of the harrowing novella The German Prisoner. Cunard was the publisher of The Hours Press in Paris and a frequent writer on the subject of war.


LITERATURE


Woolmer 57

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: W.H. Davies | Forty New Poems London 1918 first edition inscribed by the author
description:
W[illiam] H[enry] Davies


Forty New Poems. London: A.C. Fifield 1918


FIRST EDITION INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo original boards lacking dust-jacket prelims slightly toned spine slightly sunned


Inscribed by the author to the artist Augustus John in October 1918. John would later provide the illustrations to Davies's Collected Poems; Second Series (1923) and Selected Poems (1928). Davies's The Autobiography of a Super-Tramp was borne of personal experience. He lost a leg in 1899 while jumping a train in Ontario and he lived as a tramp in Britain and the USA for many years before meeting success as a writer. The National Portrait Gallery has an Augustus John portrait of Davies dated 1918.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Georgia Douglas Johnson | Bronze Boston 1922 first edition inscribed by the author
description:
Georgia Douglas Johnson


Bronze. Boston: B.J. Brimmer 1922


FIRST EDITION INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR small 8vo original cloth lacking dust-jacket (but with rear flap and rear panel laid in) a very good copy 


First edition of the second collection of poems by this important figure in the Harlem Renaissance--one of the first African-American female playwrights. Inscribed by the author: "Dec. 27 - '22. To Mr. Roscoe C. Simmons shall we not dedicate this page to this day which we record happy & signal. Read page 15 from The Heart of a Woman & thank every God for your exclusion. Sincerely Georgia Douglas Johnson." The recipient was the African-American orator journalist and politician active from the 1920s to the '50s. With an introduction by W.E.B. Du Bois. Rare--there have only been two copies at auction since 1974.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: E.M. Forster | Abinger Harvest London 1945 first edition inscribed by the author
description:
E.M. Forster


Abinger Harvest. London: Arnold 1945


FIRST EDITION INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo original boards supplied dust-jacket prelims slightly dampstained at lower margin


Inscribed by the author to the Shiffolds "with love from Morgan". The identity of the recipients remains obscure but given the warmth of the inscription they were presumably well known to Forster. Contains "a Flood in the Office" in Part IV (which was expurgated from later editions). Includes a WW1 poem critical of Churchill and the war in general on p.31. Not in Reilly's bibliography of WW1 poetry.


PROVENANCE


Birkbeck College bookplate

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Robert Frost | Mountain Interval New York 1916 first edition inscribed by the author to Wilfrid Wilson Gibson
literature: Crane A4
description:
Robert Frost


Mountain Interval. New York: Henry Holt 1916


FIRST EDITION INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR TO WILFRID GIBSON 8vo half-title original cloth lacking dust-jacket slight spotting and marginal dampstaining (not affecting text)


First edition of the author's first collection published in the USA inscribed by him: "Wilfrid [Wilson Gibson] from Robert in Philadelphia (whatever that may mean) Jan 1917". Gibson Frost's close friend and fellow "Dymock Poet" was a central figure of the Georgian Poets. He was Rupert Brooke's literary executor the person who first invited Frost to Dymock and was himself the author of several volumes of war poetry. Frost wrote to an American friend in March 1914: "I have no friend here like Wilfrid Gibson".


LITERATURE


Crane A4

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Robert Frost | New Hampshire New York 1923 first edition inscribed by the author to Marsden Hartley
literature: Crane A9
description:
Robert Frost


New Hampshire. New York: Henry Holt 1923


FIRST EDITION INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR TO MARSDEN HARTLEY 8vo woodcut illustrations by J.J. Lankes original boards lacking dust-jacket slight marginal dampstaining to endleaves binding slightly rubbed a very good copy


An excellent association copy linking two of New England's favourite artistic sons inscribed by the author with a riff on the title and two lines of text from one of the poems in the collection:


"Some may know what they seek in school and church

And why they seek it there; for what I seek - we'll see A Star in a Stone-Boat

Robert Frost

For the Author of Gulls of Gloucester".


The recipient was the celebrated Maine modernist artist Marsden Hartley who was less well-known for his poems one of which is "Gulls of Gloucester" published in his 1923 collection "Twenty-Five Poems". This collection includes the poem "To ET" for Frost's great friend (and fellow "Dymock poet") Edward Thomas who was killed in World War One and "Not to Keep" another war poem. Intriguingly the village of Dymock is in Gloucestershire (England) though Hartley's Gloucester is the port in Massachusetts. Hartley is reputed to have supported Germany during WW1 having had a relationship with a German officer who was killed in combat.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Robert Frost | Mountain Interval New York 1916 first edition inscribed by the author and his wife
description:
Robert Frost


Mountain Interval. New York: Henry Holt 1916


FIRST EDITION INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR AND HIS WIFE 8vo annotations and corrections in Frost's hand original cloth dust-jacket collector's quarter morocco box


Inscribed by the author and his wife: "Marie A. Hodge from Elinor and Robert Frost". There are letters from Hodge to Frost in the collection of his papers at Dartmouth College. Frost has made two holograph corrections to the printing errors in the text on pp. 88 and 93--the first with the offending line crossed-through and the correct text inserted in the margin. A fine copy in dust-jacket. 


LITERATURE


Crane A4

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Robert Frost | Selected Poems New York 1923 first edition inscribed by the author
description:
Robert Frost


Selected Poems. New York: Henry Holt 1923


FIRST EDITION ONE OF 1025 COPIES INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo publisher's boards dust-jacket green quarter morocco case dust-jacket very slightly frayed at one corner


Inscribed by the author on front free endpaper: "For Llewellyn Jones from his friend Robert Frost". The recipient was editor of the Chicago Literary Times and indeed a friend of Frost--especially so one would imagine after he and Louis Untermeyer devoted an entire issue of the magazine to Frost's work providing a major boost for his early career. Includes "Range-Finding" which is a commentary on the war. The dedicatee of the book is Helen Thomas Edward's wife. Frost wanted to withdraw the dedication after reading her memoirs As it Was (1926) and World without End (1931) about her marriage. Edward Thomas was the inspiration for Frost's celebrated poem "The Road Not Taken." An excellent copy in dust-jacket.


LITERATURE


Clymer & Charles p. 34

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Robert Frost | West Running Brook New York 1928 first edition inscribed by the author
description:
Robert Frost


West Running Brook. New York: Henry Holt 1928


FIRST EDITION INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo woodcuts by J.J. Lankes original cloth dust-jacket an excellent copy


Inscribed by the author: "But this we know the obstacle that checked | And tripped the body shot the spirit on | Further than target ever showed or shone. Robert Frost to Stow Lovejoy 1935." The quotation is from "A Soldier"--the sole WW1 poem in the collection. One of 8400 copies of the first issue printed without the "first edition" statement and with the misprint "roams" for "romps" in the last line of p.44. An excellent copy in dust-jacket.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Federico Garcia Lorca | Poemo del cante Jondo Madrid 1931 first edition inscribed by the author
description:
Federico Garcia Lorca


Poema del cante Jondo. Madrid and Buenos Aires: Ediciones Ulises 1931


FIRST EDITION INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo half-title later blue morocco original wrappers bound in slight foxing and soiling original upper wrapper re-attached with tissue repair


Inscribed by the author in his trademark red crayon on a preliminary blank: "A mi querido Jorge con un abrazo fraternal de Federico 1921-1931 | Madrid." The recipient was Lorca's friend the Colombian writer Jorge Zalamea--the dedicatee of Section Three of the book--making this a quasi-dedication copy. There have only been two inscribed copies at auction since 1974.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Wilfrid Wilson Gibson | Neighbours London 1920 first edition inscribed by the author to Thomas Hardy
description:
Wilfrid Wilson Gibson


Neighbours. London: Macmillan 1920


FIRST EDITION INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR TO THOMAS HARDY 8vo original boards dust-jacket dust-jacket very slightly frayed at spine ends an excellent copy


Inscribed by the author: "Thomas Hardy Esq from Wilfred Wilson Gibson 1920" and with the recipient's bookplate. One of the pre-war "Dymock poets" (alongside Robert Frost Edward Thomas John Drinkwater and Rupert Brooke) Gibson had poor eyesight but served as a private in clerical roles during the war.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Robert Graves--Siegfried Sassoon | An unimprovable pair of association copies
description:
Robert Graves--Siegfried Sassoon


An unimprovable pair of WW1 poetry association copies comprising:


i. Robert Graves. Over the Brazier. London: Poetry Bookshop 1916. First edition first impression INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR TO SIEGFRIED SASSOON ("SS from RG May 6 1916" on inside of front wrapper) 8vo original wrappers bookplate of Sassoon light spotting


ii. Siegfried Sassoon. The Old Huntsman. London: Heinemann 1917. First edition first impression INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR TO ROBERT GRAVES ("R.G. from S.S. May 1917") 8vo bookplate of Graves original boards lacking dust-jacket binding somewhat soiled 


GRAVES' AND SASSOON'S FIRST COLLECTIONS OF WAR POETRY EACH RECIPROCALLY INSCRIBED. This pair of copies stands as a powerful emblem of the longstanding if at times complex friendship between Sassoon and Graves. As Graves recounts in his 1929 wartime autobiography (for which see lot 341) the two poets more or less immediately bonded over their literary interests whilst serving together in France in the Royal Welch Fusiliers:


"At this point I was getting my first book of poems Over the Brazier ready for the press; I had one or two drafts in my pocket-book and showed them to Siegfried. He told me they were too realistic and that war should not be written about in a realistic way. In return he showed me some of his own poems. One of them began: 'Return to greet me colours that were my joy | Not in the woeful crimson of men slain...' [the opening lines of "To Victory" later printed in The Old Huntsman] This was before Siegfried had been in the trenches. I told him in my old-soldier manner that he would soon change his style." (Good-bye to All That p. 224).


Sassoon's copy of Over the Brazier evidently stayed in his possession all his life as it contains the S.S. monogram label affixed to all copies featured in the posthumous auction of his books by Christie's in 1975. Graves' copy of The Old Huntsman however appears to have been gifted at some point to an Oxford acquaintance Godfrey Elton. Now rightly united these two copies represent the greatest imaginable pair of WW1 poetry books.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Robert Graves | Goliath and David London [1916] first edition inscribed by the author
description:
Robert Graves


Goliath and David. London: privately printed for the author at the Chiswick Press [1916]


FIRST EDITION ONE OF 20O COPIES INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo original wrappers wrappers somewhat worn and split along backstrip


First edition of Graves' second publication--one of 200 copies. Inscribed by the author to a recipient understood to be one of the nurses who tended to his war wounds after he was severely injured at the front in 1916: "To Sister Bassett in gratitude Robert Graves 1919". During the Battle of the Somme in 1916 Graves had been "so badly wounded in the lung that he was left for dead and was later able to read his own obituary in the Times" (ODNB). When he was found to be still alive he was sent first to hospital in Rouen then to Queen Alexandra's Hospital in London. During and after the time of publication of Goliath and David which was printed in late 1916 and distributed in early 1917 Graves was therefore wracked with ill health both physically and mentally recuperating at Somerville College Oxford then at Harlech his family's Welsh holiday home. Perhaps as a consequence of his weakened state presentation copies from Graves himself are very rare.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Robert Graves | Over the Brazier London 1916 first edition signed by the author
description:
Robert Graves


Over the Brazier. London: Poetry Bookshop 1916


FIRST EDITION SIGNED BY THE AUTHOR IN 1916 AND LATER INSCRIBED 8vo original wrappers some spotting and marginal dampstaining wear to wrappers


First edition of his first book. Signed by the author to the title-page: "Graves 1916" (the year of publication). Additionally inscribed: "Garech (de Brun) afectionamente Robert Graves Mallorca" on verso of the title-page. The recipient was a book collector and friend of Graves (who lived on Mallorca from 1946 until the age of 90 in 1985). This may be Graves's own copy which he gifted late in his life when de Brun visited him on Mallorca. Over the Brazier was published on May 1 1916 when Graves was serving as a subaltern in the Royal Welch Fusiliers in France. There was a second impression in 1917 and a second edition in 1920. Graves's youth and obscurity presumably accounts for the scarcity of inscribed copies.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Robert Graves | Fairies and Fusiliers London 1917 first edition inscribed by the author
description:
Robert Graves


Fairies and Fusiliers. London: Heinemann 1917


FIRST EDITION INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR on the front free endpaper additional dedication inscription to the same recipient on p. 63 8vo original cloth (supplied) dust-jacket very light spottingtape residue to verso of half-title binding slightly soiled with tape residue to lower board


Inscribed by the author to the comrade who saved his life in the trenches: "Lieutenant O.M. Roberts 2nd R.W. Fus from Robert Graves. | If it hadn't been for you butty [?] this book would be unwritten. See page 63". 


Above the title of the lyric on page 63 ("Escape") Graves has hand-written: "Dedicated to O.M. Roberts 2nd R W Fus in grateful memory of July 20 1916". The poem itself dramatises Graves' time at death's door as a mock heroic narrative whereby the poet fends off the hell hound Cerberus in order to make his successful escape from the underworld. But it also registers the poet's frustration at being unable to recall an accurate account of what actually happened. Passing through Lethe he feels "the vapours of forgetfulness | Float in [his] nostrils". This Lethe is doubly troubling: a place of amnesia as in the classical tradition but also a place where through the act of writing the raw sensory horror of a gas attack in the trenches seeps back into the poet's consciousness thus failing to offer the mental respite of truly forgetting. 


Roberts' role in saving Graves' life is omitted from the poem and as well as from the 1929 autobiography of Graves' wartime experiences Good-bye to All That (see lot 341). The present copy of Fairies and Fusiliers was likely inscribed at a similar time to Owen Roberts' personal copy of Good-bye to All That (now held at the National Library of Wales). Graves recalled the circumstances in a 1966 interview with Roger Ebert:


"Well last month while I was in the hospital to be cut open in came a bloke to visit by the name of Owen Roberts. [...] So here he came into the hospital ward 50 years later a chipper old bloke 74 years old retired as a civil servant. Roberts was banged up pretty bad in the war too but he'd nevertheless managed to father two children and I've a pretty satisfactory life. It all adds up to something I suppose. I was glad to set the record straight. I signed his copy of Good-bye to All That I giving him full credit for saving my life. [...] It was the least I could do you know."


In the interview with Ebert Graves admits that he had forgotten Roberts' role in events by the time he got round to writing his autobiography and that their meeting decades later jogged his memory. This adds a further dimension of poignance to the poet's manuscript dedication to "Escape". Thus Graves not only acknowledges Roberts' importance in saving his life back in 1916 but also intimates that their subsequent meeting in the mid-1960s allowed him to fill in the blanks from a troublingly incomplete recollection of wartime events thus finally offering him an escape route from past trauma.


LITERATURE


Roger Ebert "Good-bye to All That" interview originally published 4 December 1966: www.rogerebert.com/features/good-bye-to-all-that

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Robert Graves | Treasure Box London [1919] first (sole) edition inscribed by the author to Ivor Gurney
description:
Robert Graves


Treasure Box. London: Chiswick Press [1919]


FIRST (SOLE) EDITION ONE OF 200 COPIES INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR TO IVOR GURNEY 4to original wrappers backstrip split


This book is inscribed by the author to Ivor Gurney fellow WW1 poet and composer who set several of Graves's poems to music. The collection--Graves's first book of poetry after demobilization--has no specific WW1 poems but Graves stated in the preface to "Whipperginny" that the poems in this book were an "Arcadia of amatory fancy as a reaction to war neurosis". A very good copy in wrappers.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Robert Graves | Country Sentiment London 1920 first edition inscribed to Sassoon and Owen's psychologist
description:
Robert Graves


Country Sentiment. London: Martin Secker 1920


FIRST EDITION INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR TO DR W.H.R. RIVERS 8vo rebound in chagrin leather similar to the design and colour of the original board some toning and dampstaining to endleaves


Inscribed by the author to his friend and mentor the psychologist who treated Siegfried Sassoon and Wilfred Owen for shell-shock at Craiglockhart: "W.H.R. Rivers from Robert Graves 1921". Although never a patient of Rivers himself Graves described him to Sassoon as one of his "inner circle" of friends and often sought his opinion on the psychology of poetry (co-dedicating his On English Poetry to him and to T.E. Lawrence in 1922). Upon Rivers's unexpected death later that same year Graves described him as "the finest scientist in Britain." The last inscribed copy of this title to appear at auction was over a quarter of a century ago. A very good copy.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Robert Graves | Country Sentiment New York 1920 first American edition inscribed by the author
description:
Robert Graves


Country Sentiment. New York: Alfred Knopf 1920


FIRST AMERICAN EDITION INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo original boards lacking dust-jacket worn


Inscribed by the author to an unidentified recipient: "to Miss I. B. O'Malley with gratitude 1920". There have been no inscribed copies of the first American edition at auction since at least 1974. 


For the first English edition of this work inscribed to Sassoon and Owen's psychologist see previous lot.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Robert Graves | Welchman's Hose London 1925 first edition inscribed by the author
description:
Robert Graves


Welchman's Hose. London: Fleuron 1925


FIRST EDITION INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo engravings by Paul Nash original cloth lacking plain tissue dust-jacket endleaves slightly dampstained binding slightly bowed


Warmly inscribed by the author to an unidentified recipient: "To Mary with love from Rob 1925". Graves rarely uses the diminutive form of his Christian name in inscriptions suggesting that the recipient was a close friend or family member (possibly his older half-sister of that name since another occasion he signed as "Rob" was when inscribing a different title to another sister Rosaleen-Louise). A very good copy.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Robert Graves | Good-bye to All That London 1929 first edition first impression inscribed by the author
description:
Robert Graves


Good-bye to All That. London: Jonathan Cape 1929


FIRST EDITION FIRST IMPRESSION INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo frontispiece plates original cloth dust-jacket endleaves dampstained dust-jacket torn at extremities (especially at head of spine)


Inscribed by the author: "Shirley [Martinez] from Robert 1978". The recipient was the Graves family's housekeeper on Mallorca who was clearly much beloved as several letters and cards to her from various family members are laid-in including a postcard (signed "Robbie" and in an earlier hand than the inscription in the book) commiserating with her after an accident: "Dear Shirley sorry to hear about your fall [...] Love + levitation. Robbie x." There are also four letters from the author's second wife Beryl to Martinez with many mentions of Graves as "El Rubio". First issue with the Sassoon poem on pp.341-43 (because of which the publisher had to recall this issue) thus inscribed copies are rare. Since the inscription is dated 1978 it seems probable that this was one of Graves's own retained copies eventually gifted to his housekeeper.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Ivor Gurney | Severn and Somme London 1917 first edition inscribed by the author
description:
Ivor Gurney


Severn and Somme. London: Sidgwick & Jackson 1917


FIRST EDITION INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo half-title original cloth lacking dust-jacket minor dampstaining at outer margins (not affecting text) spine sunned


Inscribed by the author: "To Marion Scott Dear Friend and Good Business Agent Nov 6 1917". Scott was the dedicatee of Gurney's later collection War's Embers (see lots 344 and 345) and two poems in this volume also have his holograph dedication: "To Marion Scott". The author has added the place (and sometimes the date) of composition beneath a number of other poems. Gurney's relationship with Scott was the most significant of his life to the extent that Pamela Blevins wrote a dual biography of the two in 2008. There has only been one book inscribed by Gurney at auction for nearly 50 years. A very good copy lacking the dust-jacket.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Ivor Gurney | Severn and Somme London 1917 first edition inscribed
description:
Ivor Gurney


Severn and Somme. London: Sidgwick and Jackson 1917


FIRST EDITION INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo photograph of author pasted in on the front free endpapers rebound in buckram light foxing


This copy is inscribed by the author "To that Bon Chaplain and Good Friend T. Ratcliffe Barnett this Highly Expensive Book from Ivor Gurney December 1917 Seaton Delaval". Gurney was gassed at Passchendaele in August 1917 and evacuated to military hospital in Scotland. On release he was deemed unfit to return to the front and sent on a signalling course at the Command Depot at Seaton Delaval in Northumberland where Barnett was chaplain. Writing to Marion Scott Gurney described Barnett as: "That rare thing especially among his kind of being a Truth-teller Lecturer on English Literature Mountaineer Lover of Men Music and Books. One does not meet men of this kind occasionally not often [sic]." A very good copy.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Ivor Gurney | War's Embers London 1919 first edition the dedication copy
description:
Ivor Gurney


War's Embers. London: Sidgwick & Jackson 1919


FIRST EDITION THE DEDICATION COPY INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo original wrappers lacking dust-jacket front free endpaper toned extremities slightly rubbed


The dedication copy inscribed by the author to his friend the poet and musician Marion Scott: "To M.M.S. To whose encouragement this and my first book are due. From the diffident but grateful author Ivor Gurney June 1919." The printed dedication--also "To M.M.S."--adds a verse tribute to Scott who befriended the eccentric Gurney at the Royal College of Music in 1912 and corresponded with him throughout the war encouraging him in his poetic endeavours and assisting in getting his first volume of poetry published. A very good copy.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Ivor Gurney | War's Embers London 1919 first edition inscribed by the author
description:
Ivor Gurney


War's Embers. London: Sidgwick & Jackson 1919


FIRST EDITION INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo rebound in green morocco slight marginal dampstaining


First edition of the author's second book inscribed in his hand: "To Lascelles Abercrombie with admiration" but--as with a couple of other presentation copies--unsigned. The recipient was a fellow Dymock and WW1 poet and a close friend of the author. Gurney's early musical promise was rewarded with a scholarship to the Royal College of Music where his teacher Sir Charles Stanford considered him a greater talent than Ireland Bliss or even Vaughan Williams. (There are several references to Abercrombie in Blevins's biography of Gurney.) A very good copy.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Thomas Hardy | Selected Poems London 1916 first edition inscribed by the author
description:
Thomas Hardy


Selected Poems. London: Macmillan 1916


FIRST EDITION INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo half-title portrait bust of author on title original cloth lacking dust-jacket in quarter-morocco chemise and slipcase spine slightly sunned


Inscribed by the author: "Clement K. Shorter (in whose paper some of these verses first saw the light) from Thomas Hardy Oct. 1916". The recipient was editor of both the Illustrated London News and the English Illustrated Magazine and an influential Fleet Street figure. Shorter later founded the Sphere and Tatler magazines in which some of these poems first appeared and he was married to the WW1 poet Dora Sigerson Shorter. A very good copy lacking the dust-jacket.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Thomas Hardy | Moments of Vision London 1917 first edition inscribed by the author to John Galsworthy
description:
Thomas Hardy


Moments of Vision. London: Macmillan 1917


FIRST EDITION INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo original wrappers (supplied) dust-jacket dust-jacket slightly soiled


Inscribed by the author to his fellow WW1 poet: "To John Galsworthy with every good wish from Thomas Hardy. Dec. 1917." and with the recipient's bookplate to the front pastedown endpaper. The two titans were both too old for active service but made their feelings about the war clear in their poetry. Hardy inscribed two or three copies to his peers (Edmund Gosse and Sydney Cockerell among them) and one to his wife but there have been none at auction for over 20 years. A very good copy in supplied dust-jacket.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Thomas Hardy | A Call to National Service 1917 first edition initialed by Florence Hardy and inscribed by the author
description:
Thomas Hardy


A Call to National Service. [London]: printed for Florence Hardy at the Chiswick Press 1917


FIRST EDITION NUMBER 1 OF 25 COPIES INITIALLED BY FLORENCE HARDY AND INSCRIBED BY THOMAS HARDY 8vo original wrappers


Initialled by his wife Florence Hardy being number 1 of 25 copies (presumably their own copy). Additionally inscribed: "Corrected by Thomas Hardy May 1917" in his hand on the title-page probably unique thus. Florence wrote in her biography of Hardy: "More verses on the war were written...in December including 'An Appeal to America' [in this volume]. A sad vigil during which no bells were heard at Max Gate brought in the first New Year of this unprecedented 'breaking of nations'". Rare--the last copy at auction was in 1965 which was presented with a letter to Clement Shorter but not inscribed. A very good copy in wrappers.


LITERATURE


Purdy 191-2

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Thomas Hardy | And There was a Great Calm [London] 1920 first edition initialled by Florence Hardy
description:
Thomas Hardy


And There was a Great Calm. [London]: printed for Florence Hardy at the Chiswick Press 1920


FIRST EDITION NUMBER 3 OF 25 COPIES INITIALED BY HIS WIFE FLORENCE HARDY 4to original paper wrappers wrappers split along backstrip


Number 3 of 25 copies of a poem written for a special Armistice Day section in The Times published on 11 November 1920 on the occasion of the burial of the unknown soldier. Rare--there has only been one copy at auction since 1974. A very good copy in wrappers.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Thomas Hardy | Selected Poems London 1921 first edition thus signed by the author
description:
Thomas Hardy


Selected Poems. London: Philip Lee Warner-Medici Society 1921


FIRST EDITION THUS SIGNED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo rebound in green morocco


First edition thus. Copy number 621 of 1025 numbered copies. Signed by the author (although not called for) and rare thus. Auction records show a single other inscribed copy sold in 1995. With the ownership inscription of A very good copy.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Thomas Hardy | Late Lyrics and Earlier London 1922 first edition inscribed by the author to Sassoon
description:
Thomas Hardy


Late Lyrics and Earlier. London: Macmillan 1922


FIRST EDITION PRESENTATION COPY INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR TO SIEGFRIED SASSOON ("(For Siegfried Sassoon) Thomas Hardy") 8vo ownership inscription on front pastedown ("Siegfried Sassoon May 24th 1922") 20 LINES OF MANUSCRIPT NOTES IN INK BY SASSOON ON HARDY'S "CONDENSED TALES" ON FINAL ENDPAPER some other markings and underlinings in the text photograph of the elderly Hardy attached to front endpaper cutting of review affixed to lower paste-down original olive-green cloth upper cover blocked in gold with TH monogram medallion lacking dust-jacket endleaves slightly browned at extremities


A FINE ASSOCIATION COPY. It was while Hardy was preparing this volume for publication that his wife Florence "came upon him one day talking to himself about the iniquities of critics until he suddenly burst out with: 'I wrote my poems for men like Siegfried Sassoon' "(Millgate). In a letter of May 1917 written to Sassoon as the younger poet recovered in hospital from his wounds Hardy wrote: "I don't know how I should stand the suspense of this evil time if it were not for the sustaining power of poetry". In October 1919 Sassoon visited Max Gate for the weekend and presented to Hardy the "Poet's Tribute" a handsomely bound volume in which forty-three poets including Bridges Kipling Yeats Graves Sassoon himself and D.H. Lawrence had each inscribed in Hardy's honour a copy of one of their poems. "Hardy was much touched by the gesture and set himself the task of thanking personally and distinctively each of the poets involved" (Millgate). A note in pencil by Frederick Adams records that Sassoon "apparently received this 24 May 1922 and on 1 June wrote TH that he was trying to review the book and finding it difficult to express his admiration coherently. He never did abandoning the task the same day" though Walter de la Mare's review is tipped to the rear endpaper. 


PROVENANCE


Siegfried Sassoon the sale of his library Christie's 4 June 1974 lot 127; sale of The Library of Frederick B. Adams Jr. Part II: Thomas Hardy Sotheby's London 7 November 2001 lot 583


LITERATURE


Purdy pp. 214-227

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
