description:
Thomas Hardy


Human Shows Far Phantasies Songs and Trifles. London: Macmillan 1925


FIRST EDITION INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo original boards dust-jacket brown half-morocco slipcase slight wear to slipcase


Inscribed by the author: "For Bryn Mawr W. W. School" on front pastedown. The school is in Western Wales and the inscription was presumably done as a gift or for a fundraising benefit. There has only been one inscribed copy of this title at auction since 1974. A fine unopened copy in fine dust-jacket.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: The Hours Press--Nancy Cunard | The Eaten Heart Eure 1929 first edition signed and inscribed by the author
description:
Richard Aldington


The Eaten Heart. Eure: Hours Press 1929


SIGNED BY THE AUTHOR AND ADDITIONALLY INSCRIBED TO NANCY CUNARD FIRST EDITION LIMITED TO 200 COPIES 4to original cloth-backed boards dust-jacket not called for extremities slightly rubbed a very good copy


The fourth book of the Hours Press. This copy is out-of-series and additionally inscribed by the author to the publisher Nancy Cunard--the two were close friends. There is a further handwritten line stating that this is: "Hours Press Own Set" next to the inscription on the limitation page. There have been no inscribed copies at auction since at least 1974. Aldington enlisted as a private in 1916 and rose through the ranks to become an officer. He was gassed and suffered from shell-shock.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: A.E. Housman | Last Poems London 1922 first edition signed by the author
description:
A.E. Housman


Last Poems. London: Grant Richards 1922


FIRST EDITION ONE OF 4000 COPIES SIGNED BY THE AUTHOR original boards lacking dust-jacket endleaves slightly dampstained a very good copy 


Signed by the author and scarce thus. A mailing label in Housman's hand sending the book from Cambridge to Ohio after he signed it is laid-in as is a postcard with Housman's photograph. The only one of the author's collections published during his lifetime to include WW1 poems. The publisher omitted punctuation from the first two lines on p.52 offering to insert an errata slip but Housman replied: "No the blunder will probably enhance the value of the first edition to bibliophiles-an idiotic class."

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Ford Madox Hueffer | On Heaven and Poems Written on Active Service 1918 author's presentation copy inscribed to Ezra Pound
description:
Ford Madox Hueffer


On Heaven and Poems Written on Active Service. London: John Lane the Bodley Head 1918


FIRST EDITION AUTHOR'S PRESENTATION COPY INSCRIBED TO EZRA POUND 8vo original cloth lacking dust-jacket top edge slightly dust-soiled dampstaining and discolouration to spine


Inscribed: "E[zra]. P[ound]. from F.M.H[ueffer]. 17.4.18". Hueffer a fellow expatriate founded The English Review in 1908 which published work by Pound and the two developed a complex enduring friendship over the next 40 years. We have no record of an inscribed copy of this title at auction since 2013 (The Joseph Conrad Collection from the Library of Stanley J. Seeger Sotheby's London 10 July 2013 lot 188). A very good copy lacking the dust-jacket.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Aldous Huxley | The Defeat of Youth and Other Poems Oxford [1918] first edition inscribed to Katherine Mansfield
description:
Aldous Huxley


The Defeat of Youth and Other Poems. Oxford: [B.H. Blackwell 1918]


FIRST EDITION AUTHOR'S PRESENTATION COPY INSCRIBED TO KATHERINE MANSFIELD 8vo re-bound in quarter cloth and paper boards various internal repairs


Inscribed on the front free endpaper: "K[atherine]. M[ansfield]. from A[ldous].L[eonard].H[uxley]. Sept.'18". Mansfield and Huxley had a difficult relationship. The fact that she had caricatured him as the effeminate Eddie Warren in "Bliss" (one of her best stories published the previous month in The English Review) may explain the less than effusive inscription. She had married John Middleton Murry earlier in the year and Huxley would caricature him as the hypocritical Burlap in Point Counter Point (1928). Provenance: Mary Hutchinson (with whom Huxley and his wife Maria were romantically entangled). There has only been one inscribed copy of this title at auction since 1975. A good copy only but a great association.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Max Jacob | Le Laboratoire Central; Poesies Paris 1921 inscribed by the author
description:
Max Jacob


Le Laboratoire Central; Poesies. Paris: aux Sans Pareil 1921


Second edition INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo original wrappers marginal dampstaining throughout upper wrapper detached backstrip becoming fragile


Inscribed by the author to Roland Dorgelis the author of the very popular 1919 war novel Les Croix de Bois. Jacob was a close friend of Picasso and Apollinaire. He was deported to Auschwitz in 1944 and murdered there.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: David Jones | In Parenthesis London 1937 first edition inscribed by the author
description:
David Jones 


In Parenthesis. London: Faber & Faber 1937


FIRST EDITION ONE OF 1500 COPIES INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo green morocco "Royal Welch Fusiliers" stamped in gilt to upper board


Inscribed by the author: "Eric Strauss from David Jones March 23rd 1947". Strauss was the noted psychiatrist who treated Jones during his second nervous breakdown in 1947 (later treating Evelyn Waugh after the breakdown that inspired The Ordeal of Gilbert Pinfold as well as Graham Greene). Jones served from 1915 to 1918 nearly died from trench fever and suffered from severe shell-shock. Ownership ticket "E B Strauss 81 Harley Street London W1" pasted to the binder's blank. Impressively bound presumably for presentation to the recipient.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: D.H. Lawrence | Look! We Have Come Through! London 1917 first edition inscribed by the author
description:
D.H. Lawrence. 


Look! We Have Come Through! London: Chatto and Windus London 1917


FIRST EDITION INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR TO S.S. KOTELIANSKI 8vo original boards lacking the rare dust-jacket marginal dampstaining covers faded and spine sunned spine label browned and chipped


Inscribed by the author on the front free endpaper: "Kot. from D.H.L." S.S. Kotelianski met Lawrence in 1914 and a life-long friendship ensued. Translator of many Russian writers "Kot" was one of the inner circle of friends who were to be the residents of "Rananim" the Utopian community that Lawrence wished to establish at the end of WW1. In one of the nearly 350 surviving letters--the largest number to any recipient--that Lawrence wrote to Kotelianski he declares (in December 1918): "You my dear Kot are a tower of strength--a real tower of strength to us both--and a solitary tower in the land at that." There have only been two inscribed copies of this title at auction since 1974.


LITERATURE


Roberts A10a

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: D.H. Lawrence | Bay London 1919 first edition one of 120 copies on hand-made paper signed by author and illustrator

D.H. Lawrence (author)--Anne Estelle Rice (illustrator)


Bay. A Book of Poems. London: Beaumont Press 1919


FIRST EDITION NUMBER 21 OF 30 COPIES PRINTED ON JAPANESE VELLUM SIGNED BY LAWRENCE AND RICE 8vo wood-engraved illustrations by Rice original boards dust-jacket not called for


One of 120 numbered copies on hand-made paper of a total edition of 200. Lawrence complained repeatedly to correspondents about the publisher ("that miserable little Beaumont" or "that bewildered chicken" and that "17 months he's been at it" and "hasn't done a thing I want him to") and the illustrations but grudgingly acknowledged "the beautiful paper and print". An excellent copy.

THE "DEFINITIVE EDITION" NUMBER 37 OF 50 "SPECIAL COPIES" FROM A TOTAL EDITION OF 550 SIGNED BY THE AUTHOR on limitation page 8vo author portrait frontispiece rebound in pale grey morocco dampstaining at margins (not affecting text)

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Manning ('Private 19022') | The Middle Parts of Fortune 1929 first edition 2 vols inscribed by the author in vol.1
description:
Frederic Manning (as 'Private 19022')


The Middle Parts of Fortune. [London]: the Piazza Press for Peter Davies 1929


FIRST EDITION NUMBER 316 OF 520 NUMBERED COPIES ISSUED TO SUBSCRIBERS INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR IN VOL.1 2 volumes 8vo printed on handmade paper red silk bookmarks brown buckram boards top edges gilt marbled endpapers red slipcase lacking the original unprinted glassine dust-jacket bindings slightly rubbed both volumes in very good condition


First edition in two volumes of the complete text. Number 316 of 520 numbered copies issued to subscribers. Inscribed by the author in volume 1: "To Olivia Shakespear Private 19022. Come avesse lo inferno in gran dispitto. June 1930". The quotation is from Dante's Inferno. The pseudonym "Private 19022" was Manning's service number. An Australian Manning served from 1915 enlisting as a private aged 33 and rising to become an officer in 1917. Manning described the recipient--W.B. Yeats's muse and Ezra Pound's mother-in-law--as "my belovedest aunt" and it was to her that he first showed the manuscript. Prior to the war Manning had established a degree of literary recognition notably attracting the admiration of the influential Ezra Pound for his first book Scenes and Portraits (1909). Following the war with his health precarious his literary career languished until in 1927 the publisher Peter Davies asked him to write something about his wartime experiences. Knowing Manning's reputation for procrastination Davies lured the neurasthenic author to London and shut him up in his flat for several weeks to write not allowing him out and keeping his friends from him. Davies took the manuscript from him page by page and set it in type without allowing Manning any chance to revise the text. Upon publication a number of admirers including Manning's friend T.E. Lawrence claimed to recognise the work as being by the author of Scenes and Portraits. Ernest Hemingway later said that he read "the finest and noblest book of men in war" every year "so that I will never lie to myself nor to anyone else about" war. Due to the controversial nature of the text--later published in expurgated form as Her Privates We--inscribed copies are rare; there have been none at auction for nearly 50 years.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern

A.A. Milne


The Sunny Side. New York: Dutton 1922


FIRST AMERICAN EDITION ONE OF 1500 COPIES INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo original cloth lacking dust-jacket


Inscribed by the author to Frederick Harrison--the leaseholder and manager of London's Haymarket Theatre--referring to the theatre and Milne's association with it. The author served as an officer from 1915 was wounded in 1916 and went on to work in military intelligence until 1919. He was later the author of the "Winnie-the-Pooh" books and though there are several simple WW1 poems this book is not listed in Reilly's bibliography.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Wilfred Owen | Poems London 1920 first edition inscribed by Edith Sitwell
description:
Wilfred Owen 


Poems. London: Chatto & Windus 1920


FIRST EDITION INSCRIBED BY EDITH SITWELL 8vo half-title frontispiece original cloth lacking the scarce dust-jacket endleaves slightly toned


The author's first collection posthumously published. Inscribed by the de facto (but uncredited) editor of the book Edith Sitwell.: "For Joseph Cohen who protects this great poet. In memory of a most happy evening the 9th of April 1957 from Edith Sitwell". Sassoon had insisted that Owen had wanted him to edit the book but in January 1920 he had to go to New York and gave the material he had and what was supplied by Owen's mother to Edith Sitwell. He later criticised her for errors in the editing. Cohen was a professor at Tulane and author of Journey to the Trenches the 1975 biography of Isaac Rosenberg. He also wrote the earlier (1966) speculative biographical booklet Owen Agonistes. Apart from a copy inscribed by Owen's mother this is perhaps the only association copy offered for sale. An officer from October 1915 to November 1918 Owen was killed a week before the Armistice aged 25. An excellent copy lacking the scarce dust-jacket.


LITERATURE


Keynes B2

Wilfred Owen


Poems. London: Chatto & Windus 1920


FIRST EDITION 8vo original boards in the scarce dust-jacket dust-jacket missing large chip from lower right hand-corner of upper panel (c.4.5 x 2.5 inches but not affecting any text) spine ends and lower panel slightly chipped


The author's first collection posthumously published.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Wilfred Owen | Poems London 1920 W.J.R. Turner's review copy
literature: Keynes B2
description:
Wilfred Owen


Poems. London: Chatto & Windus 1920


FIRST EDITION 4to frontispiece original cloth lacking scarce dust-jacket 


The author's first collection posthumously published. W.J.R. Turner's review copy with his ownership signature and a Chatto and Windus review slip laid in. Turner was a journalist and fellow WW1 poet. He was the literary editor of the Daily Herald from 1920-23 (recommended by and succeeding Siegfried Sassoon in this job). He was also a critic for London Mercury 1919-1923. Photocopies of the reviews of the book in both publications are laid-in and it is safe to say that one or both were written by Turner. He was a close friend (and sometime landlord) of Sassoon who contributed the preface to this book. An excellent copy.


LITERATURE


Keynes B2

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Wilfred Owen | Poems of Wilfred Owen London 1931 first Blunden edition inscribed by Siegfried Sassoon
description:
Wilfred Owen


Poems of Wilfred Owen. London: Chatto & Windus 1931


FIRST BLUNDEN EDITION INSCRIBED BY SIEGFRIED SASSOON 8vo original boards dust-jacket red half morocco box binding slightly sunned at extremities dust-jacket slightly soiled


Inscribed: "Edith Olivier. from SS. | 21.3.31." Sassoon contributed the preface to the first edition of Owen's poems. The recipient was a friend and neighbour of Stephen Tennant (one of Sassoon's lovers) and in 1933 she introduced Sassoon to his future wife Hester Gatty. 


PROVENANCE


Anthony Hobson label

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Ezra Pound | Cathay London 1915 first edition inscribed by the author to W.B. Yeats's mother-in-law
literature: Gallup A9
description:
Ezra Pound


Cathay: Translations by Ezra Pound for the most part from the Chinese. London: Elkin Matthews 1915


FIRST EDITION ONE OF 1000 COPIES INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR TO NELLY TUCKER W.B. YEATS' MOTHER-IN-LAW 8vo original printed wrappers preserved in cloth folding box light to moderate foxing throughout wrappers slightly toned and chipped at extremities


Inscribed by the author: "To Mrs. H. T. [`Nelly'] Tucker | With [...] salutations | E.P. March 1915." Nelly Tucker was a close friend of Olivia Shakespear Yeats's muse and sometime lover and was married to Shakespear's brother Henry Todd Tucker. Yeats eventually married Georgie Hyde Lees who was Nelly Tucker's daughter and Shakespear's niece. This tangled web was further complicated as Ezra Pound--who worked as Yeats's secretary--married Olivia's daughter Dorothy (who was also of course Georgie's cousin). Pound and Mrs. Tucker were the only witnesses at Yeats's marriage to Georgie. These poems are Pound's translations of Chinese war poems such as "The Frontier Guard" (p.16) in which he inserts his own reflections on the war. A very good copy in wrappers.


LITERATURE


Gallup A9

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Ezra Pound | Hugh Selwyn Mauberley [London] 1920 first edition inscribed
description:
Ezra Pound


Hugh Selwyn Mauberley. [London:] the Ovid Press 1920


FIRST EDITION NUMBER 90 OF 200 NUMBERED COPIES INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo title-device decorative initials and colophon device by Edward Wadsworth original boards (dust-jacket not called for) binding slightly bowed dampstain to lower board


Inscribed by the author to "BCW" (Bernard C. Windeler) in August 1920. Windeler was a friend of Pound and his book Elinus was published by Three Mountains Press who also published Pound's Indiscretions as part of the same series.


There have only been two inscribed copies of this title at auction since 1974 although one of them (to Scofield Thayer) has appeared three times. A very good copy of an important (and now scarce) book.


LITERATURE


Connolly Modern Movement 35b; Gallup A19

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: John Rodker | Hymns London 1920 first edition inscribed by the author
description:
John Rodker 


Hymns. London: The Ovid Press 1920


FIRST EDITION NUMBER 20 OF 20 SIGNED COPIES INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR (numbered 16-35 of a total edition of 190) 8vo original boards binding slightly soiled


The second book of The Ovid Press with initials and colophon by Edward Wadsworth. Inscribed by the author (himself the founder of The Ovid Press) to an unidentified recipient: "To Carrie Hayland with the author's love" and additionally signed by Rodker on the limitation page. One of the "Whitechapel Boys" Rodker was a conscientious objector and was imprisoned in 1917. The anti-war poem "Hymn to Death 1914 and On" was reviewed by Richard Aldington as being "vain and morbid". A very good copy. Dust-jacket not called for.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Isaac Rosenberg | Poems London 1922 first edition presentation copy from the poet's sister
description:
Isaac Rosenberg


Poems. London: Heinemann 1922


FIRST EDITION ONE OF 500 COPIES POSTHUMOUSLY PUBLISHED PRESENTATION COPY 8vo original boards dust-jacket dust-jacket defective a very good copy


Presentation copy from the poet's sister Annie Wymick inscribed by her to unidentified recipients--Billy and Harry--and with her bibliographical notes regarding the publishing history of the book. One of the 'Whitechapel Boys' Rosenberg enlisted in 1915 and was killed on 1 April 1918 aged 28.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: George William Russell (as "A.E.") | Gods of War 1915 first edition one of 100 copies signed by the author
description:
George William Russell (as "A.E.")


Gods of War. Privately printed 1915


FIRST EDITION ONE OF 100 COPIES INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 4to manuscript corrections on p. 27 (with accompanying manuscript note on half-title: "[author's correction p27"]) numerous items pasted in to endleaves "Oliver Gogarty" written on front pastedown rebound in green cloth original wrappers bound in


The items pasted into endleaves comprise: 


i. autograph letter signed from George Russell to Shane Leslie dated 14 June 1933 "enclos[ing] a copy of the rules of the Irish Academy of Letters" of which Leslie had been elected a member and listing the then-current members of the organisation 1p 4to folded; ii. manuscript copy of Russell's 1916 poem "Salutation" in Leonie Leslie's hand on mourning stationery 3pp 8vo folded; iii. autograph letter signed from Russell to Mrs Justine [?] addressed from 17 Rathgar Avenue Dublin (the author's Dublin Address) no date apologising that "your letter marked 'Friday' only came to me today" since it was erroneously "addressed to 17 Rathgar Road" and apologising as he "would have been glad to see Lady Leslie again" 1p 8vo folded; iv. typescript of a letter written by Russell on his deathbed to his childhood friend Judge Richard Campbell 1p 8vo folded; v. autograph letter signed from Russell's biographer Alan Denson to unnamed recipient dated 22 March 1954 concerning the forthcoming publication of Denson's writings on Russell and asking the addressee to "show me the AE letters you have" 3pp 4to folded; vi. autograph letter signed no date from Russell to "Oliver" [St John Gogarty?] concerning Shane Leslie's nomination as a "'member' rather than an 'associate'" of the Irish Academy of Letters and asking for a "list of works" to support Leslie's nomination 2pp 8vo folded; vii. autograph letter signed from Russell to Leslie dated 28 November 1916 on paper headed "Irish Homestead | Dublin" (i.e. the weekly publication of the Irish Agricultural Organisation Society) declaring that "there is nothing happening in Ireland except the resolving gradually of the old political parties to their atomic elements" 1p 4to folded; viii. signed note in Oliver St John Gogarty's hand no date probably exerpted from longer letter stating that "Miss AS Violet Russell died yesterday" on small slip of paper loosely inserted


Inscribed by the author: "To Shane Leslie with kind regards from A.E. 21.1.16". Sir John Randolph ("Shane") Leslie 3rd Baronet (1885-1971) was a first cousin of Winston Churchill and a prominent advocate of Irish Home Rule. On the verso of the half-title is a manuscript note in Leslie's hand explaining that this copy was "given to me in Jan of 1916 by George Russell the Irish mystic and reread amazingly in 1941". A number of items have been tipped into this copy by Leslie including autograph letters signed and a manuscript copy of Russell's 1916 poem "Salutation".


PROVENANCE


Presented by the author to Shane Leslie: ownership inscription ex libris and engraved armorial bookplate; ownership inscription of Oliver Gogarty (perhaps a relative of Oliver St John Gogarty who was friends with Leslie but died in 1957 some fifteen years before Leslie passed away)

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Vita Sackville-West | Orchard and Vineyard London 1921 first edition inscribed by the author
literature: Not in Reilly
description:
Vita Sackville-West


Orchard and Vineyard. London: John Lane the Bodley Head 1921


FIRST EDITION INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo original cloth-backed patterned paper boards labels to upper board and spine top edge gilt others uncut endleaves toned


A fine copy inscribed "to Irene from Vita Christmas 1921". Irene Hogarth (later Pirie) was a friend of the author from teenage years to late in life. Laid-in is a letter from the author presenting the book to Irene: "I have had this little book specially bound for you & herewith send it". The poems on pp.29 and 30 refer to WW1.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Siegfried Sassoon | Vigils Bristol 1934 first edition inscribed by the author to Lawrence of Arabia
description:
Siegfried Sassoon


Vigils. Bristol: privately printed 1934


FIRST EDITION ONE OF 50 COPIES BOUND FOR PRESENTATION BY THE AUTHOR and number 255 of a total edition of 303 INSCRIBED TO T.E. LAWRENCE 8vo original boards spine lettered in gilt endleaves slightly toned


AN EXTRAORDINARY ASSOCIATION COPY LINKING THE TWO MOST COLOURFUL LITERARY FIGURES OF WW1 inscribed by the author to T.E. Lawrence (a.k.a. "Lawrence of Arabia"): "Salutamus" signed by both Siegfried Sassoon and his wife Hester and additionally signed by the author to the limitation page.


Sassoon and Lawrence were introduced by Eddie Marsh in 1918 and became firm friends until Lawrence's death in 1935 the year after the publication of this volume. Sassoon had become "enthralled by this mysterious figure" as "Lawrence too had been made by the war in his case the campaign against the Turks in the Middle East" (Egremont p. 275). Sassoon was one of the first people to whom Lawrence showed the manuscript of Seven Pillars of Wisdom eliciting the response in a letter that it was a "bloody masterpiece" and ending with the comment: "It is a GREAT BOOK blast you!"


Tipped-in to the book is a handwritten list by Sassoon of the dates that each poem was composed. Loosely inserted is a letter 1p 8vo in postmarked envelope dated 27 January 1957 from Sassoon to this copy's former owner Alan Clodd (1918-2002) the publisher and WW1 book collector referring to Clodd's grandfather having been a friend of George Meredith the subject of a biography by Sassoon.


LITERATURE


For the friendship between Sassoon and Lawrence: Egremont Siegfried Sassoon: A Biography pp. 220; 275

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Siegfried Sassoon | Morning Glory London 1916 first edition inscribed by the author to John Drinkwater
description:
Siegfried Sassoon


Morning Glory. London: Chiswick Press 1916


FIRST EDITION COPY NUMBER 5 OF 11 COPIES INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR TO JOHN DRINKWATER small 4to with Sassoon's pencil notes beneath four poems original wrappers in cloth chemise a near-fine copy


A LEGENDARY SASSOON RARITY Inscribed by the author to his fellow poet: "No 5 for John Drinkwater October 1916 Siegfried Sassoon". With Sassoon's pencil notes below four of the poems detailing where and when they had appeared previously in magazines. These poems were privately published at a time when the author was beginning to turn against the war following the death of his brother Hamo in late 1915 and a year before his first openly anti-war collection The Old Huntsman. The last copy at auction (copy No. 7 inscribed to Sydney Cockerell) was in 1958 and is now in the British Library; there are three other copies located in university libraries at Cambridge Indiana and Texas.


PROVENANCE


John Drinkwater; Henry Lewis Batterman Jr.: bookplates to front pastedown of chemise

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Siegfried Sassoon | The Old Huntsman 1917 first edition the dedication copy inscribed to Thomas Hardy with inscribed carbon copy of A Soldier's Declaration
description:
Siegfried Sassoon


The Old Huntsman. London: Heinemann 1917


FIRST EDITION THE DEDICATION COPY INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR TO THOMAS HARDY 8vo WITH A RARE INSCRIBED CARBON COPY OF "A SOLDIER'S DECLARATION" tipped-in to front pastedown cuttings of Sassoon's lyric "Suicide in the Trenches" and of newspaper article referring to the circumstances of "A Soldier's Declaration" tipped-in to front free endpaper beneath inscription to Hardy six of the poems marked with an "X" in pencil next to the titles original boards paper label to spine dust-jacket housed in blue half morocco collector's case extremities bumped newspaper clipping becoming detached at inner margin case slightly sunned a near-perfect copy 


THE DEDICATION COPY OF THE COLLECTION CONTAINING SASSOON'S FIRST PIECES OF WAR POETRY INSCRIBED TO ONE OF HIS "GREATEST IDOLS" (Egremont) whose poetry Sassoon claimed to have read during the horror of the trenches: "To Thomas Hardy with all my admiration from Siegfried Sassoon. 'What of the faith & fire within us?'" Sassoon penned this effusive dedication having already written to Hardy in February 1917 requesting permission to dedicate the volume to him (Egremont p. 121).


The quotation "What of the faith & fire within us?" is the opening line of Hardy's poem "Men Who March Away". Published in The Times in September 1914 Hardy's lyric captured the prevailing public mood of jingoistic self-confidence at the outset of the conflict. But whilst in its original context the rhetorical question posed by the poetic voice of "Men Who March Away" serves as a rallying cry it holds a very different resonance in the context of Sassoon's 1917 volume a collection of poems registering the true horror of mechanised mass slaughter. Here it is as if the voice of Hardy's soldier has re-emerged as a ghostly echo mocking his old misguided belief in a universe where "Victory crowns the just".


The carbon copy of "A Soldier's Declaration" tipped-in to the front pastedown is a significant object in and of itself. This slight but incendiary document in which Sassoon declines to return to active duty citing a betrayal of the noble principles of "defence and liberation" which compelled a generation of men to make the ultimate sacrifice -- principles which Hardy rather unconvincingly evokes in 1917 in A Call to National Service (see lot 348) -- succeeded in causing quite a public stir being read before the House of Commons and printed in The Times. But it is important to remember that the present copy of the "Declaration" was one of a very small number of copies originally circulated by Sassoon to a select group of "friends and people he admired" (Egremont p. 151).


Unusually Hardy's copy bears a decisive inscription at the upper margin: "I am handing this to my Commanding Officer. SS.". In this context it is as if the inscription and the powerful language of the "Declaration" itself comprise Sassoon's response to the imploring voice of Hardy's soldier in "The Men Who March Away". It is as if the cry of Hardy's soldier has in some measure revived the "faith & fire" within Sassoon not to convince him that the fighting is just but rather to urge his bitter denunciation of a war of "aggression and conquest [...] deliberately prolonged by those who have the power to end it". 


Hardy's own attitudes to a conflict "in which a favourite cousin Frank George was killed" (ODNB) were complex and reading The Old Huntsman appears to have been a moving experience for him. After receiving the present copy he wrote to Sassoon: "I should say that I am not reading th[e poems] rapidly. I never do read rapidly anything I care about". Six of the poems are marked in pencil next to the titles: "When I'm among a Blaze of Lights" (p. 18); "Blighters" (p. 31); "They" (p. 35); "The Tombstone Maker" (p. 45); "The Hero" (p. 48); "Conscripts" (p. 51)--subtle signs of Hardy's careful deliberative reading.


Hardy continued to exert a major literary influence on Sassoon throughout his poetic career and Sassoon paid him a visit at Max Gate in Dorchester in November 1918 shortly before the Armistice. The two writers developed a friendship meeting often during the last ten years of Hardy's life.


PROVENANCE


Hodgson & Co. sale of Hardy's Max Gate library 26 May 1938 lot 225 (cutting from sale catalogue loosely inserted in prelims); bought by Maggs Brothers; acquired by Henry Lewis Batterman Jr.: bookplate; thence by descent


LITERATURE


Jean Moorcroft Wilson Siegfried Sassoon: The Making of a War Poet 2004 ("[Sassoon] told his uncle Hamo [...] that after some gruelling experience in the trenches he would sit down calmly to read Hardy's Selected Poems which he carried in his pocket"); Max Egremont Siegfried Sassoon: A Biography 2006 (for circulation of the 'Declaration' see p. 151); "Hardy Thomas" Oxford Dictionary of National Biography 2004

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Siegfried Sassoon | To Any Dead Officer... Cambridge 1917 first separate edition signed presentation copy
description:
Siegfried Sassoon


To Any Dead Officer (Who Left School for the Army in 1914). Cambridge: The Cambridge Magazine 1917


FIRST SEPARATE EDITION PRESENTATION COPY ADDITIONALLY INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo single sheet folded in quarter-morocco slipcase and chemise one panel of chemise detached


An offprint of one of Sassoon's three verse contributions to C.K. Ogden's anti-militarist magazine: being Number 6 in the series of offprints (from August 1917). Presented "with the author's compliments" and additionally inscribed by Sassoon: "Hilda Gaige from SS 23 December 26" on the cover-title. Laid-in is an autograph letter from Sassoon to the recipient - the wife of Crosby Gaige the American publishers of Sassoon's `The Heart's Journey': "I am sending you the poem you like in the leaflet form of its original appearance" and also requesting that she be "careful not to say anything" about a "sensitive" letter from Florence Hardy which Gaige had only seen "by accident". No inscribed copies of this title at auction since at least 1974.


PROVENANCE


Henry Lewis Batterman Jr. bookplate to front pastedown of chemise

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Siegfried Sassoon | The Redeemer Cambridge 1916 first edition inscribed by the author
description:
Siegfried Sassoon


The Redeemer. Cambridge: The Cambridge Magazine 1916


FIRST EDITION INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR ONE OF 200 COPIES 8vo single sheet folded slightly creased


The first of the three rare offprints of contributions by Sassoon to C.K. Ogden's anti-militarist magazine. Inscribed by the author to "J[ames].S[teuart].W[ilson]. June 1916". Wilson served alongside Sassoon during WW1 and was wounded twice. He was an operatic tenor later taking on senior managerial roles in classical music organisations. No inscribed copies of this work have appeared at auction since 1974.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Siegfried Sassoon | Counter-Attack and Other Poems London 1918 first edition inscribed by the author to W.J. Turner
description:
Siegfried Sassoon


Counter-Attack and Other Poems. London: William Heinemann 1918


FIRST EDITION INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR original wrappers collector's cloth slipcase extremities slightly browned wrappers starting to split along spine


Inscribed by the author to W. J. Turner a fellow WW1 poet and Sassoon's close friend (and sometime landlord). Turner received a review copy of Wilfred Owen's 1920 Poems and wrote reviews of the book for The Daily Herald and London Mercury (see lots 367-70). Sassoon wrote Lingual Exercises (1925) whilst lodging with Turner and his wife Delphine in Tafton Street London. No inscribed copies of this title has appeared at auction for 15 years.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Siegfried Sassoon | The War Poems London 1919 first edition signed by the author
description:
Siegfried Sassoon


The War Poems. London: William Heinemann 1919


FIRST EDITION SIGNED BY THE AUTHOR (and scarce thus) 8vo original boards dust-jacket some spotting binding slightly bumped dust-jacket slightly discoloured


A very good copy in a very good dust-jacket. Perhaps Sassoon's most complete comment on the war including the first trade appearance of 12 poems alongside 64 more of Sassoon's most powerful poems from previous works.


LITERATURE


Keynes A20

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Siegfried Sassoon | Picture Show Cambridge 1919 first edition inscribed by the author to  Henry & Ruth Head
description:
Siegfried Sassoon


Picture Show. Cambridge: privately printed for the author by J.B. Peace at the University Press 1919


FIRST EDITION ONE OF 200 COPIES INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR original boards lacking the plain paper dust-jacket an excellent copy


Inscribed to Henry & Ruth Head and dated June 7 1922. Sassoon has also transcribed the first stanza of Thomas Hardy's poem "My spirit will not haunt the mound".


Sir Henry Head was the neurologist who worked with WHR Rivers at Craiglockhart conducting experiments on his own nervous system. (For a volume inscribed to Rivers see lot 338). Head met Sassoon at Craiglockhart and became a mentor to the poet especially after the death of Rivers in 1922. Head also wrote a book of WW1 poems entitled Destroyers. This copy of Picture Show was gifted by the Head family to Janet Ashbee in 1941. A letter from Sassoon to Janet dated 17.7.1947 is laid-in and an original photo of Sassoon is pasted-in. Sassoon has also signed the limitation page and dated the photograph "New York July 1920". Also laid-in are three clippings of poems by Sigma Sashun (a Sassoon pseudonym) one of which is signed by Sassoon.


LITERATURE


Keynes A19a; Reilly p. 285

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Siegfried Sassoon | Recreations London 1923 first edition inscribed by the author to Max Beerbohm
literature: Keynes A22
description:
Siegfried Sassoon


Recreations. London: privately printed for the author by the Chiswick Press 1923


FIRST EDITION ONE OF 75 COPIES INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR TO MAX BEERBOHM 8vo original boards lacking dust-jacket slight wear to boards upper board slightlysunned a very good copy 


Inscribed by the author to Max Beerbohm (printing his name above the colophon and initialing it below) the caricaturist who was a friend of Sassoon's. Additionally initialled by the author at the head of the spine.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Siegfried Sassoon | Lingual Exercises Cambridge 1925 first edition inscribed to Gabriel Atkin
literature: Keynes A23
description:
Siegfried Sassoon


Lingual Exercises. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press 1925


FIRST LIMITED EDITION ONE OF 99 NUMBERED COPIES INSCRIBED TO GABRIEL ATKIN original boards in the original slipcase extremities of slipcase worn with minor loss


Inscribed to Gabriel Atkin probably Sassoon's first lover of whom he wrote: "One of the divinest things that had happened . . . I was drunk with physical passion then as I'd never had before or since."' (Egremont p.302.) Atkin became a drunk and scrounged money from Sassoon who later said he was "like cheap liqueur". The inscription is to "GA" and initialed "SS". By 1925 their relationship was long over. A nice copy in the original slipcase.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Siegfried Sassoon | Lingual Exercises first limited edition Cambridge 1925 inscribed to Vivian de Sola Pinto
description:
Siegfried Sassoon


Lingual Exercises. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press 1925


FIRST LIMITED EDITION ONE OF 99 NUMBERED COPIES INSCRIBED TO VIVIAN DE SOLA PINTO 8vo original boards lacking original slipcase light foxing a very good copy


Inscribed to Vivian de Sola Pinto Sassoon's second-in-command of A Company 25th Battalion of the Welch Fusiliers in 1918 with de Sola Pinto's bookplate to the front pastedown. de Sola Pinto was a close friend of Sassoon's and also published books of WW1 poetry himself. He was the inspiration for the character `Velmore' in Sherston's Progress and there are many references to him in Egremont's biography of Sassoon.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Siegfried Sassoon | The Heart's Journey New York 1927 first American edition inscribed by the author
description:
Siegfried Sassoon


The Heart's Journey. New York: Crosby Gaige 1927


FIRST AMERICAN EDITION ONE OF 590 COPIES INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo original boards dust-jacket endleaves very slightly spotted


Inscribed by the author: "To Dr. Kaltenbach of Untergrainau from one who will always be grateful to him. Siegfried Sassoon Easter 1929." Sassoon has also signed the title-page and made a correction to p.14. The recipient was a German chest specialist who treated Sassoon's lover Stephen Tennant after his diagnosis of fluid on the lungs in 1928. An excellent copy in dust-jacket.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Siegfried Sassoon | Vigils Bristol 1934 signed and inscribed by the author to Florence Hardy
provenance: Henry Lewis Batterman Jr., bookplate to front pastedown
description:
Siegfried Sassoon


Vigils. Bristol: privately printed 1934


FIRST EDITION ONE OF 50 COPIES BOUND FOR PRESENTATION BY THE AUTHOR INSCRIBED TO FLORENCE HARDY 8vo original boards endleaves slightly toned a near-fine copy


One of 50 copies bound in boards for presentation by the author of a total edition of 303. Inscribed by the author to: "Florence Hardy from her friend SS Heytesbury June 1935". Thomas Hardy's widow published several booklets of WW1 poems by Hardy. Additionally signed by Sassoon on the limitation page.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Siegfried Sassoon | Vigils 1934 first edition number 82 of 212 copies bound in niger morocco signed by the author
description:
Siegfried Sassoon


Vigils. Bristol: privately printed 1934


FIRST EDITION NUMBER 82 OF 212 COPIES BOUND IN NIGER MOROCCO SIGNED BY THE AUTHOR (of a total edition of 303) 8vo original boards prelims browned at extremities


The 22 poems were engraved on copper by Charles Sigrist. The frontispiece was designed and engraved by Stephen Gooden. Laid-in are an additional copy of the title page a copy of the 'proposal' for the book issued by the printer and the printed breakdown of the six different issues comprising the edition. In excellent condition.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Siegfried Sassoon | Poems Selected by Dennis Silk 1958 first edition editor/publisher's own copy signed
description:
Siegfried Sassoon 


Poems: Selected by Dennis Silk. Marlborough Wiltshire: Marlborough College Press 1958


FIRST EDITION THE EDITOR/PUBLISHER'S OWN COPY NUMBER 47 OF 150 COPIES INITIALLED BY SASSOON original calf slight stain at foot of spine an excellent copy


Initialled by Sassoon on the limitation leaf and signed by Silk at the end of his preface. Printed and published by Marlborough College pupils and staff. (Sassoon had been a student there as had Charles Sorley). Silk was a professional cricketer before becoming the headmaster.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Dorothy L. Sayers (Contrib.) | Oxford Poetry 1915 Oxford 1915 first edition Sayers's own copy
description:
Dorothy L. Sayers (Contributor)


Oxford Poetry 1915. Oxford: Basil Blackwell 1915


FIRST EDITION SAYERS'S OWN (SIGNED) COPY OF HER FIRST APPEARANCE IN BOOK FORM 8vo original wrappers wrappers splitting along backstrip


First edition. Sayers's own copy of her first appearance in book form with her ownership signature to the half-title and her holograph corrections to her contribution on p.50 (a poem entitled "Lay" written during her final year of reading Modern Languages at Somerville College Oxford). Sayers went on to co-edit the volumes of Oxford Poetry for 1917-19. Amusingly this slim volume also contains the first appearance in book form of J.R.R. Tolkien and the first appearance in print of Aldous Huxley.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Charles Sorley | Marlborough and Other Poems Cambridge 1916 first edition letters from Sorley's mother laid in
description:
Charles Sorley


Marlborough and Other Poems. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press 1916


FIRST EDITION 8vo 4 letters from Sorley's mother laid in original boards lacking dust-jacket browning to front free endpaper a very good copy


Sorley was an officer from 1914 until he was killed in action on October 13 1915 aged 20. Four poignant letters from Sorley's mother Janetta C. Sorley (granddaughter of the economist Adam Smith) from 1915-16 are laid-in the earliest written two weeks after her son's death at the Battle of Loos: "Is it not strange that we could never see his future clear & defined? but now it is assured . . . It is a great deal to have had in this life even a perfect human experience through Charlie. He was never anything but a spring of joy and strength to us all."


The recipient of these letters was the Sanskrit and Pali scholar Mary Ridding. Janetta explains in the second letter that her husband (the philosopher Willam Sorley) has undertaken a reprint of their son's poems on account of a new poem ("XXVIII") having been sent to them by a friend of Charlie's and that "he had a number of copies of the poem struck off to send to our friends who have the first edition" --this rare offprint is loosely inserted in the present volume. In Goodbye to All That Robert Graves ranked Sorley as "one of the three poets of importance killed during the war" alongside Isaac Rosenberg and Wilfred Owen.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Andre Spire | Et J'ai Voulu le Paix London 1916 first edition inscribed by the author
description:
Andre Spire 


Et j'ai voulu le paix. London: Egoist Press 1916


FIRST EDITION INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo original wrappers staple rusting


An influential and scarce book and perhaps the rarest Egoist Press publication. Inscribed by the author to Mary and Christopher Middleton. The inscription is dated 1963 when Spire was 95 years old. Spire - a close friend of Ezra Pound who was instrumental in this publication in his editorial capacity at the Egoist Press - was an early Zionist and a WW1 poet although too old to be called up. It was at a party at Spire's apartment that James Joyce first met Sylvia Beach.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Robert Stewart | Prison Rhymes [Dundee] 1919 first (sole) edition inscribed by the author
description:
Robert Stewart


Prison Rhymes. [Dundee]: National Prohibition and Reform Party 1919


FIRST EDITION 8vo 4pp ephemera laid in original wrappers some wear


First (sole) edition of these poems written by an imprisoned conscientious objector during the war. Inscribed by the author to Bob Smillie a Miners Union leader who opposed conscription and whose son Alex was also a conscientious objector and was in Wormwood Scrubs gaol at the same time as Robert Stewart. The author was a founding member of the Communist Party of Great Britain in 1920. He rose to be its liaison with the Soviet Embassy and in that role he was involved in the early years of the Cambridge spy ring. Andrew Dodds a Scottish WW1 poet included a poem about Bob Smillie in his 1921 collection "Antrin Sangs". Four pages of ephemera on Smillie laid-in comprising a photo two leaflets and a typed poem. Rare--only three copies are located on OCLC--and a very good copy in wrappers.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Edward Thomas | Poems London 1917 first edition inscribed to Martin A. Freeman
description:
Edward Thomas


Poems. London: Selwyn & Blount 1917


FIRST EDITION ONE OF 525 COPIES POSTHUMOUSLY PUBLISHED INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo original boards lacking dust-jacket extremities slightly browned 


Inscribed to A. Martin Freeman by Thomas's widow on front free endpaper: "from E. & H[elen]. T. Oct 1917". (The author enlisted in July 1915 aged 37 and was killed in action in April 1917 and Helen has inscribed it as if from both of them.) Freeman was a friend of Thomas who collaborated with him on The Pocket Book of Poems and Songs for the Open Air published in 1907 (cf. p.viii of the "Note by Compiler" in that book). A very good copy.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Edward Thomas | Collected Poems London 1920 first edition inscribed by the poet's widow
description:
Edward Thomas 


Collected Poems. London: Selwyn and Blount 1920


FIRST EDITION INSCRIBED BY THE POET'S WIDOW 8vo original boards lacking dust-jacket some browning extremities slightly rubbed


Inscribed by the poet's widow to James Guthrie: "E. & H[elen]. T Oct 1920". (The author enlisted in July 1915 aged 37 and was killed in action on April 1917 and Helen has inscribed it as if from both of them.) Guthrie was the proprietor of the Pear Tree Press and subsequently published Thomas's Six Poems (1927) These Things the Poets Said (1935) and To the Memory of Edward Thomas (1937). The book is further inscribed from James to his son Stuart Guthrie "with love from Daddy Dec 7 1920". A penny postcard postmarked July 28 1939 from James to Stuart is laid-in.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Iris Tree | Poems Nassau 1917 first edition inscribed by the author
description:
Iris Tree


Poems. Nassau Bahamas: privately printed 1917


FIRST EDITION INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo original wrappers wrappers somewhat creased and worn


First edition (preceding the later publication by John Lane in 1919 (New York) and 1920 (London)). Inscribed to her school friend Nancy Cunard: "Nancy Darling from Darling Iris". Tree--the daughter of Sir Herbert Beerbohm Tree and Helen Maud--was much in demand as an artist's model in Bloomsbury and beyond having been depicted in various media by Duncan Grant Augustus John Vanessa Bell Jacob Epstein Man Ray and Modigliani. Her output as a poet was slim but well-received (as was her later acting ability at least by Federico Fellini). The edition was published while Tree was on honeymoon in the Bahamas with Curtis Moffat. Only two other copies of this edition are located in libraries.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: William Peterfield Trent | autograph manuscript of Twilight of the Manikins 1915-1919
description:
William Peterfield Trent


Autograph manuscript of 'Twilight of the Manikins' [New York] 1915-1919


208 pages 8vo manuscript disguised in bound book titled 'The Long Gallery' by Eva Lathbury upper joint cracked


Trent the founder of the Sewanee Review was a professor of English Literature at Columbia when he wrote these poems. Poems by the author had appeared in The Literary Digest The New York Times Fatherland and The Texas Review in 1915 but that appears to be the extent of his published writings. Many of the poems are either pro-German balanced against anti-German hysteria or simply anti-British. The poems read like a diary of his personal views of the war that day (some are dated) and many of them are bitter in tone for example: (page 125) a poem on American Ladies bewailing the loss of babies unless they are German and being starved by Kitchener; (page 98) the death of Kitchener by drowning suggesting that he deserved it. Trent appears to have had no specific German ancestry and he knew Woodrow Wilson as a fellow undergraduate at the University of Virginia. Few of the poems in this book were published. He has pasted in two that were both pro Germany/Austria. The fact that the manuscript is disguised in a bound book suggests that he intended to keep the contents private. There are collections of Trent's papers at the University of North Carolina Chapel Hill Yale and Columbia.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: Edith Wharton | Twelve Poems London 1926 first English edition number 23 of 130 signed copies
description:
Edith Wharton


Twelve Poems. London: The Medici Society 1926


FIRST ENGLISH EDITION NUMBER 23 OF 130 SIGNED COPIES ADDITIONALLY INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo original boards dust-jacket housed in grey quarter morocco slipcase with compartment on front flap of case containing 1p autograph letter signed to dedicatee of inscription prelims slightly spotted dust-jacket split along upper joint with some loss at spine ends letter with slight creasing spotting and closed tear at folds


Inscribed by the author: "For Rutger Jewett with Christmas best wishes Edith Wharton 1926". Rutger Bleecker Jewett (1867-1935) was her friend advisor and editor at Appleton the New York publisher of many of her novels. In the accompanying autograph letter signed to Jewett dated Jan 1 1931 Wharton sends him "best wishes for a happy new year" thanks him for his recent Christmas present to her and assures him that she has "a stern resolution of getting to work again tomorrow".


During WW1 Wharton famously travelled by car with Walter Berry to the front line to report on the war for Scribner's Magazine.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: E. Wilson (contributor)--A. Noyes (editor) | A Book of Princeton Verse 1916 first edition inscribed by Wilson
description:
Edmund Wilson (contributor)--Alfred Noyes (editor)


A Book of Princeton Verse. Princeton: Princeton University Press 1916


FIRST EDITION INSCRIBED BY WILSON WITH A TWO-LINE VERSE 8vo original boards lacking dust-jacket


Inscribed: "Mrs. W. P. Hamilton from Edmund Wilson Jr. Aug 22 1917" with a two-line verse. One of Wilson's poems refers to WW1 and--as Wilson's first appearance in a book--this must be one of his earliest inscriptions.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: W.B. Yeats | The Wild Swans at Coole Dundrum 1917 first edition inscribed by the author to Carroll Carstairs
description:
William Butler Yeats


The Wild Swans at Coole other Verses and a Play. Dundrum: Cuala Press 1917


FIRST EDITION ONE OF 400 COPIES INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR TO CARROLL CARSTAIRS 8vo original boards original glassine dust-jacket an excellent copy


Inscribed by the author to Carroll Carstairs and dated 15 January 1923. Carstairs was the author of two collections of war poetry: My Window Sill and A Generation Missing. He represented himself as a Canadian in order to enlist in the Royal Artillery subsequently transferring to the Grenadier Guards and winning a Military Cross before being severely wounded in 1918. In later life he was a successful art dealer with the Knoedler Gallery.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: W.B. Yeats | The Wild Swans at Coole New York 1919 first American edition inscribed by the author
description:
W.B. Yeats


The Wild Swans at Coole. New York: Macmillan 1919


FIRST AMERICAN EDITION ONE OF 1500 COPIES INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 8vo original boards lacking dust-jacket very slight stain to upper joint


Inscribed by the author: "To my father's good friend Mrs. Cleveland W.B. Yeats 25 May 1920". The identity of the recipient is obscure though she was clearly very familiar to the author and his father John Butler Yeats. There has only been one inscribed copy of the first American edition--expanded from the original Cuala Press edition of 1917--at auction since 1974 (and that copy was inscribed the day after this one). A very good copy lacking the dust-jacket.

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: W.B. Yeats | Later Poems and Plays in Prose and Verse London 1922 first editions 2 companion vols both inscribed
description:
W.B. Yeats


Later Poems [and] Plays in Prose and Verse. London: Macmillan 1922


FIRST EDITIONS INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR 2 companion volumes 8vo original boards both volumes lacking scarce dust-jackets inkstain to upper cover of Plays in Prose and Verse


Each one of 1500 copies both volumes inscribed by the author to an unidentified recipient S.D. Green on October 15 1928. Each book was initially inscribed by Yeats to his wife's grandmother Mrs. Woodmass--the mother of Nelly Tucker (see lots 371 and 405)--in the year of publication. The earlier inscriptions are scribbled out but still legible: "Mrs. Woodmass from W B Yeats Nov 16 1922". The first volume has a number of WW1 poems and is a very good copy; the second is less so both lacking the scarce dust-jackets. I

auction_name: Books Manuscripts and Music from Medieval to Modern
item_title: W.B. Yeats | Selected Poems London 1929 first edition inscribed by the author to his mother-in-law
description:
W.B. Yeats


Selected Poems. London: Macmillan 1929


FIRST EDITION ONE OF 1500 COPIES INSCRIBED BY YEATS TO HIS MOTHER-IN-LAW 8vo autograph correction on p.186 original boards dust-jacket extremities bumped else a near-fine copy


Inscribed by the author to his mother-in-law: "Mrs Tucker from W.B. Yeats Nov. 15 1929". (The publication date was Oct 8 1929.) Edith Ellen "Nelly" Tucker formerly Hyde-Lees was a close friend of Olivia Shakespear (Yeats's muse and sometime lover). Yeats married Georgie Hyde-Lees Nelly's daughter by her second husband Henry Tucker Olivia's brother. Olivia's daughter Dorothy--Georgie's best friend--married Ezra Pound. Pound and Mrs. Tucker were the only witnesses at Yeats's marriage. Yeats was 52 at the time and Georgie 24 but as Yeats scholar Roy Foster notes: "Long afterwards WBY told a later lover that Georgie had been more or less 'reared' to be his wife by Nelly Tucker and Olivia Shakespear who directed her interests towards mysticism in preparation" and that she was "wise beyond her years". Handwritten correction by Yeats to the text of "Sailing to Byzantium" on p.186 (emending "ladies and lords of Byzantium" to "lords and ladies of Byzantium"); the same correction as on the erratum slip (which is present). A very nearly fine copy in dust-jacket and scarce in this condition.
